PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement reported in the Sydney Morning Herald of 27 June 1987 that, `I am very, very confident that Australia has gone through the worst, that the crisis has bottomed and that we are not going to have the repetition of that loss of national income'. I also refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement on the AM program this morning that, `Our view is that we are approaching the bottom of the downturn'. I ask the Minister: When will we reach the bottom of the downturn? Are we in a recession? What confidence can the Australian people have in these statements given the Prime Minister's consistent failure to deliver in the past?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In June 1987 when the Prime Minister made those remarks, which Senator Short has quoted, he was no doubt referring to the very difficult circumstance which the economy had been through in 1986 as a result of the precipitate fall of the dollar. When he was speaking this morning he was not just expressing a view which the Government has but, I think, a view which is pretty widely held at least in large sections of the business community. For example, a number of sectors of the Australian economy-for instance, those companies associated with the production of building supplies and so on-take the view that the current downturn has bottomed. There are differences of opinion about that and so on within the business community, but that is a view, as I say, which is shared by more people outside this Parliament than the Prime Minister.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short asked me whether the economy was in recession or not. There are all sorts of technical answers to that question. I think the technical answer is probably no. When we last had circumstances of the current kind it was in 1982 and at that time, as I recall it, the economy was in negative growth for four quarters-four quarters in a row. Unemployment rose very rapidly to a figure exceeding 10 per cent and wages rose very rapidly. There was a whole range of circumstances in 1982 which are different from the circumstances at the current time. One can debate whether or not there is a technical recession. That is a pretty esoteric argument, I think. Nobody would shrink from the view that the economy is in a period of significant downturn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that answer, but I ask him again: When will we reach the bottom of the downturn?

—I understand there is a golden rule of forecasting that one gives either a figure or a date but never both together. I will adopt the golden rule. It is not a matter about which I am particularly expert-any more than Senator Short or a number of economists who have different views about this matter are; it is not a matter about which I can speculate. I think the Prime Minister's view, expressed this morning, is that we are approaching the bottom of the downturn, and there is no reason for disbelieving that view.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. What is the Government's current assessment of the likelihood of conflict in the Gulf? Has the Government's policy position altered in any way on the question of the Gulf crisis? What is the Government's attitude to certain private initiatives being organised in Australia and elsewhere to secure the release of hostages being held by Iraq?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite the immense media focus of the last few days, there has been no basic change in the Gulf outlook, in our assessment, since I last described that outlook in this chamber. Nor has there been any change in Australian Government policy. It remains our strong hope that the objectives enshrined in the United Nations (UN) resolutions-that is, the complete withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait, the restoration of the legitimate government of Kuwait and the freeing of all hostages-will be able to be achieved peacefully. It remains our belief that these objectives are capable of being achieved peacefully through the sustained and effective application of economic sanctions by the international community. It is quite premature to make the judgment at this stage that that strategy has failed or will fail.

ANSWER.PARA: It also remains the case that the military strike option must remain available in the event that the UN objectives do prove to be unachievable by other means. We hope against hope that war will not be necessary but the stakes are such-not just for the West, not just for the Gulf states, but for the whole future peace of the world-that war simply cannot be ruled out.

On the hostage question, we and every other country with hostages held in Iraq and Kuwait have striven constantly and assiduously through every available diplomatic means to secure the release of all our hostages. In common with every other government with hostages there, we have taken the view that the strength of the international reaction against Iraq and Saddam Hussein is its solidarity, and that that solidarity is compromised by unilateral attempts to negotiate the release of a particular country's hostages. If what is involved is not so much an attempt to negotiate separate terms but simply to plead, on humanitarian or related grounds, for the release of particular people or categories of hostage, the issues are a little bit more finely balanced.

We welcome the release of any persons from the awful situation in which they and their families presently find themselves, and again we have indicated we will not put any obstacles in the way of those who in good faith believe that they have something to contribute to bring this about. But it still, unhappily, remains the case that efforts of this kind tend to compromise the larger objectives we all share-in particular, getting Iraq out of Kuwait and getting all the hostages released. Every release generates some degree of favourable publicity for Saddam Hussein, diverting attention from the crime he continues to commit by keeping anyone there at all. Every release contributes thereby an extra layer of division and confusion to a situation about whose basic moral simplicity we must remain absolutely clear. Every release in that way prolongs the advantage for Saddam Hussein in continuing to play the hostage card and in that way, in turn, makes the situation worse for the great majority of hostages who remain.

There are basic problems, then, in any official or unofficial envoy effort of the kind which has been proliferating. The European Council at its meeting in late October made clear the objections that were held to government negotiated initiatives of that kind. A further meeting of the Community Foreign Ministers is being held today at which the issue will be revisited. It is for all these reasons that the Australian Government and, we believe, other governments are simply not in the position of officially sponsoring or encouraging exercises of this kind, however well motivated they may be.

Finally, our reluctance is all the greater when the person in question has adopted a posture of opposition to Australian or to other international involvement in the Gulf crisis and, indeed, a posture of overt sympathy and understanding for Iraq. Whatever propaganda advantage there is for Iraq generally in these situations is multiplied dramatically when the person being rewarded, as it were, by some hostage release is someone who is perceived-for better or worse, whatever his intentions-as an apologist for Iraq.

We will continue to do everything we possibly can in conjunction with the international community to get all our people out as soon as we can. The best way to do this, in our judgment, is to do nothing that will increase Iraq's confidence, nothing that will prolong Iraq's resistance to the mass of world opinion for any day longer than needs to be the case.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SALE OF MIRAGE AIRCRAFT TO PAKISTAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to assurances he gave to the Estimates Committee meeting of 11 September when he said that the Government of India acknowledges that the sale of Australian Mirages to Pakistan would not represent a net addition of any significance to Pakistan's actual military capability; that delivery was not likely to occur before the new year; and that the Indian Government was at ease, publicly and privately, in relation to the sale of Mirages. I refer the Minister to statements by the Indian High Commission that India expresses its dismay and unhappiness about the sale; that the decision to go ahead with the sale is contrary to assurances given by the Foreign Minister during his talks with the External Affairs Minister in New Delhi in August 1990; and that the manner in which the sale was announced and the lack of sensitivity in its timing and to India's expressed concerns, overlooking understandings given at the highest levels, led India to doubt the Australian Government's appreciation of India's commitment to peace in the subcontinent. Can the Minister explain the divergence between what he says is the position of the Indian Government and the public statements of the Indian High Commission?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot explain what goes on in the minds of Indian High Commissioners who get things as fundamentally wrong as this particular gentleman did on this occasion. All I can say for the record is that what was said in that exchange in Melbourne by the Indian High Commissioner-and, indeed, in any earlier statement to similar effect coming out of the Foreign Ministry in Delhi-was fundamentally wrong.

ANSWER.PARA: The point is, as I have said to this chamber on numerous occasions, that the matter was satisfactorily resolved in Delhi on the basis that Australia made clear that we would not review the Mirage sale, whatever its merits-it was history-other than in a situation where hostilities broke out between Pakistan and India or such hostilities were imminent. By hostilities, as I said in answer to Senator Durack in this chamber some weeks ago, we clearly meant a situation of full scale war between the two countries. We wanted to avoid a situation where there would be ambiguity or some subsequent recrimination by taking a literalist position in an environment where clearly the situation was dramatically headed downhill and war was imminent within a matter perhaps of a week or two weeks by relying on some legalistic interpretation of there not being hostilities where obviously the situation was such as to demand a review so, for that reason, I used the expression `where hostilities were imminent'. That was, I believe, well understood and I used similar terminology in public and in private in both India and Pakistan. I am not saying that there was universal ecstasy about that particular outcome, but it was accepted and on that basis difficulties we have been having in the bilateral relationship were overcome, meetings were resumed--

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the timing of the delivery?

—I will come to that in a moment. I want to make it absolutely clear that that was the agreed-in the sense I have described it-formula. I believe there is no basis for revisiting that formula or seeking to argue that in some sense currently hostilities are imminent in a way that was not the case at the time that I had the discussions in India. Indeed, I do not believe that is the nub of the issue so far as the Indian spokesmen were concerned. What appears to be the nub of the issue is a further comment I made-again, both privately in direct exchanges with the Minister and officials, and also publicly in almost identical terms-to the effect that in any event it appeared unlikely that the Mirages would be delivered until the new year. I explained why I made that judgment. A period until the end of October was allowed under the defence contract for the sorting out of the transport arrangements. At the time of my visit to Delhi, which I think was in August, no arrangements had been made. It was a reasonable assumption, as I said to my interlocutors, that the lead time on these deliveries would necessarily be of some months. It certainly appeared that the Pakistan Government was in no rush to secure a delivery.

ANSWER.PARA: Against the background of that explanation as to why I used the language I did, I certainly said-and I quite frankly acknowledge it-that it did not seem likely that there would be such a delivery until early in the new year. What subsequently happened was that a few weeks ago the Pakistan Government, before the end of the October deadline, not only set in train arrangements for transport, but in fact despatched a ship almost simultaneously from Pakistan which led to a delivery schedule around about now for at least the first batch of the aircraft in question.

There is no question of any assurance being given of a deferral until early in the new year; it was simply an explanation of the circumstances. I believe that was very well understood in India by the Minister and by the Government, and I am very surprised and disappointed as a result that the matter was aired in the way that it was by the High Commissioner. It seemed to me to be an excursion without justification.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Administrative Services whether he would inform the Senate of the outcome, if any, of the meeting of the Australian Council of Service Ministers in Perth last week. Also, can he inform the Senate, in light of the positive response of all States to the Special Premiers Conference, whether a cooperative approach to government purchasing is likely to be adopted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: — He is right; service Ministers met in Perth at the end of October and discussed basically two major issues. One was the question of government purchasing and the other was the Federal Government's highly successful Purchase Australia campaign. I am pleased to announce that by the end of the meeting all State and Territory governments endorsed our strategy-a strategy aimed at increasing the impact of the combined $30 billion government annual purchasing bill on the nation's industry. This endorsement will build on the Federal Government's Purchase Australia campaign and the national preference agreement which was implemented in 1986.

ANSWER.PARA: Also, I ask the Senate to note that the New South Wales Government has supported the campaign and endorsed the strategy. This stands very starkly in contrast to the carping, whingeing Opposition attitude expressed not only by Senator Parer but also by Mr Prosser. Their responses and attitudes have been such that Senator Parer, I think, called this a `communist plot'. He made no endeavour to find out what the Government's campaign is about.

It is pleasing to see, however, that all State governments, as I said, including New South Wales, have seen value in the approach we are taking. It is a responsible approach. It is one that is good for Australian business. It is one that has been recognised by business as being such.

In essence, the Ministers agreed to form a national supply group to recommend ways in which the concept of value for money can be targeted towards stimulating Australian industry. That group, we anticipate, will develop a strategy plan and that plan will be discussed and endorsed, I hope, at the next meeting of the Ministerial Council. It should be recognised that we are talking about big bikkies when we are talking about government purchasing. Thirty billion dollars is the combined purchasing vote of State and Federal governments. The more of that money that we can direct towards local, competitive Australian products, the better it is for the nation.

I instance the fact that every $1m that is spent to replace imports creates approximately 35 jobs and returns a net benefit of over $440,000 to governments and about $260,000 to consumers. State governments recognise the importance of it; it is a pity that the Opposition does not.

In closing, I also say that the campaign is based on a very simple principle-a principle of adopting a value for money concept rather than adhering to the traditional lowest price attitude. By doing so, government programs can enhance the capabilities of industry, can increase the potential of domestic industry to have access to government purchasing and, as a consequence, can increase the potential for a fair go for Australian businesses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has seen the article by former Senator John Stone in the Australian Financial Review of 1 November this year in which Mr Stone addresses the current situation in the Middle East and concludes that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . Saddam won't back down, and if Mr Bush does so, his presidency will be forever linked with that of Jimmy Carter. Mr Bush could not contemplate that outcome. As Commander in Chief, he should soon give the order to move. I think he will do so.

Mr Stone also expresses his conviction that sanctions will fail and that quick military victory is likely. I ask the Minister: first, is the Australian Government as concerned as Mr Stone appears to be about the political future of President Bush; and, secondly, can the Minister assure the Senate that the Australian Government will not join or follow a United States attack on Iraq during the post-Congressional election period?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the first part of the question, we have never taken any notice of John Stone in the past and do not propose to begin now-certainly not in the context of this particular article, which was--
—What about when he was Secretary to the Treasury?

—It was a close run thing when he was Secretary to the Treasury, but once he abandoned that particular pretension to intellectual gentility and got out into the jungle in the way he has done subsequently, he abandoned all credibility. Certainly, nothing he has said in the present context suggests that he has lifted his game since leaving this place. So let us ignore Senator Stone and his prognostications.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of Australia's likely military response in the event that hostilities do break out in the way that I indicated earlier, we cannot exclude such a response from the realm of possibility. That is something on which obviously the Government needs to formulate a considered position, and I do not think it is appropriate to speculate about that at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Government see any compelling reason to destroy Kuwait in order to save it?

—I have made the point that we hope against hope that war will not be necessary in this situation. I think it is acknowledged that, if full-scale ground war does break out in the area of Kuwait, there is a very real danger indeed that the infrastructure of that city-state will be very largely destroyed. That is an outcome that nobody prefers. But we are faced with a situation where there has been naked exercise of aggression in circumstances which are not only of significance for the country of Kuwait, or, as I have said earlier today, for the Gulf, or simply for the developed and developing world because of its implications for the future of the Gulf region and oil supplies, but also of immense significance for the future peace of the world in the post-war era. It is crucially important that this particular act of aggression not be allowed to succeed. We all want to achieve that through the application of sanctions policy and associated diplomacy; none of us wants to see a war becoming necessary. But beyond that I cannot say anything more than that, if a war is necessary, if at the end of the day the military strike option is the only one that will bring that situation about, then it is a result that we have to be prepared to contemplate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to the proposal by the Leader of the Opposition and Mr Howard that the leave loadings paid to Australian workers be abolished? Does he have any information on what the impact would be on wage-earners and the economy generally? Can the Minister advise honourable senators whether or not the Leader of the Opposition and Mr Howard are correct in asserting that Australia is the only country in the world where leave loadings are paid?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to start by saying that mum and dad and the kids are entitled to their holidays this year, and they are entitled to their holidays with a full leave loading. The reason they are is that they have practised wage restraint during the course of the year, and they have practised wage restraint under the accord during the period of this Government. The leave loading is significant because it enables Mr and Mrs Australia to afford to have a holiday. Therefore, since it was first awarded in 1972 it is entitled still to be observed now.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been a couple of peculiar interjections. One was about rising unemployment and restraint generally. I will take those interjections. I think the question of restraint and who should exercise it is a very good argument. Several times in this chamber I have talked about high executive and professional salaries in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that what Clyde Cameron was talking about?

—I will refer to Clyde Cameron next. The interjections can queue up. Their salaries were ripping well ahead of ordinary wage and salary earners' wage incomes. If anyone wants to exercise restraint and call for it, then restraint should be equitable. It should be across the board. It should be fair to all. No one should break out and everyone should observe it.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us go to the record of who has been observing it and who has not been observing it. Taking figures on salary movements in Australia in 1984-85, the salaries of senior managers went up 10 per cent, with wage earners' salaries rising 6.8 per cent. In 1985-86 senior managers received an 11.5 per cent increase, wage earners 6.4 per cent; in 1986-87, senior managers 11.9 and wage earners 6.9; in 1987-88, senior managers 11.4 and wage earners 5.9; in 1988-89, senior managers 11.4 and wage earners 7.4; and last year, senior managers received 10.5 and wage earners 7.2. There is an example of inequitable restraint.

I notice that Mr Howard has done nothing to call upon senior executives in this country to exercise the same restraint as ordinary wage and salary earners. I repeat that mum and dad and the kids are entitled to their holiday this year and they are not entitled to have it ripped off them by stunts such as that which Mr Howard is pulling because the Opposition does not have a wages policy.

Let me go to the second interjection, relating to Clyde Cameron. Clyde Cameron is just plain wrong. It may be that his memory is totally defective. He seems to be donning some sort of theoretical hair shirt today, saying that he is responsible for introducing the leave loading. He is not. The leave loading was first achieved within the Commission in November 1972, before the election of the Labor Government. Mr Cameron, who was Minister for Labour after the election of the Whitlam Government, did not preside over its introduction into the Australian Public Service until December 1973. The industry in which it was introduced in 1972 was the metal trades industry which, as everyone knows, is a benchmark for other industries. It flowed substantially through the economy before Mr Cameron came on the scene. So Mr Cameron is just wrong and the record should be corrected.

While I am correcting the record, another statement was made in this silly stunt style of debate yesterday by Dr Hewson, who said that Australia is the only country where people receive more money when they are on holidays than at work. That statement is inherently wrong in itself because it is not true to say that most Australians receive more money when on holidays than at work because at work they receive a whole host of other award provisions and they work overtime. I have only taken the opportunity to look at Europe, but I can identify Austria, Belgium, Denmark, Greece, the Netherlands, Norway, Sweden and West Germany as all having similar, and in most cases much more beneficial, leave loadings than apply in Australia.

In West Germany it is usual for a person to receive pay plus a bonus of up to an additional month's salary when going on leave; in Norway a person can receive normal pay plus an 11.2 per cent loading which is built into pay during the whole of the year as a holiday bonus; and so on through this list. Mr Hewson, who has bought into this debate as well is, just like Mr Cameron, wrong. Before one starts to talk about restraint and who should exercise it, one ought to look at equitability.

I conclude by saying that if one does not have a wages policy-and the Opposition does not-one cannot govern in this country and one cannot run the economy. We have a wages policy, we can govern in this country and we have governed because of it. At the last election it was said, `If you don't control wages you can't govern'. The electors recognised that and rejected the Opposition. There is no basis for the Opposition, in the absence of any policy on wages at all, simply to trot out a stunt to gyp ordinary Australians out of their holiday at the end of the year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senate Knowles, I remind honourable senators to use proper titles when they are answering questions or asking them.

—I refer the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs to the so-called `blue file' marked `Govt' seized by the Australian Federal Police from the office of convicted Western Australian private investigator, Robert Smith, in December 1988. Was the then Attorney-General briefed on the content of the file? Did not the material indicate that in his work Mr Smith was investigating Liberal politician, Mr Ross Lightfoot, and was paid for this work at the expense of the then Labor Government headed by Brian Burke? Does not the material suggest that instructions were given by Mr Burke and his services officer and driver, Vince Sherington? Were the Federal Police satisfied that the file did not contain any evidence whatsoever of breaches of any Commonwealth legislation? Why was the file delivered to the Western Australian Police Commissioner?

—Senate Knowles has asked a question relating to an incident, or perhaps incidents, which occurred in late 1988. Quite clearly, I do not have a recollection of the activity of the Australian Federal Police in relation to those files and the consequent action taken by them from that time. I will certainly undertake to find out and provide Senator Knowles with an answer.

—I ask the Minister for Industrial Relations whether the recent reports that a nationwide investigation has found that nearly 3,000 employers have been in breach of Federal awards are correct? If they are correct, can the Minister provide details of the investigation and its findings? Can he also advise the Senate what measures are in train or are planned to make sure that employers do not continue to escape their legal obligations to pay their workers their full award entitlements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must preface this answer by saying that of course most employers are honest and seek to pay the correct rate of pay. But there are occasions on which mistakes are made owing to lack of information, and I would counsel employers generally, particularly small employers, to join employer organisations that provide an award service to them so that they can make sure that the remuneration which they are giving to their employees is in accordance with the legal minimum rate set out in awards.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I should also say that the service that the Commonwealth provides through the Awards Management Unit is a service that inspects for underpayment of wages or non-observance of working conditions. Obviously, this service, where it detects breaches, benefits workers in ensuring that their due entitlement is properly paid. It is also a service that advantages employers, in my view, for the reason, as I have said, that employers are basically and largely honest and do not cheat on the legal entitlements of their employees, but those who do-and there are occasions when it happens-ought to be brought to book lest they obtain a competitive advantage over honest employers simply by dudding workers on their wages.
So the service we provide is of benefit to workers, as it is also of advantage to all employers to know that their competitors are observing the right rates of pay.

Having said that, I point out that my Department inspected more than 8,067 firms in the last financial year and found that 2,795 employers were in breach of proper award rates of pay provisions for 15,486 workers. In total, the Department recovered about $4m in back pay for workers who had been underpaid.

In view of that result, we are now taking a further look at how we handle this area of industrial inspection. I am providing further staff to the award management unit to upgrade its activities. Its activities will be concentrated on increasingly providing information and education about what awards are, what the legal requirements under them shall be, how employers should observe them, and what the rights and obligations of employees are. That increasingly will be the focus, as we hope to eradicate these breaches. But we will of course continue always to prosecute employers who are trenchantly opposed to meeting their legal requirements.

I conclude by saying that another problem we have encountered in our survey is that a large number of employers have not met their award obligations to pay superannuation. Since superannuation is a major social advantage to the community, as well as an obligation on employers and a benefit for employees in retirement, we will be concentrating on that aspect in the future. I have written to all superannuation funds, all employer organisations and all unions with members entitled to superannuation cover, drawing their attention to their obligations, and we will now inspect to ensure that there is full observance of superannuation coverage as well.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MR ROBERT SMITH: ALLEGATIONS OF IMPROPER CONDUCT

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to the report in the Sunday Times on 4 November 1990. I quote:

QUESTION.PARA: Disgraced private detective Bob Smith helped dig up political dirt on Opposition politicians and police while he was working for the Burke Government according to files seized by Federal police.

Smith was performing a $6,500 per month plus expenses debugging contract with the State Government. Has the Minister called for an explanation by Mr Burke, now Ambassador to Ireland, regarding these allegations of improper behaviour? Is the Minister satisfied, or will he satisfy himself, that Mr Burke was not involved in or had any knowledge of investigations carried out by Mr Bob Smith on Liberal politician, Ross Lightfoot?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the first occasion on which Senator Crichton-Browne has sought to malign the Ambassador to Ireland for reasons of squalid domestic politics in Western Australia.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I do not mind the Minister misleading the Senate and the Parliament by his first claim, but to suggest that I have reflected in that way is grossly improper, and I ask him to withdraw it.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw it.
—Imputations of ill political motives are par for the course in this place. It would be less than appropriate on that basis for me to withdraw it.
—Order! I ask the Minister to withdraw the inference that he made.

—I withdraw the comment, Mr President, in deference to your ruling. In relation to the substance of Senator Crichton-Browne's question, I have no knowledge of the article or report to which he refers. I will dig it up and see what action may be appropriate in all the circumstances.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Small Business and Customs to an article which appeared in The Australian magazine on 2 June this year entitled `The Bird Snatchers', in which it was alleged that Australian fauna is being smuggled to Californian dealers aboard some of the many Australian Customs exempt military flights emanating from the United States base at Pine Gap. According to the article, two separate dealers referred to what they called the `Pine Gap racket', while aviculturalists said that Customs and wildlife officials knew all about the racket but `can't touch it'. Is the Minister's Department aware of these claims by its officials at Alice Springs and is it true that they cannot deal with this issue? If this is true, why is it so, given that Australian Customs have in the past claimed the right to check the regular United States Military Air Command flights coming through Richmond and Alice Springs? Finally, is the Minister aware that we are talking about an illegal trade worth millions of dollars a year, with some birds fetching up to $30,000 a pair? Is he prepared to thoroughly investigate these claims and report back to the Senate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The article in the Australian magazine of 2 June has been drawn to my attention. The subject of that article is what Senator Vallentine refers to as the Pine Gap racket. The question of Customs searches of United States military aircraft operating in Australia has been raised on a number of occasions. The answer that I am going to give Senator Vallentine repeats the answer which has been given, as I say, on a number of occasions.

ANSWER.PARA: First of all, United States military aircraft landing in Australia are subject to Customs, health and quarantine controls. Secondly, Customs officers can and do conduct searches of those aircraft in accordance with the risk assessed, just as they do with any other suspect vessel or aircraft. The searches extend to goods and persons arriving or leaving on these United States military aircraft flights.

Much of the information in that particular article in the Australian magazine is very old and first appeared in the media in about 1983. Allegations that Australian birds were smuggled out of Pine Gap aboard United States aircraft were certainly published in newspaper articles in September 1979 and, perhaps, first appeared even earlier than that. Australian and United States authorities reacted to the allegations during the early 1980s by conducting a series of search operations and so on, but nothing was found to indicate that there was any substance to them.

I am sorry that this is such a long answer but as Senator Vallentine and I are the only two people interested in it I do not think it particularly matters. I have obligations imposed on me and I am going to give a very long answer. Australia and the United States of America are member parties to the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Flora and Fauna. Under this Convention the trade in parrots is subject to stringent international control. The illegal export of any Australian parrot to the United States constitutes breaches of both the United States Endangered Species Act and the US Lacey Act, as well as being an offence under the Australian Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982.

The Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service has, for many years, maintained close liaison with the United States Fish and Wildlife Service on such matters as combating the illegal traffic in fauna. United States military flights have received attention in the course of that liaison but still no suggestion of smuggling has been uncovered. Stringent security controls over these flights and over the Pine Gap installation provide a strong deterrent against their use as a smuggling conduit.

That is a long answer. To recapitulate on a couple of the main points in my answer: this very old allegation, which was probably first raised in the media late in the 1970s, first emerged as a serious allegation in 1983 and has been recycled in this article in the Australian magazine on 2 June.

In answer to the somewhat stroppy-if I can use that word, because I cannot think of another-substance of Senator Vallentine's question, Customs has the authority to conduct searches and it does conduct searches from time to time on the same random sample basis as it does for other vessels which may or may not be bringing contraband into Australia or taking wildlife out of Australia. Nothing has been found in the course of those searches and a lot of the information which is alleged in Senator Vallentine's question is very old and totally unsubstantiated by the circumstances. I thank the Senate for its indulgence in respect of this somewhat lengthy answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. He is a former dean of law. Can the Minister explain how Saturday's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) elections could be held to elect members of the Torres Strait Regional Council when the regulations establishing the Regional Council have never been tabled in the Senate? Would the Minister agree that the Government has put the Torres Strait Regional Council elections in doubt by not tabling regulations which are required to be tabled under section 116(5) of the ATSIC Act, which states that the notice of election provisions is a disallowable instrument? Does the Minister agree that the ATSIC elections on Saturday for the Torres Strait Regional Council elected a body whose method of constitution has never been publicly notified, whose potential membership has not been notified, and whose method of election and terms of office have not been notified? In fact, all matters provided for in the Act had not been ratified by Parliament before the elections were held. Is this the type of incompetence the Prime Minister is referring to when he is making a desperate plea for Ministers to lift their game?

—I think Senator Boswell's question might have been better directed to Senator Collins, representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. My obligations in this matter were probably at their height late on Thursday afternoon-Thursday evening-when I provided legal aid to enable a challenge to go to the Full Court of the Federal Court of Australia to enable this matter to be looked at before the election. As I recall, the Full Court of the Federal Court nevertheless decided that it was not essential that the matter be resolved then but that a remedy could be sought after the election. Given the fact that the Full Court of the Federal Court is still to hear argument on the sort of matters raised by the honourable senator, I believe that it would be improper for me to comment any further.

—I draw the attention of the Minister to the fact that the court action was taken not on this particular regulation that was not tabled in the Senate but on another one. My supplementary question is: If Senator Tate is not prepared to answer that question, could I direct that question to Senator Collins?
—I think it was a good try. I call Senator Crowley.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I understand the first round of applications for funding under the cooperative research centres program closed last Wednesday. Can the Minister advise the Senate what has been the response to the program and, in particular, can he give any information about the timetable for the establishment of the centres?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some press reports, I think today, about the cooperative research centres, and may I say that the Government is very pleased with the response to the announced program. A total of 120 applications have been received in the first round and the program will address a major weakness in Australian science by forging closer links between research institutions and industry and other users. I think those administering the program have to be very careful to see that the industry links are strongly established and that the research centres program is not in any major sense captured by academic scientists-a note of personal warning, if I might say so.

ANSWER.PARA: The applications which have been received embrace many fields of science and technology, including areas such as agriculture, mineral processing, computing and robotics, new materials, waste management, the environment, and medicine and health. It is a requirement of the program to have at least one higher education institution involved, but a number of the applications in fact bring several universities together and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation is a participant in more than half the applications. I should say that the extent of the end user involvement is also encouraging with private industry, State Government departments and Federal agencies being involved in the majority of proposed centres with a good geographical spread.

The Government now has the task of selecting from the 120 applications a maximum of 15 centres to be set up in the first round and the results of that will be announced in March 1991. The assessment will be carried out by the cooperative research centres committee chaired by the chief scientist, Professor Ralph Slatyer, with the assistance of two expert panels.
I understand that the quality of the applications is excellent and the Government is extremely optimistic about the benefits which this program will bring to science and industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. Given that the Federal Airports Corporation regards Darwin as one of its fastest growing airports-and the Minister regards it importantly as a personal pet project-why has Darwin Airport safety been downgraded to the point where no safety officer is on duty between the hours of 10 p.m. and 6.30 a.m. when a significant number of passengers and cargoes arrive in Darwin? What are the contingency plans in the event of an international, air medical, military or other aircraft requiring an emergency landing during these hours? Is the Minister willing to take responsibility for the coordination of a response to such an emergency?

—Under the new arrangements that operate within the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC)-new arrangements which in fact I support-responsibility for decisions in respect of issues such as that raised by Senator Tambling is allocated to local administrations. The manager of the FAC airport at Darwin did in fact take that decision in the terms Senator Tambling described. The matter was almost immediately drawn to my attention. The FAC is currently examining the basis of that decision. I will be consulted on that by officers of the FAC shortly. When that happens, I will be happy to provide Senator Tambling and the Senate with the response of the FAC to the decision taken by the Darwin Airport manager.

—I ask a supplementary question of the Minister. As part of that review process has the Minister taken responsibility for emergencies and is it proposed that the review will in fact totally review safety at Darwin Airport? What other airports are subject to similar downgrading of safety officer shifts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Federal Government did not set up either the FAC or the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) for the purpose of second guessing every decision they have taken. The Government is not in the business of doing that and in fact the boards of the FAC and the CAA have the ultimate responsibility for decision making within those organisations. Quite properly, as Minister, I am happy to examine any matter of concern in the aviation sector which is raised with me, and that is all I am doing on this occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: I might add that in the past where concerns have been raised with me about decisions taken by the FAC, they have on almost every occasion that I can recall subsequently been totally justified by the management of the FAC and/or its board. I have no doubt that on this occasion the same will occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to back its decision on this one?

—I thought that I was clear enough when I said where that responsibility ultimately rested. However, on the question of safety, and the implications of safety, I am of course the person ultimately responsible to this Parliament for the safety of passengers using both the airlines in Australia and the terminals that service them. For that reason I am always anxious to take up directly with either the FAC, or the CAA when appropriate, matters relating to safety, as I have done on this occasion. When the decision taken by the FAC manager in Darwin has been examined, I will, in accordance with the undertaking I gave two minutes ago, respond to Senator Tambling's question and advise the Senate of the outcome of that investigation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The question is in two parts, both concerning markets for rural produce. What action is being undertaken to increase opportunities for overseas sales of Australian rural products? Specifically, have any negotiations taken place with any particular countries to facilitate the sales of Australian rural produce? Have any alternative sales strategies-for example, counter trading, bartering, joint ventures or internal manufacturing projects-been undertaken? Secondly, with the continuation of subsidies and bounties by other countries for their rural producers, will this Government protect our primary industries with tariffs equal to the level of overseas subsidies and bounties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I do not know whether the timing of this question is deliberately designed to invite the Government to embarrass itself before the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). Members of the Senate may know that currently the multilateral trade round is going ahead at GATT and that our policy, as the leading country in the Cairns Group of countries, is to push within that forum, and in fact to provide as a model for ourselves, the level playing field concept, the removal of protection, so that there can be free trade in agricultural products in the world. Quite clearly, that is in Australia's domestic interests, as it is in the interests of growers in other countries, so that there is not subsidised production resulting in huge surpluses being built up that cannot be sold and are therefore released onto the world market, depressing prices for growers of commodities who in fact would be competitive were those subsidies not to be in place.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the Senate that we support free agricultural trade in the world. We are moving to a system of applying that to ourselves. We are arguing for the barriers to be wound down elsewhere. It is an important issue.

In the honourable senator's question there were several subsets of questions regarding what we may have done in specific markets or what we may have done with specific commodities to promote them into particular markets. A series of initiatives has been taken but it is too long for me to list here. I will take that on notice and reply in due course.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister referred to a level playing field. I ask: Where is this level playing field? Is it only in rural Australia or are we really trying to get the rest of the world to play Australian Rules?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obviously an objective we are striving to bring to the world because there are not sufficient level playing fields to enable free trade and commerce between countries. It is a desirable objective to have and one for us to apply as a model to ourselves.

ANSWER.PARA: If the honourable senator thinks we can subsidise our production in this country and not suffer retaliatory subsidies in other countries which shut us out of markets, then he is living entirely in a fool's paradise.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October, Senator Coulter asked me a question about the multifunction polis. It is a long answer and I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
On 17 October 1990 (Hansard, page 3239) Senator Coulter asked Senator Cook, as Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, the following questions without notice:

In respect of studies of the proposed Gillman site for the Multifunction Polis, commissioned by the South Australian Government, does the Federal Government accept that these studies should be released? What efforts will be taken to ensure that they are released for public scrutiny?
The answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

These studies were commissioned by the South Australian Government and formed the background to its submission. The Federal Government has no knowledge of their contents, except as reflected in the submission by the South Australian Government.
An assessment of the full site is currently being undertaken as part of a two stage study to demonstrate whether the ``Gillman Crescent'' would provide a viable site for a new urban development.
Stage one will involve a site evaluation and will encompass a complete assessment of environmental questions. It will in part draw on the earlier studies as well as additional new work.
A strategy for development of the site will be prepared in stage two.

The results of the stage one study will be released for public consideration in early 1991 with stage two scheduled for completion by 31 March 1991. The documentation will be publicly released in a form that can be understood by lay people.
At that time, details of the previous reports into the site will also be released.

It is intended that the MFP Community Consultation Panel canvass public reaction to this site assessment study as part of their role in advising the two Governments on community attitudes to the MFP initiative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 17 October, Senator Knowles asked a question without notice of Senator Cook which was referred to me as it was an economic question. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
On 17 October 1990 (Hansard, page 3244) Senator Knowles asked the following question without notice to Senator Cook:

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In light of the earlier comments by Senator Button that major projects have been stalled on economic grounds, does the Minister share the concern of the Executive Director of the Business Council of Australia that 35 per cent of new projects have been so affected at a cost to Australia of $9 billion? If so, what will the Government do to prevent this trend continuing to Australia's great detriment?

While I do not fully agree on the specific numbers quoted and the reasons given, the Government is aware that many potential projects in resource processing sectors do not become actual developments. The Government has identified several reasons for this, including the relatively high cost of capital, micro-economic reform issues in areas such as rail transport, power pricing, generation and distribution, multi-tiered and complicated planning and approval processes and complex environmental and resource access/security issues.
While each of these impediments individually may impose only a minor cost penalty upon processors, taken together they can represent a barrier to investment in such activity in Australia.
We need to take a strategic view of these complex issues and convey to Australian and international investors that we are serious about developing world scale resource processing projects.

That is why the Special Premiers' Conference has agreed that action be taken to simplify processes and provide consistency of approach in environmental regulations and procedures; standards and planning issues; to approval processes; to implement a more efficient national transport system; and to identify and act on areas for increasing efficiency in the power generation and distribution sectors.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CAPE YORK: DEVELOPMENT OF SPACE BASE

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 11 October, Senator Kernot asked me a question relating to the status of the Cape York land use study. Again, as the answer is somewhat long, I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-
On 11 October 1990 (Hansard, pages 2916-2917) Senator Kernot asked me the following question without notice:
What is the Federal Government's view of the present status of the (Cape York) land use study;

Does the Minister support the action of the Queensland Premier in breaking yet another promise-that is, the Queensland Australian Labor Party's promise of a moratorium on development in the Cape York area while the study was under way;
What is the point of a jointly funded study whose outcome is pre-empted by the Queensland Premier?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

Last December the Government decided that support for the spaceport was to be subject to the results of a joint Land Use Study for Cape York to be conducted by the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government, of which the Environmental Impact Statement for the spaceport was to be an integral part.

Arrangements for the Land Use Study have commenced. In August the Government agreed to the conduct of the study and endorsed a set of objectives and a plan. The Government also agreed to the establishment of a Commonwealth/Queensland Steering Committee to develop agreed terms of reference for the study and to monitor its implementation and development. Commonwealth and Queensland Government officials are continuing with their examination of suitable administrative arrangements for the jointly funded study and study guidelines.

Following the Government's decision last December on the need for a spaceport Environmental Impact Assessment, guidelines for the assessment were developed jointly by the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments. These were issued to the proponent, Cape York Space Agency Pty Ltd, on 11 October 1990.
The intention of the Government is that the Environmental Impact Assessment and the Land Use Study will run in parallel.

Whilst the Land Use Study will take a number of years to complete, it is the expectation of both Governments that a sufficient part of the study will be completed, on a priority basis, within approximately two years to enable integrated decision making on currently identified land use issues, such as the Cape York spaceport, without causing undue delay to these decisions.
The Queensland Premier's statement is consistent with this agreed approach.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add to an answer that I gave on 17 October to Senator Reid on a question that she had asked about powerlifting. My response on that occasion was based on advice prepared by the Australian Sports Commission, and I tabled that advice for the information of honourable senators. Since receiving that advice, I have been informed that it contains a minor inaccuracy which I now seek to correct. The information provided to me indicated that the Australian Sports Drug Agency endorses the Australian Powerlifting Federation as the recognised powerlifting body. The Agency, of course, has no such role, which is the responsibility of the Australian Sports Commission.

ANSWER.PARA: The position of the Australian Sports Drug Agency with respect to powerlifting is that it supports an amalgamated powerlifting organisation with an independent drug testing program conducted by the Australian Sports Drug Agency which will monitor the resolve of that organisation to eliminate drug use amongst its members. It has no position on which organisation is recognised by the Commonwealth as the controlling body for the sport of powerlifting in this country. As I indicated in my response on 17 October, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mrs Kelly, has asked the Commission to review the matter and report back to her.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament: This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Apartheid in South Africa
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

That they are committed to the elimination of the abominable and inhuman system of apartheid in South Africa, as practised by the minority Government of that country, consistent with the promotion of human rights and civil liberties.

Urge the Federal Government to formally request the South African Government to immediately cease the practice of apartheid, by repealing all laws and regulations relating thereto, and by the release of any political prisoners detained by virtue of such laws, and by any other means consistent with the human rights and civil liberties of all its people.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL HEALTH AND MEDICAL RESEARCH COUNCIL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

This National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) report confirms what many of us know but do not always acknowledge. The fact is that Australia has a large body of distinguished researchers undertaking work of world class. To see that we need to look no further than the pages of this report, which details the work of recipients of Commonwealth funds made available through the National Health and Medical Research Council. For instance, we read of research into anti-inflammatory treatment which provides real hope for asthma sufferers; we read of ways of preventing bone loss with consequent benefits for sufferers from osteoporosis, and that particularly includes many Australian women; we read of research into Alzheimer's disease, research into cancer, and research into multiple sclerosis; we read of a tendon reconstruction method that results in patients using fingers or toes within a week of operation rather than within a six-week period as presently occurs; and we read of new understanding of factors contributing to emotional problems of children and to the question of depression which occurs during pregnancy.

These are research projects undertaken as part of Australia's research effort. There are many other examples, each of them with the potential to improve the quality of life of many Australians and to improve the quality of life of people beyond our shores, because the application of research is international.

In 1990, through the National Health and Medical Research Council, the Government has supported 948 researchers with project grants; it has provided support to 23 research teams with 23 program unit and block grants; and it has provided more than 250 training fellowships and undergraduate and post-graduate scholarships, all of which have helped young researchers. In addition, there have been 21 research fellowships awarded or renewed for top flight career and medical researchers, bringing the total number of such researchers supported by NHMRC to more than 130.

This report offers us one other opportunity. This will be the last report from the NHMRC under the chairmanship of Professor John Chalmers, a resident of your city, I believe, Madam Acting Deputy President, but a former colleague of mine. One might say that he has the best of both worlds. Professor Chalmers has been a distinguished member of the research community and his tenure of the post of chair of the NHMRC has been a distinguished tenure.

I would also like to place on record our welcome to his successor, Dr Diana Horvath, who has taken over as Chairman of the NHMRC. She brings an impressive portfolio of achievement already to the position she has taken. I am sure I join all honourable senators in wishing her well in her tenure of this important post. If under her chairmanship the NHMRC can continue to achieve in the ways which I have set out and which are contained in this report, it will indeed be serving Australia well.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN MEAT AND LIVE-STOCK RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT CORPORATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I congratulate the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation on its annual report and on the research work it has done into major areas affecting the industry in both the on-farm and the off-farm sectors. As I read the report, I noted that the Corporation commissioned a number of research programs to service urgent industry needs. A number of them were designed to address the following objectives: to maximise the benefit for Australian producers and processors from the expanding Asian beef markets; to increase the volume of land going into the higher value domestic and export markets; to increase the demand and price for Australian sheepskins; and to increase the productivity of cattle and sheep by genetic engineering or rumen microbes.

I can tell honourable senators that, however fine and commendable these objectives are, I doubt that there has been much success with them in the past year. That, as we all know, is because there has been a dramatic turnaround in the fortunes of anyone associated with the Australian rural sector. Already honourable senators would know that the nation's greatest single export earner-the wool industry-has had its confidence shattered by this Government's decisions.

We also have a beef industry which is struggling for survival. Although it has been receiving high prices, which regrettably are now falling fairly dramatically, it is being smothered by escalating costs and government charges. It does not matter whether we produce the goods: factors outside the farm such as disastrous government decisions on rural issues, in addition to the Government's economic policies, mean that being on the land is just not profitable. I can speak from experience as one who lives on the land and knows of the bills that have to be paid.

I particularly noted that the Chairman said that the decade we have just entered will be a testing one for our sheepmeat and beef industries. He is certainly right about that. He also stated that our markets and consumers' needs are changing significantly and that both sectors must change with them. Producers will have to produce to market specifications which best suit their enterprise and processors will have to reduce the cost of processing and lower the two to three times difference in costs which exists between Australia and its competitors.

Failure to do so will relegate the Australian meat industry to producers of manufacturing meats only and will force us to forgo the premiums associated with quality. In order to lower this difference in cost between Australia and its competitors we should also be looking at the imposts placed on small rural businesses and farming families by bureaucracy and big business. An estimated 30,000 farmers are currently suffering a cost price squeeze which will force many from the industry in the 1990s to join the 30,000 farmers who have already left the industry over the past 30 years. That statistic will surely add weight to the Chairman's predictions for the 1990s. Currently, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics estimates that the real net value of farm production will fall 51 per cent in 1990-91 to $1.6 billion.

Australia has a golden opportunity to become the world's greatest agricultural exporter with its pollution-free food. We are on the doorstep of rapidly emerging Asian markets, the demand from which is expected to lift commodity prices in real terms for the first time this century. But, in congratulating the Corporation on the report, we note that there is no doubt about the importance of the Corporation and its work. I certainly commend it for the tremendous job it is doing-with what I might add is little support from the Labor Party and its union-controlled Government-to identify, and help find the solutions to, many of the problems that face the Australian meat and livestock industry.

I must say that I do not find that the Department of Defence Annual Report 1989-90 is a particularly satisfactory annual report. I am sorry to have to say that. I think that, a little like the explanatory notes in the Budget documents, there was not sufficient detailed information. Unfortunately, what is provided in the report is not consistent with what was provided in previous years, so it is very difficult to make comparisons. It is a much smaller report than last year's report and the material in the appendices contains very much less statistical information than we have had previously.

I want to refer briefly to five areas which were previously covered in the appendices and which do not appear in this report. These include a list of the Australia Defence Force units and establishments. This was a very valuable appendix. It gave the facility name of the Army, Royal Australian Navy or Royal Australian Air Force-of all Defence establishments across Australia-and it listed the formational unit and the equipment held at the location. The information was broken down into categories such as land command, logistic command, operational command, et cetera, depending on the service. It was really a very useful ready reckoner for knowing exactly what was where and when. That information has now been excised from the annual report. I hope that it reappears next year because it will be missed by many people who are concerned with defence matters.

The second appendix which did not appear this year is the financial statistics appendix. This information was also formerly contained in this appendix and was extremely valuable. It included statistics such as defence function expenditure and revenue and outlay as a percentage of gross domestic product. It included comparisons of the Commonwealth departmental budget sector outlays and comparisons of expenditure on the defence function in Australia, the United States and other countries. It included production establishments revenue and costs and included Garden Island Dockyard production and work values. Some of the information that was formerly included in the appendix does appear in this year's annual report, but it is not in the same form and that, in itself, is unsatisfactory.

I was particularly concerned that a personnel statistics appendix does not appear in this year's Defence annual report, and that is absolutely unbelievable. I suppose one could understand why-the Government would be wanting to try to hide the Defence personnel facts. But I would have expected the Department to put them on the record. The situation is the worst it has been for 10 years and the Australian people have a right to know that from the annual report.

Where there is personnel information, it is largely inconsistent with that of previous years. It is difficult to make comparisons in respect of the distribution of service personnel and civilian staff; the separations in the Defence Force over the last five years; the enlistments over the last five years; the geographic distribution of reserve personnel with training obligations over the last five years; and defence civilian targets. Another appendix which is missing is information on training and staff development. That means we no longer have information on cadet, trainee and apprenticeship schemes.

Admittedly, as I said earlier, some of these things have been subsumed into the body of the annual report but they are not in the same form and they cannot be accurately compared with earlier years. Honourable senators will recall that guidelines require annual reports to be as consistent as possible year after year just so that everybody can see the development that has taken place over the years. This year's information, in many cases, has an extra bit added or something has been left off that which was provided last year. That alters the end result and makes it near impossible to compare figures from year to year.

This is becoming a bit of a trend with Defence. We see a similar situation with explanatory notes and even questions taken on notice. Senator Vallentine asked a question on 16 August this year regarding military bases. She wanted an update on information that had previously been asked for by John Spender. She got, really, a refusal to answer the question. Yet Gordon Scholes, when Minister, had answered John Spender in considerable detail. Scholes, himself, had been answered on the same question in great detail by Minister Killen. In other words, Ministers have been asked to update an answer that was given all those years ago. However, gradually those updates are becoming restricted and members of parliament are being prevented from doing their job. This refusal of the Department of Defence-with or without the Government's knowledge, I cannot say-is unacceptable. The Department should recognise that it is open to scrutiny like every other department of state in this country and that this Parliament will not accept that information be restricted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to begin with a positive comment on the 1989-90 annual report of the Department of Defence. Under the heading `The Labours of Hercules: Defence Assistance to the Civil Community' the report covers an area in which the Australian Defence Force (ADF) often is an unsung hero-and, of course, that includes heroines these days.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I want to commend the defence forces for their incredible services to the community in relation to the aftermath of the earthquake which struck Newcastle on 28 December 1989 and the bushfires which raged around Albury soon after that time. Later in the year, of course, many areas of Queensland and north-west New South Wales were flooded and the ADF did a sterling job in assisting the community. It is this aspect of the ADF's program that I heartily endorse and recommend. I suggest that it should do an even better public relations job on those positive aspects of its role in the community than it has been able to do to date. It is this kind of role that the ADF should be doing in between its military exercises about which, of course, I am often critical.

I would like to mention the defence cooperation program which is set out in program 4. Again, there are some commendable aspects to the defence cooperation program, particularly the handing over of Pacific patrol boats to the Cook Islands, the Federated States of Micronesia and the Marshall Islands. Another one took place in Perth last weekend. The provision of patrol boats to the island states of the Pacific-fishing is their major resource and they really need these boats to guard that resource-is a very considerable and positive step that the Australian defence cooperation program funds.

However, on the other hand, it is also very worrying that at the request of Papua New Guinea four Iroquois helicopters were provided for Papua New Guinea defence force use on Bougainville. This has created quite a lot of ill-feeling amongst the Papua New Guinea community, mostly, of course, from the Bougainvillean point of view. Bougainvilleans do not like to see Australia being part of the militarisation which is used to deny the legitimate course of self-determination on Bougainville.

I think that the Australian Government has to look carefully at how it spends its defence cooperation budget. In fact, there was a 22.4 per cent increase in the defence cooperation program this year-some of this, as I have said, is well spent; other dollars I think are very unwisely spent and can create problems in our region instead of creating goodwill among our neighbours-whereas the overseas aid budget is at the lowest point it has been at for 20 years; it is down to 0.33 per cent of the gross domestic product. This is the area where we could create much more goodwill among our neighbours. It is very worrying that defence is still getting 9.3 per cent of the Budget while other programs are being cut, and it is obvious that with the peace dividend which some other nations are beginning to enjoy--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for consideration of Government papers has finished.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. With the peace dividend actually becoming a reality in some countries, we should also be getting in on the peace dividend and strengthening our foreign affairs budget in relation to our defence budget. Of course, the crisis in the Gulf has cut through a lot of that and obviously a call for a reduction in the defence budget would not be popular at the moment, but it should be because I think we should be negotiating our way out of that difficulty and not preparing for armed combat. A small cut in defence of, say, one per cent would mean a 5 per cent increase in the foreign affairs budget because they are so unequal to start with. We need to place the emphasis on diplomacy and negotiation skills such as those displayed by Michael Costello over the Cambodia issue. We also need an increase in funding for language skills training and this should become a part of the foreign affairs budget, an increasingly important affair. There should be increased funding for the United Nations peacekeeping forces as well. This would mean a cut in the defence budget. I think we must constantly weigh up these two Budget claims on behalf of the Australian community. There are many people in the Australian community who would like to see that imbalance evened up considerably.
