TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I am glad that, after wasting 15 minutes of the Senate's time, we can now address the real issue which is that on 23 August the Minister signed a regulation. Precedent suggests that when a Minister signs a regulation the regulation is deemed to have been made on that date. If that was the case, the regulation could not be tabled in the House because the 15 sitting days would have passed. The regulation was gazetted on 24 August and this is the last day that the regulation can be tabled in this House under the 15-sitting day rule. As I understand it, it has never happened before that the date of gazettal is the date that the regulation has been deemed to have been made. So there is a question about that. It is a substantial question that no doubt will be taken up in the courts of Australia.

The real point of the issue is that there has been an election which I believe has had very little support among the Aboriginal community in Australia. In my home area in Brisbane there are 7,000 Aboriginals and about 1,200 voted in the election. Aboriginals have called into my office over the last two days and overwhelmingly have told me that there was no interest in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander (ATSIC) election and that people did not want it anyhow. The issue goes back to when we, as members of a Senate select committee, including Senator Collins and Senator Coulter, went around Australia and found that the Aboriginal community and the Islander community did not want to have a bar of ATSIC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish; what a load of rubbish.
—It is not rubbish. Every time we took evidence anywhere in Australia people were reluctant to have ATSIC, or certainly they did not understand it and wanted more time to consider it.
—I must have been on another committee.

—Senator Collins was on the committee. If I were Senator Collins I would not make such interjections now. The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission was a fiasco when it began. A number of commissioners from the Aboriginal Development Commission were dismissed and sent home to their communities in disgrace because they would not agree with the then Minister that the ATSIC proposal would be good for their community.
—What has this got to do with the tabling of the rules, Senator?

—I want to go through the scenario and the events in chronological order. Right throughout, ATSIC has been a disaster and it has not been good for the Aboriginal people. That is probably why only a third of the people voted in the recent election.

SPEECH.PARA: Today we are facing a serious precedent where the Parliament of Australia has been bypassed. This institution, which is the most precious institution we have in Australia, has been bypassed. We have just had a regulation tabled after an election that was held on Saturday at a cost of $5m. If that is not a serious matter for this Parliament to be debating, I do not know what is.

On the matter of the Torres Strait Regional Council, the Torres Strait Islanders went to an election to vote for people on a regional council that has not even been constituted. The number of people on it has not been established. The terms of the election that was held have not been established. The people have voted for nothing. I hope that we never again in this Parliament of Australia see this Government, through its incompetence, ineptitude or deceit-I do not know which-trying to bypass the Australian people. The bypassing of parliamentary representation is one of the most serious accusations that can be levelled at a government. It is an insult to not only every senator and member of this place but also every Aboriginal community and person.

We have seen the greatest incompetence in regard to ATSIC by the Minister and his Department. I want to take the Minister up. He is captain of his Department. When the regulation was not tabled, did he take it like a man? Did he say, `I am responsible for my Department'? He blamed some little class 3 clerk-probably an Aboriginal person-in his Department. He would not take the blame himself; he tried to pass the blame onto some clerk in his Department. Instead of saying, `I am responsible; I am the Minister of my Department and I administer that Department', he tried to flick pass the blame to someone else.

Two regulations have not been tabled. The first is subject to a court challenge, and I do not want to mention that. The other regulation was discovered on Friday before the court had a chance to consider it. No doubt the judges of the full Federal Court will take this matter into consideration. This Parliament is facing a serious threat when a government tries to bypass the tabling of regulations and then tables them three days after an election. That is a worry and is a matter for debate in this Parliament.

I do not know where we will go from here and whether we will move a motion to disallow those regulations. I suppose that will be subject to decisions of the various parties in this chamber. We are now faced with an election that has been held and a regulation that has been tabled after the election. I believe that every person in the Torres Strait would have voted for his or her representatives. It is not unlikely that the election will be declared invalid so that those people will have to vote again. That is the responsibility of the Ministers of the Government. It is no wonder that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has said that everyone has to lift his game. If this is the best that the Hawke Ministry can do, no wonder the Prime Minister is getting desperate and telling his Ministers that they will have to go out and do a better job. This incompetence is driving down the polls for the Australian Labor Party to where they stand at present-around 30 per cent of the electorate supporting the Government. If a government has not the ability to table regulations before an election, one wonders why anyone could support it.

In conclusion, we have today seen one of the most serious things that have ever happened to a parliament; that is, the dereliction by a government to honour its commitments and to bring forth in a proper way the regulations that are prescribed under an Act of Parliament. Section 116 (6) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act quite clearly states:

Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 applies in relation to a notice under subsection (1), other than any notice published before the beginning of the first Regional Council election period, as if paragraph (1) (b) of that section were omitted and the following paragraph were substituted . . .

That tells me very clearly that the election for the Torres Strait Regional Council could not take place unless section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act and section 116 (1) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act prescribing the regulations were tabled. This is a very serious situation facing the Australian Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As succinctly as I can, I will point out to the Government where it is wrong in this matter and where it has completely fouled it up. As Senator Boswell has mentioned, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) takes the easy escape of blaming some clerk in his Department. It seems to me that the Minister does not have a terrible lot to do. He apparently administers no department and does not seem to have a lot of legislation to look after. One wonders what the Minister is around for. If this is an example of his competence, then he should do the country a favour by resigning and letting in some Minister who might be able to administer Aboriginal affairs and the affairs of Torres Strait Islanders in a much better way. Section 116 (1) of the Act states:

Where the Minister is satisfied that the Torres Strait Regional Council would best be able to represent Torres Strait Islanders and Aboriginals living in the Torres Strait region if it consisted of, or included, persons elected to represent particular communities in the Torres Strait region under the Queensland Act, the Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette, declare that he or she is so satisfied.
Subsection (2) states:
The notice shall also set out particulars of how the Torres Strait Regional Council is to be constituted . . .

So the notice is the Constitution of this Regional Council. Subsection (2) goes on to say what the rules of election will be and how the Council will operate. Subsection 5 of the Act-that is, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act-provides that the notice which the Minister has to sign saying he is satisfied and also setting up the Constitution is a disallowable instrument under the Acts Interpretation Act.

Section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act talks about instruments declared to be disallowable instruments. Section 48 of the Acts Interpretation Act relates any references to instruments to references to regulations. That is just to tie the notice in with being a regulation under the Act.

Section 48(1) of the Acts Interpretation Act states that, where the Act confers power to make regulations, certain things have to happen. One of the things that have to happen-this is quite separate from making the regulations-is that the made regulation `shall be notified in the Gazette'. Having been made, it:
. . . shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within fifteen sitting days of that House after the making of the regulations.

This regulation was signed-I hold it in front of me-on 23 August 1990. If one counts 15 sitting days from that date, one finds that it is too late today to be tabling that document. The time has expired. If that is the case-and I suggest that it is-I challenge the Government to show me wherever else the signing of a regulation has not been taken as being the making of the regulation. That being the case, section 48 (3) states:
If any regulations are not laid before each House of the Parliament in accordance with the provisions of sub-section (1) . . . they shall be void and of no effect.

I have told the Senate that the regulation was made on 23 August. If one adds 15 sitting days, the time in which regulations have to be tabled, one comes up with yesterday's date. Section 48 (3) states that regulations not tabled within 15 days cease to have effect.

So the notice that the Government is trying to table today has no effect because it ceased to have effect yesterday. If that ceased to have effect yesterday, not only were there no rules for the election which supposedly occurred on Saturday, but also there was nothing for those standing for election to be elected to: there is no such thing as a Torres Strait Regional Council because the regulation to set it up and set up the constitution ceased to have effect yesterday.

Why we went through the ridiculous situation of having a $5m election last Saturday for a body that does not exist is completely beyond me. It shows how completely incapable this Government is of running this country. I do not need to tell you that, Madam Acting Deputy President, nor do I need to tell the Senate. One has only to look at the opinion polls to see that if the people of Australia had gone to an election yesterday this Government would have been tossed out on its you-know-what because it is incompetent and is not capable of addressing the real problems that confront Australia at present.

Last weekend the Northern Territory voters showed their displeasure at the sort of mismanagement that this Federal Government has embarked upon by giving the thumbs-down to the Labor Party in that constituency. Despite many things happening in the Territory, the Territory Government has been there for a long time. The wise men say that when a party is in power for a long time there is an election swing against it. But not only did the swing not go to the Labor Party; the Liberal Party in the Northern Territory achieved a massive swing in its direction. The voters know the complete mess that the Federal Labor Party has made and they certainly did not want to give the State Labor Party the chance of messing up completely the Northern Territory economy. That is what this is all about-the incapacity of this Government to govern this country properly.

Section 104 subsection (3) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: The polling day, or the last of the polling days, for the first round of Regional Council elections shall be no later than 8 months after the commencement of this Act.

This Act, I point out for the benefit of honourable senators who do not recall it, came into effect on 5 March 1990. The eight months was therefore up on 5 November 1990-yesterday. I can only think that the Government was possibly hoping that the election that was going to be declared void was the election that was held for the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly last weekend. Maybe that is the election that it would very much like to have disappear from its memory because it was a slap in the face for the Australia Labor Party (ALP) from the people of the Northern Territory because they do not understand, accept or see the point in the way that the ALP has run this country, the Victorian economy, the Western Australian economy or the Tasmanian economy. The ALP has proved itself completely incapable of running any economies at all. That is what was said in the Northern Territory election and that is symptomatic of the ALP's complete mismanagement of this very simple matter.

As I mentioned before, the Minister does not seem to have a great workload; he does not even have a department to administer and he seems to have very little legislation to put through the Parliament, yet he cannot get this right. The Government has not been able to get interest rates right; it has not been able to get the employment figures right; it has not been able to get the exchange rate or inflation right and it has not been able to administer this Act, which I would have thought was a pretty simple task.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the mismanagement of this legislation, which is symptomatic of the Government's mismanagement generally. I draw the attention of the people of Australia to the fact that yet another $5m of their hard won money-of taxpayers' money- may well be thrown away through the incompetence of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are addressing the failure of the Government and, in particular, the failure of the relevant Minister to ensure that the necessary procedural steps were properly followed in order for these regulations to take effect. I believe this question raises grave doubts as to the validity of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) elections that occurred over the weekend. I think the action-or rather the inaction of the Government because it should have tabled this disallowable instrument within 15 days of its creation-has brought the ATSIC election into disrepute amongst the Aboriginal community. Also, I believe it has created a set of circumstances under which the ATSIC election which occurred over the weekend was technically invalid and void.

SPEECH.PARA: I will firstly address the effect that the Government's inaction and its failure to table the disallowable instrument within the necessary period have had on the perception of the election amongst the eligible voters themselves. I was in Townsville over the weekend and I read a comment in the Townsville Daily Bulletin on Saturday by one of the candidates for the election on, I believe, Palm Island. She had been asked about the uncertainty created by the Government's failure to table the instrument within the necessary period, and she was not impressed. She said that many of the electors had come to her and were of the belief that it was `a little black fella's election' and that no-one was interested. This is what one of the candidates had to say about the manner in which the election was conducted as a result of the Government failing to table the instrument within the necessary period. How can we have any confidence that ATSIC truly represents the Aboriginal people when there was such a cloud over the election at the time at which it occurred and when there was such uncertainty as to whether the election had been properly called? I believe that comment by one of the candidates standing for election shows that the Government, as a result of its inaction, has brought the election and ATSIC into disrepute.

I believe there are certain technical issues that are also very important when we consider this particular disallowable instrument. I want to analyse in detail whether the instrument was in fact tabled within the necessary timeframe. This goes to the creation of the instrument. In making these and other comments I shall be making liberal reference to the foremost text book on this subject, which is entitled Delegated Legislation, by Mr D.C. Pearce, who was formerly the acting legal counsel to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. Mr Pearce makes it very clear in paragraphs 18, 19 and 20 of his text that an instrument is created on the day on which it is signed and that an instrument is not created on the day on which it is gazetted. The argument that the Government, I assume, wishes to make in favour of the fact that this instrument was properly tabled today is that the instrument was not created until the date of notification under section 116 of the Act-but that is the date on which it comes into effect.

If I am correct, the Act prescribes that if the Minister is satisfied that the people of the Torres Strait region can be properly represented he shall make his views known in a notice published in the Gazette. That is clearly part of the notification process and it is not, in itself, the Act which actually causes the regulation to take effect. In other words, the Minister failed to understand the process by which he gave effect to and created the disallowable instrument. I believe it is very clear in there and it is also a very clearly understood practice on both sides of the chamber that a disallowable instrument is created on the day on which it is signed; it takes effect from the day on which it is notified. There are four types of disallowable instruments but, on my understanding, this is a disallowable instrument which has effect from the date of notification until such time as the Senate disallows the instrument or the instrument is deemed to have been disallowed.

Then we come to the question of whether it was, indeed, tabled within the necessary period of time. The answer is: very clearly, it was not. It is a requirement under the Acts Interpretation Act for the disallowable instrument to be tabled within 15 sitting days of creation-not of notification but of creation. As we have already seen, this instrument was created through the signature of the Minister on 23 August, not 24 August. Therefore, the Government is one sitting day late in tabling this regulation in the Senate. For that reason, this piece of delegated legislation is void and is of no effect.
Mr Pearce very ably points out that it is not possible to backdate the effect of a piece of delegated legislation. In paragraph 70 he says:
In all jurisdictions, except Victoria and New Zealand, regulations cannot be back-dated in a manner disadvantageous to members of the public.
Very clearly, if they cannot be backdated they cannot be tabled after the date on which they are supposed to take effect.

This is for a very simple reason. We, in the Senate, must have the opportunity to vote to disallow the regulations or otherwise. Whether we were going to disallow it or not is another matter. But the Senate, through the Government's failure to table the disallowable instrument within the necessary period of time, deprived members of this chamber of their rights to disallow the instrument and to have the instrument properly scrutinised.

Of course, this is very important. The Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has, I understand, recommended in a previous report that there be changes so that it is not possible for the Government perpetually to create delegated legislation by tabling regulations the day after the day on which they were disallowed. Quite clearly, there is a possibility--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an entirely separate issue. It is totally unrelated.

—It is not a different issue, it is not an unrelated issue, as I will ably demonstrate to Senator Collins in just a minute. This matter might be an embarrassment to Senator Collins but I can only assure him that the embarrassment will continue a little longer if he continues to interject in such a spurious manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason why the Standing Committee recommended that there be changes so that legislation could not be tabled after it had been disallowed was that the effect would be to create rolling delegated legislation which would have no end.

This brings me to the very pertinent point that I believe that not only should this legislation have been tabled prior to the ATSIC elections taking place but also the period during which the delegated legislation could have been disallowed should have elapsed prior to the date on which the ATSIC elections took place. While the possibility exists that the delegated legislation could have been disallowed, I believe there is a very good case that that election was not validly held because there was the possibility that the election could be invalidated at a subsequent date.

The best argument that the Government could come up with against this proposition would be that the election was validly held until the date on which the disallowable instrument was, in fact, disallowed by the Senate. Suppose we had the situation where the election took place-and I am being hypothetical here-five days before the time period during which disallowance could occur. The very best argument the Government could put forward would be that the election, and the result of the election, was valid for five sitting days.

Not only has the Government failed to table the instrument within the necessary period of time but also it failed to allow a sufficient period of time prior to the election to enable those of us in this chamber to have the opportunity of disallowing the delegated legislation so that, if it was not disallowed, those who bothered to turn out at the weekend would have known with total and absolute certainty that their vote was a valid one.

What confidence does the Government instil in electors when it creates an election which, I believe, was invalid and when it asks people to vote with the possibility not only that the election was invalid but also that the result could be invalidated at a later date? It does absolutely no good for the confidence of electors and it does absolutely no good for their confidence in ATSIC itself.

I believe that if the Government were truly concerned about representation for Aboriginal persons, it would have carried on in a manner wholly different from the manner in which it has acted in respect of this matter. That is what is of concern to me. I do not intend to take issue on whether ATSIC is right or wrong. What I am concerned about is the contempt in which this Government has held not only this Senate but also all of the people who made the effort to vote and, in fact, ATSIC which was itself a child of this Government's policy.

There is one final matter that is of very great concern to me. Because the instrument was not tabled until today, and was not tabled before the date of the election, those members of this chamber who serve on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-a committee which Senator Collins once chaired, and his contribution to it is much valued-did not have the opportunity to carry out their role. In case Senator Collins has forgotten, the role of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is to scrutinise delegated legislation to ascertain, firstly, that it is in accordance with the statutes; secondly, that it does not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties; thirdly, that it does not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative and not judicial decisions; and, fourthly, that it is concerned with administrative detail and does not amount to substantive legislation which could be a matter of parliamentary enactment.

In addition, there is a well recognised obligation upon the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances to ensure that the disallowable instruments that are tabled in this place are not of a nature which is unacceptable in administrative law. Of course, the Committee looks at the consequences of the disallowable instruments that have been tabled.

I have grave concerns and reservations as a member of that Committee-not as a senator with a parliamentary hat on, or as a senator with an axe to grind-when the Government does not table a delegated instrument that affects people's rights and their supposed representation. I believe that the Government's failure, firstly, to table the instrument within the necessary time period and, secondly, to allow sufficient time for the delegated instrument perhaps to be disallowed prior to the election has, in fact, breached the rule of law. One of the principles of the rule of law is that laws must be certain and that rights must be certain. Unfortunately, what we have seen through the Government's shameful conduct is a flouting of legal certainty and a flouting of the certainty of the rights of electors under ATSIC.

These are the four reasons-the effect it has had upon the confidence of electors; the failure for the instrument to be properly tabled within the necessary period of time after its creation; the enormous possibilities created for the delegated legislation to be disallowed after the election; and, finally, the contempt that the Government has shown for the Senate and for the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances-which compel me to have grave concerns about the manner in which the Government is carrying on and the manner in which the Minister has handled his portfolio.

I know for a fact that there will be many people outside this chamber and outside Canberra-be they electors in ATSIC or just concerned citizens-who want to know how the Government could have bungled this so incredibly. They want to know how the Government could have failed even to bother to table the disallowable instrument within the necessary time, or before the election, or to have the election within a sufficient period of time for the possible disallowance of the delegated legislation prior to the election taking place. All of these are matters of grave concern, and matters which the Government has failed to answer.

They are a comprehensive report from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) provided to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) at his request on 5 November, after this came to his attention, and written advice he received from ATSIC on 19 September which indicates clearly that all the charges made against the Government and the Minister fall in a heap.

SPEECH.PARA: When I talked about declamatory tripe, I was referring to the tedious nonsense about ministerial responsibility that I have heard so many times in the 14 years I have been a member of parliament. The so-called Westminster system of responsible government has never existed in this country, neither should it have, nor will it in the future. The reasonable and proper interpretation of ministerial responsibility I have always clung to, and will continue to cling to, is that where a Minister does or does not do something that he should or should not have done, or should have reasonably known-in other words, a test of competence-that it should have been done or should not have been done, he is responsible for it. But this so-called nonsensical Westminster tradition of ministerial responsibility that we hear such pontificating tripe about, always from the members of the Opposition, and I have delivered it enough against Ministers in my time as Leader of the Opposition to know what I am talking about, is just that-tripe.

The Westminster system-and it has happened in Great Britain on many occasions-has resulted in highly competent Ministers being expected to conclude successful contributions to public life because of a mistake that they in fact were not responsible for in every sense of the word; in other words, one they were not aware of, nor could they have reasonably been aware of it. That is arrant nonsense. I have no doubt that the people who have delivered this tripe this afternoon-

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a pretty important thing though, isn't it?

SPEECH.PARA: This is an issue that I have raised again and again in the Senate in the time that I have been here. PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Customs (Rainforest Timber) Amendment Bill 1990 is to selectively ban the importation of tropical rainforest timbers into Australia. The Bill is a response to the alarming rate of destruction of the world's tropical rainforests. It is one element of a comprehensive strategy by which Australia could and should make a positive contribution to arresting this destruction.

The need for a comprehensive strategy can not be overemphasised; import restrictions alone are not enough. Aid, technical assistance and campaigning for international action to protect rainforests and develop sustainable economic alternatives to the logging of primary forests are essential adjuncts to a ban.

Proposals to ban tropical timber imports have been before the Government for some time. Last year, the then Environment Minister, Senator Graham Richardson, responded by commissioning Coopers and Lybrand Consultants, in conjunction with Forestry Technical Services Pty Ltd, to evaluate a range of policy options for the Australian Government.

The Coopers and Lybrand main report, dated April 1990, recently surfaced in the public domain. It recommends against any form of import restriction, favouring instead some modest aid measures and the encouragement of substitutes for tropical timbers, in order to reduce demand in Australia `in [the] medium to long term'.

It is my hope that this Bill will provoke Cabinet to reject the Coopers and Lybrand report, and to take concerted action which reflects the seriousness of the problem. Cabinet must understand that the report is woefully inadequate, and fails to seriously address Australia's global environmental responsibilities. One of the central weaknesses of Coopers and Lybrand's analysis is that it fails to face up to the scale of the ecological, social and economic damage now being wreaked in the world's tropical rainforests.

According to the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA), some 142,200 square kilometres of rainforest was destroyed in 1989-a 90 per cent increase in the deforestation rate in only 10 years. The United States-based World Resources Institute (WRI) puts the annual loss at nearly 200,000 square kilometres, resulting in the average loss, conservatively estimated, of one hundred species per day, a rate unprecedented in natural history. In a communication of 2 August last year, the European Commission (EC) estimated that `at present rates of forest loss, all but a few of the remotest forest regions, mostly in the Amazon and Congo basins, could have disappeared by the early 21st Century (2010-2025)'.

In other words, global deforestation could be largely complete in twenty years time. Half-hearted measures to take effect in the `medium to long term', as proposed by Coopers and Lybrand, would simply be too little, too late. A report to the International Tropical Timber Organisation (ITTO) has concluded that:
The extent of tropical moist forest which is being deliberately managed at an operational scale for the sustainable production of timber is, on a world scale, negligible.

The Sunday Herald recently reported that a leaked Indonesian Government report found that only 22 of the country's 527 logging operations follow government guidelines. Those guidelines are themselves inadequate.

The indigenous people of the Malaysian state of Sarawak, three of whom recently visited Australia, are engaged in a desperate struggle to arrest the destruction of the forests which are essential to their livelihood-forests which will disappear in eleven years if present logging practices continue, according to the International Tropical Timber Organisation.
The social and economic impact of this plunder, which is almost completely ignored by Coopers and Lybrand, is horrendous. As WRI notes:

Escalating human populations, deforestation, disruptions of watersheds, soil loss, and land degradation are all linked in a vicious cycle that perpetuates and deepens poverty, and often creates ecological refugees.
The EC states that:

The most important causes of tropical forest destruction are extreme poverty and over-population. Their impact is accentuated by patterns of land control and ownership which multiply the phenomenon of landlessness and hence acute land hunger. Two more immediate pressures producing this crisis link developing countries to developed via demand for hardwood timber, or cheap beef.

But the industrialised world's gain of cheap timber and beef is also its loss, through the political and economic impact of Third World poverty, the contribution of deforestation to the build-up of greenhouse gases, and the loss of genetic material available for future use in medicine, agriculture and other vital fields. A 1989 study published in the journal Nature, estimates that the economic value of `minor' forest products from Peruvian rainforests-including fruits, resins, and medicines actually being marketed-exceeded the economic value of using the forest for timber by almost 10 to one.

In short, the destruction of tropical rainforests is a prime example of unsustainable practices which, as ACFOA observes, are the result of `the inequitable distribution of resources, both between and within countries'. For example, the tribes of Sarawak are pitted against Western importers and corrupt local politicians, almost every one of whom-along with friends and relatives-owns extensive logging licences.

As Australian rainforest activist Patrick Anderson notes, it is essential to view the crisis of rainforest destruction in its historical, cultural and ecological context. He quotes leading rainforest ecologist Marius Jacobs:

If we review present-day tropical rainforest exploitation we see a strong fixation on timber. This is a recent and curious development. Until well into the 19th century, the prevalent forest use was not for the extraction of timber, but of minor forest products . . . Conscious efforts by tropical foresters to extract timber and to change the forest composition are scarcely older than a century, while mechanical logging, which has so markedly speeded up this process, is even more recent.

These recent developments seem anomalous because the rainforests are so evidently unsuited to timber extraction ... It is hard to think of a manner of utilization more wasteful for the present and more destructive for the future. A finely tuned, slow-motion ecosystem, a `factory capable of yielding hundreds of exquisite products, some of which are highly valued in international trade, is ripped open by bulldozers that pull down the very pillars supporting its roof, while quantities of scarce minerals that the ecosystem might convert into fruits, latex, medicine, spices, stimulants and other precious articles, are lost in the process. To obtain a few useful species, all others are left to their fate. It seems almost too clumsy an approach to spend any more words on . . .

If the present type of utilization is continued, in at most half a century's time the remaining `pillars', too, will have been extracted, the roof of our living factory will have caved in and the factory itself demolished altogether over certain areas. How is it possible that people have invoked `economic need' to justify such stupidity?
In the face of this crisis, the Australian Democrats support the comprehensive strategy adopted by ACFOA, which calls for:
* international debt relief for the poorest countries, including through `debt-for-nature' swaps;
* large increases in overseas aid, redirected towards the alleviation of poverty, and with a particular emphasis on developing alternative, sustainable economic strategies in tropical countries;
* world trade arrangements which do not discriminate against developing countries;
* wide-ranging technical assistance to developing countries in areas of forest management, and environmental planning and impact assessment;

* a ban on the importation of tropical timbers cut from primary rainforests, measures to ensure that timber plantations established by Australian firms overseas have acceptable social and environmental impacts; and
* international lobbying to widen the adoption of these measures.

The import ban is of course the focus of this Bill, but the other measures are equally important. They must be implemented together if they are to be just and effective. For example, it is essential that Australian aid and capital does not contribute to deforestation. Patrick Anderson has evidence that Bunnings Brothers, a Western Australian firm, has had a devastating impact on the forests in the West Sepik region of Papua New Guinea. Another Western Australian firm, Asmus McLean, is apparently involved in a 600,000 hectare forest concession in West Irian, where the rights of local people have been ignored in the push to establish a huge logging operation. And BHP Trading is reported to trade in timber from Sarawak, to the detriment of the local indigenous peoples.

According to Anderson, the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB), has funded `Forest Enrichment' programs in Fiji which have destroyed native forests and polluted waterways with powerful herbicides. Other aid has funded massive sawmills, to the detriment of local communities. And AIDAB is planning a $2.3m forest resource inventory for the Solomon Islands which will map the areas of remaining forests for the benefit of largely multinational logging companies. Concerted action to end such malpractices is as important as the import ban.

The ban is implemented as an amendment to section 50 of the Customs Act 1901, which provides for the selective or absolute banning of specified imports by regulation. A new section 50A would empower the Minister to issue licences to import logs, sawn timber, veneers and plywoods made from rainforest timbers only if he or she is satisfied that the timber is to be cut from plantations, or that:
* the forest from which the timber is to be cut is secondary or regrowth forest;
* substantial areas of the forest from which the timber is to be cut is adequately protected in secure parks and reserves;
* the operation is carried out at the instigation of, or with approval of the owners and inhabitants of the land concerned; and
* the logging operations do not threaten the area's integrity as a natural rain forest or its ability to support any traditional inhabitants thereof.

Each licence would specify the maximum quantity of timber to be imported, the area from which it is to be cut and an expiry date. The Comptroller-General of Customs would be empowered to require importers to produce records of the origin of timber or timber products imported under licence. Where licence conditions had been violated, licences could be cancelled and fines of up to $10,000 imposed. The granting, refusing or revoking of a licence would be subject to review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

The Bill includes a transitional provision under which imports resulting from sales or contracts struck from today would be blocked after proclamation. This is to prevent attempts to avoid the intent of the Bill by concluding long term contracts.

The import restrictions have been limited to logs, sawn timber, veneers and plywoods because they comprise a majority of Australian imports-about 70 per cent by volume-and because imports of those products are already categorised by timber species by the Australian Customs Service for the purposes of levying tariffs. This makes administration of the ban a relatively straightforward extension of existing Customs activities. Other wood products, such as mouldings and furniture, are not categorised by timber species, thus complicating the administration of a ban. Furthermore, further processing makes it more difficult to identify the area from which the timber is cut.

While efforts should be made to increase the range of products covered by the ban, it may be just as cost-effective to use lobbying and aid measures to assist producer countries to change their practices, and to convince other importing countries to follow Australia's lead. There can be no more important target for such lobbying than Japan. It is obscene that Japanese car parts enter Australia in casing made from tropical timbers.

The conditions in the Bill relating to the rights of indigenous peoples are particularly important, as they are affected more adversely by tropical deforestation than most. A 1987 report commissioned by the Sarawak State Government on the plight of the Penan forest dwellers concluded that logging had reduced the Penan's food resources and raw materials for handicrafts, had polluted their rivers and streams, and had disrupted their normal activities-yet the Penan had no voice in policy formulation. That report, incidentally, has been suppressed and came to me via a leak in Denmark.

The Bill places the onus on intending importers to demonstrate that they should be given licences. Where doubt exists because insufficient information is available, then licences should not be issued. It is essential that bilateral and multilateral processes be established to identify environmentally responsible timber producing operations.

There have been a number of arguments advanced against an import ban, most of which are discussed in the Coopers and Lybrand report. One argument is that the major cause of tropical deforestation is not logging, but shifting agriculture. Therefore, a ban on timber imports will have little effect.

The EC cites estimates that 4 per cent of rainforest removals are for timber exports. But it warns that the large equipment used for export timber extraction causes disproportionate damage, with the removal of three to five trees from a hectare in Borneo resulting in the destruction of up to 55 per cent of the forest. Furthermore, export logging opens up remote areas for unsustainable slash and burn agriculture and displaces indigenous people who are then forced to practice such agriculture. The various forms of destruction are interrelated, which demonstrates the need for the comprehensive approach I am proposing.

In any case, Australia's major source of tropical timber imports is Malaysia, where the contribution of slash and burn agriculture to deforestation is much lower than in, for example, South America and where the contribution of export logging is correspondingly higher. As Dr Kenneth Baldwin of the Australian National University has written, most of the shifting agriculture in Sarawak occurs in previously logged secondary forest and is estimated to be responsible for the loss of only 4,000 hectares of primary rainforest, compared to the 200,000 hectares devoured by logging.

Another objection is that a logging ban, particularly if widely adopted, would cause economic hardship in tropical countries. It must be re-emphasised that the unsustainability of current practices is certain to cause such hardship in the medium term, and that restructuring will avoid that the provision of significant levels of aid should help prevent much short term damage. The Democrats have shown, in our alternative Budget proposals for 1990-91, that Australia could afford to provide $60m of aid for that purpose. This compares to the $280m which we now spend on tropical timber imports.

Conversely, it has also been claimed that an Australian ban would have very little impact and would be a meaningless symbolic gesture. This is wrong on several counts. Firstly, a comparatively modest aid investment in Pacific island countries, notably Papua New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, coupled with a ban, would have a large impact in these countries. Secondly, the impact on Malaysia would be significant enough to be noticed, even though Japan is the major destination of Malaysian tropical timbers. Thirdly, there is evidence of sufficient international concern for an Australian ban to have a significant demonstration effect. Austria has already moved to ban such imports. Sweden is reported to have followed suit, although detailed information has yet to come to hand. As international efforts to reduce the rate of species loss and greenhouse gas emissions gather momentum, tropical deforestation will increasingly be a focus of attention.
If Australia abides by its international responsibilities and implements a selective ban, it is in a strong position to lobby other Western nations to follow suit.

There have been claims that Australia's international legal obligations to free trade, enshrined in the faltering General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) would be inconsistent with a ban. However, GATT allows for general exceptions to free trade principles where `necessary to protect human, animal or plant life or health' or `relating to the conservation of exhaustible natural resources if such measures are made effective in conjunction with restrictions on domestic production or consumption'. A ban would help achieve these goals.

Australia has a good record of protecting its remaining rainforests, consistent with the terms of the import restrictions specified in this Bill and hence with the GATT exceptions. But a moral, if not legal, question mark hangs over Government policy on our non-tropical native forests, which continue to be logged unsustainably. It is worth pointing out that the development of a plantation based forestry industry in Australia would be accelerated by a domestic ban on logging of old-growth forests, coupled with tropical timber import restrictions.

Coopers and Lybrand, in their report, devote considerable attention and anxiety to the problem of finding substitutes for imported tropical timbers in the domestic economy. The pessimism they express completely ignores the union-led advances that have already been made in this area. It is instructive to read a hysterical headline from the Australian of 17 October 1989: `Union ban on imported wood threatens building industry'. This followed a ban by the Victorian branch of the Building Workers' Industrial Union on the use of imported rainforest timbers on building sites, particularly plywood for concrete formwork. In the twelve months since then, substitutes have been found, and, quite clearly, the building industry in Victoria has not collapsed as a result. This development is ignored by Coopers and Lybrand.

The Wilderness Society's Keith Tarlo has noted that imported rainforest timbers comprise a mere 6 per cent of our total timber usage. Woodworker and furniture maker Michael Gill told ABC Radio's AM program on 10 October that:

The whole of the Australian building industry could stop using imported rainforest timber tomorrow without any ill effects being felt whatsoever. It will cost a little bit more to use alternatives, and that's about all we'll feel. It could be done tomorrow.

Until now, the Australian Government has placed its faith in international institutions such as the ITTO, and the Tropical Forestry Action Plan prepared by the WRI, the World Bank, the United Nations Development Programme and the UN Food and Agriculture Organisation. However, this is not enough. Urgent action is needed, and international consensus has yet to produce a strategy which is equal to the task at hand. Catalysts are required, and Australia can and should take the lead.

A precise analogy can be found in the case of Antarctica. International efforts have yielded a convention which would allow mining in the world's last remaining continental wilderness. The Federal Government, against what seemed to be overwhelming odds, began a campaign for the Antarctic to comprehensively protect it. Important gains have been made as a result of the courageous lead that has been taken. The same commitment is required to save the world's rainforests, for the sake of humanity.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Bill 1990 represents a further stage in the Government's strategy to deal effectively with the illicit trade in drugs.

As all Honourable Senators are aware, this illicit trade has no regard to national boundaries; it is by its nature international. Effective, co-ordinated international action is, therefore, an essential element in combating this evil.

It is for this reason that the Government has over the past seven years placed the highest priority on providing and securing international co-operation in the fight against the illicit trade in drugs and organised crime which is dependent on it.

Over the past seven years the Government has modernised Australia's extradition laws and negotiated and secured 28 modern extradition treaties. In this period, Australia has led the rest of the world in the development of modern arrangements for mutual assistance in criminal matters, thereby securing treaty backed obligations to assist in criminal investigations, prosecutions, the pursuit of the international criminal money trail and the confiscation of criminally obtained assets.

Further, in the international arena Australian model extradition and mutual assistance treaties form the basis of model bilateral treaties developed by the United Nations Crime Prevention Committee for adoption by the 8th UN Crime Congress being held in Havana.

On the domestic legal front the Government's Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988 and the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 comprise one of the most comprehensive legislative packages for following the money trail in the world.

Australia's achievements have been recognised in the international community, most recently by our inclusion in the Financial Action Task Force established by the Group of Seven major economic nations to advise on the prevention of money laundering. As the International Enforcement Law Reporter stated in its September 1989 edition``Australia's participation-in the taskforce-is significant because it has taken a leadership role in international criminal co-operation''.
BACKGROUND TO THE BILL

It was because of our commitment to international law enforcement co-operation that Australia played a prominent role in the development of a new United Nations convention whose purpose is to ensure that the international community co-operates in the adoption of a wide range of measures aimed at stemming the illicit drug trade.

Australia's ratification of this convention will achieve one of the aims of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse, which has the support of all governments in Australia. The States have been aware of the proposed Convention and of the Commonwealth's wish to become a party to it from the beginning of the drafting process in 1985, and their views were sought at each stage of the negotiation process.

This legislation represents the first step in the process of Australia's ratification of that Convention-the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, which was signed by Australia in Vienna in February 1989. It is the culmination of almost four years' work by member countries of the Commission on Narcotic Drugs.

I wish to emphasise, however, that this Convention represents only one strand in the international drug strategy, which, as the international community recognises, requires a multidisciplinary approach. Thus, the Declaration of the International Conference on Drug Abuse and Illicit Trafficking in Vienna in June 1987 designated four areas for future action:
- prevention and reduction of demand;
- control of supply (including programs for rural development involving crop eradication and substitution);
- suppression of illicit trafficking; and
- treatment and rehabilitation.

Although the Convention is, of course, directed at the illicit drug trade, it also touches upon these other important aspects of the problem of drug abuse. This, too, is consistent with the approach adopted in the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse. This Campaign also takes a multidisciplinary approach with a strong emphasis on education and prevention directed at vulnerable groups, and treatment and rehabilitation of regular users.

There is a degree of misunderstanding about the effect which ratification of the Convention will have on policy in the drugs area. Contrary to some views which have been expressed, this Convention does not preclude the re-examination of policy in relation to personal use of prohibited drugs. It is open to Governments, within the context of this convention, to provide that possession which would otherwise be an offence will not be subject to criminal penalties where the possession is clearly for personal use only.

Thus, the Convention specifically states that Parties may, as an alternative to conviction or punishment in such cases, provide measures for the treatment, education, aftercare, rehabilitation or social reintegration of the offender.

Additionally, section 17A of the Crimes Act 1914, which provides that imprisonment should be imposed as a last resort, will apply to offences created under this Bill. As a result, when the courts are considering sentences to be imposed on persons convicted of offences in relation to cultivation or production for personal use, they will be required to give preference to alternative forms of sentences which could lawfully be imposed. Such alternatives could include programs of rehabilitation, treatment and education and the court would need to be satisfied that none of these options is appropriate before they impose a sentence of imprisonment. Thus, sentencing options already available in the case of Commonwealth offenders enable us to take full advantage of the alternatives to sentencing proposed in Article 3 of the Convention.

Many of the obligations created under the Convention which fall within areas of Commonwealth legislative responsibility are already covered by Commonwealth legislation such as the Customs Act 1901, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, the Extradition Act 1988, and the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987.

Other obligations fall within areas of State responsibility, and consultations are under way with the States on action to be taken by them to ensure their laws are in accord with the terms of the Convention. The Commonwealth has been very much aware of the importance of not encroaching on areas of State jurisdiction in this field and fully supports the continuation of the co-operative approach to drug law enforcement with the State and Territory Governments and their law enforcement agencies.
OUTLINE OF PROPOSED LEGISLATION

The principal area requiring legislation in the Commonwealth sphere relates to the need to create extra-territorial jurisdiction under Article 4 of the Convention. The purpose of the jurisdictional changes envisaged by Article 4 is to ensure that drug traffickers cannot escape justice by moving from one jurisdiction to another e.g. to a jurisdiction which for a valid reason is not prepared to surrender the person to the country whose laws were infringed.
I will now outline the ways in which this Bill will extend Australia's extra-territorial jurisdiction.

The first extension relates to Australian nationals who have engaged in conduct, outside the reach of existing jurisdiction, which would constitute an Article 3 offence if it had occurred in Australia and where extradition of such persons from Australia is not sought or, if sought, is not granted for reasons outside the scope of section 45 of the Extradition Act 1988.

The Bill also establishes a second area of jurisdiction where a person who is not an Australian national has engaged in drug-related conduct outside Australia which would constitute an offence against the law of the country where it occurred and also against the law in force in an Australian State or Territory; the person is subsequently present in Australia, and Australia declines to extradite that person.

Thirdly, the Bill creates jurisdiction over persons who, outside Australia, engage in conduct with the view to the commission of a drug-related offence in Australia-for example, knowingly growing a crop for subsequent marketing in Australia.
The Bill also creates offences arising out of drug-related conduct on Australian aircraft and provides for the exercise of Commonwealth jurisdiction on Australian ships in certain circumstances.

Another provision creates a federal offence which has the effect of applying, outside Australia, State and Territory offences of conspiring or attempting, aiding, abetting, counselling or procuring the carrying out of drug-related conduct which is an offence against the law of a State or Territory.
FINANCIAL IMPACT
I do not anticipate that the proposals put forward in this Bill will have a significant impact on Government expenditure in the foreseeable future.
CONCLUSION

This Bill is the first step in the process of ratification of this most important United Nations Convention. Further action will be required by the States before ratification can take place. The Convention seeks to achieve concerted international action against those who, for their own gain and at great cost to the community, engage in illicit trafficking in drugs. The co-operative multidisciplinary approach of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse recognises the need to address the problems of addiction with compassion and to offer treatment and rehabilitation to those suffering under all forms of drug addiction. In no way can it be argued that ratification will prevent a reasoned and complete debate on the merits of the present national approach to drug abuse. The Government welcomes such a debate but remains committed, along with our State and Territory counterparts, to the type of tough and thorough measures prescribed by the Convention in respect of illicit drug trafficking.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill I am introducing today is to set the legislative framework in place for Australia to ratify the Convention on the Settlement of Investment Disputes between States and Nationals of Other States.
BACKGROUND

The Convention provides a mechanism for settlement, by means of conciliation and arbitration, of investment disputes between a State Party to the Convention (or any constituent subdivision or agency of that State) and investors from other States Party. To this end the Convention established the International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes, better known as ICSID. Hence the Convention is often referred to as the ICSID Convention.

The Convention, which is the outcome of the work of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (`the World Bank'), was opened for signature on 18 March 1966 and entered into force on 14 October 1966. There are currently 91 parties to the Convention including nearly all Australia's major trading partners. Australia signed the Convention on 24 March 1975.

The ratification of the Convention by Australia will be a further important step in advancing the Government's objective of developing Australia's role in international commercial dispute resolution. Honourable Senators will recall that in 1989 this Government introduced legislation to implement the Model Law on Commercial Arbitration which had been developed by the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law (UNCITRAL). The adoption of the Model Law was a major step towards enhancing Australia's position as a centre for international commercial arbitration. Ratification of the ICSID Convention will further enhance this position.

Australia already has 2 centres for international arbitration in Sydney and Melbourne which have been operating for some time, and ratification of the ICSID Convention will enable Australia to build on the expertise developed in those 2 centres.

There are also significant advantages which flow from ratifying the Convention from which Australian investors could benefit. In particular, the facilities provided under the Convention for conciliation and arbitration are an appropriate means for settlement of claims by investors arising out of expropriation of private assets in overseas countries. Ratification may also help to promote foreign investment in Australia.
CONTENT OF THE BILL

I refer now to some of the more salient features of the Bill. The Bill will implement the ICSID Convention by amending the International Arbitration Act 1974 and the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963. The International Arbitration Act currently gives effect to the 1958 Convention on the Recognition and Enforcement of Foreign Arbitral Awards (the so-called `New York Convention') which establishes rules governing the recognition and enforcement in Australia of international arbitral awards and agreements. The Act also implements the UNCITRAL Model Law. The Bill will amend that Act by inserting a new Part and a new Schedule to that Act. Thus all Commonwealth legislation relating to international arbitration will be contained in the one Act. The Bill will amend the International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act to enable effect to be given to certain privileges and immunities provisions of the Convention by extending the regulation-making power under that Act.
The Bill gives the force of law to the key provisions of the Convention. It also provides that arbitral awards will be binding and enforceable in the Supreme Courts of the States and Territories.
THE ICSID CONVENTION

I will now turn to the principal features of the Convention. The Convention established the Centre which incorporates an Administrative Council, a Secretariat, a Panel of Arbitrators and a Panel of Conciliators. The Administrative Council comprises a representative from each Contracting State. The President of the World Bank is ex officio Chairman of the Council. The Panels of Conciliators and of Arbitrators are made up of persons designated by the Contracting States and by the Chairman of the Council.

The jurisdiction of the Centre under the Convention extends to any legal dispute, arising directly out of an investment, between a Contracting State and a national of another Contracting State. No proceedings can be initiated under the Convention unless both the State and the investor have specifically agreed to accept the Centre's jurisdiction. However, once the parties have given their consent, it cannot be withdrawn unilaterally. This will enable investment disputes between a State and a foreign investor to be dealt with under the ICSID Convention if the parties agree.

There is provision to designate constituent subdivisions of a State Party and, in the case of Australia, it is proposed to designate those Australian States that agree to such designation. The effect of designation is that a State Government involved in an investment dispute with a foreign national will be able, if the parties so agree, to avail itself of the facilities offered by the Convention. All States except Western Australia have indicated their agreement to be designated.

The dispute is to be settled in accordance with the rules of law chosen by the parties or, if they fail to agree, the law of the Contracting State party to the dispute and any applicable rules of international law.
Every Contracting State is required to recognise arbitral awards as binding and to enforce such awards as if they were final decisions of a domestic court.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development provides the Centre with accommodation and basic services free of charge in Washington DC. Under the Convention, parties making use of the ICSID's facilities are required to bear the expenses incurred by the Centre in connection with conciliation and arbitration proceedings. Only in the event that the expenditure of the Centre cannot be met out of charges for the use of its facilities, or out of other receipts, will Contracting States be required to contribute towards any excess. It is accordingly anticipated that any impact on Commonwealth expenditure will be minimal.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
