DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1990[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1990-91APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, with the concurrence of the Senate, I suggest that the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91 be debated cognately with the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1990-91.
—There being no objection, that course will be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills that we are now debating cognately contain the essence of the Government's Budget for 1990-91. Appropriation Bill (No. 1) has as its purpose to appropriate amounts required for expenditure in 1990-91 from the Consolidated Revenue Fund for the ordinary annual services of the Government. The amounts sought in this Bill total $24.1 billion. Of that total, the Bill seeks authority for the issue of $13.45 billion, the balance of $10.7 billion having already been authorised by the Supply Act (No. 1) 1990-91, which Act will be subsumed when this Appropriation Bill is enacted.

SPEECH.PARA: Appropriation Bill (No. 2) seeks appropriations from Consolidated Revenue totalling $6.8 billion, of which $2.9 billion was authorised by the Supply Act (No. 2). The balance of $3.9 billion will be authorised by this Bill. Appropriation Bill (No. 2) provides primarily for proposed expenditure on the construction of public works and for capital items.

The third Bill in the trio is the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill. The amount sought is $117.8m, which is for the operating expenses and capital expenditures of the parliamentary departments for the year ending 30 June 1991. Of this amount of $117.8m, $47.6m was authorised by the Supply (Parliamentary Departments) Act and the balance of $70.2m is being sought in this Bill.

It is quite clear that the levels of appropriation being sought in these Bills are inconsistent with the economic needs of this nation, with the need for fiscal restraint. Quite clearly, the Government has lost control of one major arm of economic policy, namely fiscal policy. It is a matter of considerable concern that the expenditure control by the States-they are never noted for great expenditure control-has been greater this year than that by the Commonwealth. A 6.1 per cent increase is budgeted for the States of Australia this financial year compared to a staggering 11.9 per cent increase for Commonwealth own purpose spending, net of public debt interest.

The Government's latest monthly transaction statement shows that we are more than on track with the reckless expenditure course set by the Government at Budget time. The Government has obviously lost all serious intent in meaningful control of its spending. This year, at a time when we should be exercising the greatest possible expenditure restraint, the Government has gone back to the profligate ways of the first two or three years of the Hawke Government when the spending and fiscal policies set in train most of the problems that have occurred in our economy in the ensuing period.

So profligate has the Government been this year that it could find only a paltry $350m reduction in expenditure against the Forward Estimates-less than one half of one per cent. No government serious in its intent to govern responsibly would suggest that a reduction less than onehalf of one per cent in its Forward Estimates of expenditure represents a meaningful reduction in expenditure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to tell us where you would cut?

—Yes, I would be very happy to do that. Had the Minister been following this debate at all-which it is quite clear from his performance in the Parliament and elsewhere he has not-he would know that 12 months ago the Opposition released an Economic Action Plan which detailed most carefully a $3 billion expenditure reduction which has never been challenged by the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1990 Budget was introduced only 10 weeks ago. Already that Budget is outdated; already it is obsolete. It is obsolete because the whole framework surrounding the Budget has been blown apart. Even the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) said on television on Sunday that the key parameters guiding the Budget estimates are now incorrect. He has admitted that both inflation and unemployment will be higher than predicted at Budget time and that the downturn may be more drawn out than the Government was banking on with consequent impacts on outlays and revenues.

Today the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, in response to a question of mine, almost admitted that this economy was in recession. He said that it is not in a technical recession, but he did admit that we were in a major downturn and that it follows from that that the problems facing this economy are very deep seated and intractable. The mechanisms and policies that the Government is pursuing to attempt to deal with those intractable problems are patently out of line with real needs. What this fiscal laxity on the Government's part means is that even greater weight has to be put on other policy arms to address our problems. That has not been the case. There has been a substantial easing in monetary policy. Micro-economic reform has stalled before even getting into first gear. The Government is hamstrung on its wages policy.

I want to focus on inflation, since the Government, and especially the Treasurer (Mr Keating), have thrown the towel in on attacking inflation. The Minister for Finance has already admitted that the Budget time forecast of 6.5 per cent inflation will be exceeded. That comes on top of the 7.3 per cent and 8 per cent increases in the previous two financial years. It is almost a cliche now to say that under this Government we have seen our inflation rate consistently around twice the average of that of our major trading partners. That is a problem of fundamental magnitude. What should be done about it?

The first thing that needs to be done is to establish an anti-inflationary culture. That was recently recognised by the Governor and the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia. Monetary policy needs to be directed at attacking inflation. The Government itself must be committed to that goal. It must make that commitment clear to all concerned over the medium and the longer term. That is what is so damaging about the policies of this Government-there is no commitment at all to reduce inflation. In fact, the accord has institutionalised inflationary expectations. As the Governor of the Reserve Bank has acknowledged, this has set a dangerously high floor under inflation in Australia.

That is also why the continued reliance on monetary policy has been so damaging for Australia. It has been directed at essentially the wrong prime target-the current account of the balance of payments, as the Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank was honest enough to point out before he was, of course, publicly berated by the Treasurer, who was unwilling to admit the error in his whole policy targeting and direction.

It would be hard to find an economist today who would not acknowledge that the thing monetary policy does best is control inflation. Also, there has never been any commitment on the Government's part to reduce inflation. The next cut in interest rates was always around the corner, even if no headway was made on inflation. No headway could be expected, given the damage and the institutionalisation of that high inflation rate by the accord.

There is a need to replace the inflationary expectations now entrenched in our system with an anti-inflation culture. I quote the Governor of the Reserve Bank in New Zealand because it is a very important statement:

The objective of eliminating inflation can be accomplished provided the authorities remain committed to that objective . . . if those who set prices and wages could be convinced that inflation could be eliminated over the next two years, the social costs of achieving this would in turn be eliminated. This emphasises the need for the Reserve Bank (and indeed politicians) to say nothing which might reduce the credibility of that objective. Every time credibility is reduced, the social costs of reducing inflation are increased.

To do this the Government needs to better articulate the major costs of inflation. They are not always well recognised or easily identified, but they are of major concern. Major social and economic costs are involved with inflation. The redistributive effects on income and wealth are unpredictable and undesirable. There is a bias to short term, speculative investment rather than to long term, productive investment. Volatile high rates of inflation make planning difficult. Interaction with the tax system is a major problem. Under high inflation there is a strong incentive for acquisition of real estate rather than productive investment and discouragement for financial savings. This is the very opposite of what the country needs.

Inflation provides an incentive for the Government to see it continue through the revenue gains from bracket creep. Indeed, it has been calculated by the firm, Access Economics Pty Ltd, that since 1983-84 the Government has received $22 billion from taxpayers in bracket creep alone. Inflation adds to the foreign debt problem by eroding competitiveness, eroding incentives to save and invest, and also by attacking stability.

The Government should give an unequivocal commitment that inflation is a prime concern which will be consistently addressed. There is only one way to bring down inflation on a sustainable basis and that is to convince savers that the Government and the Reserve Bank are irrevocably committed to long term price stability. This is especially difficult when there is a history of caving in when the short term social and political costs of achieving it begin to mount. There is now an obvious parallel with the excessive easing of monetary policy back in 1987-88. The then outgoing Governor of the Reserve Bank, Bob Johnston, said in May 1989 that the excessive easing in policy due to the bank's miscalculations meant that interest rates would remain high for quite a while. He said:

It was believed then (ie around May 88) that the course of monetary policy would be a good deal easier. Now . . . the major miscalculation that we made, including myself, was to underestimate the power in the economy, the pressure of growth, the exuberant spirit and the animal spirits that were at large and we have gone on underestimating for a very long time how strong the economy is-so that we were not able to get a switch of policies, pressure from monetary policy on to fiscal policy, and we find now that we need them both.

That is exactly the point that I was making earlier. With every premature easing of monetary policy which is not accompanied by accommodating changes in other arms of policy, the task is that much more painful next time around. The inflationary expectations become further entrenched and the problem becomes that much more intractable.

We need decisive action on inflation. We should have had it when this Government started to let the inflationary situation run out of control years ago. The Government lacked the courage then and the resolve to make the necessary changes to turn our disastrous inflationary situation around. It is still refusing to do that and we are living bitterly with the consequences of that lack of courage. Instead, the Treasurer is quite obviously preparing the ground for a further cut in interest rates at a time when the wheels are falling off the Government's policy cart particularly, as I said earlier, so far as fiscal policy is concerned. As Max Walsh said only yesterday in the Melbourne Age-and I commend his article to senators:
A further cut in domestic interest rates would signal that Australia is prepared to risk the inflationary consequences of capital flight, a collapsing exchange rate and accelerating inflation.
It seems that we are on the precipice of another major hike in our inflation rate compared with the rest of the world. If that is the case, then that indeed is a recipe for disaster.

Many exporters and local manufacturers who face competition from imports understandably complain about the impact of high interest rates on the exchange rate. High interest rates cause the exchange rate for the Australian dollar to be higher than it otherwise would be. As a result, at least in the short term, exports are dearer and imports are cheaper. The issue is very complex, but a number of points can be made.

Firstly, it is absolutely beyond dispute that monetary policy-any monetary policy-will have an effect on the exchange rate. It is also generally acknowledged that monetary policy has a major impact on inflation but has only limited effect on the real economy-that is, output and employment-other than in the short term. If we were to accept the need for a devaluation of the currency, there would be a direct and quite immediate effect on inflation. This would come through increased prices of imports and for those goods which are sold domestically but also exported.

Movements in the exchange rate are also likely to have a major impact on inflationary expectations-expectations already so entrenched in Australia. Exchange rate changes also tend to reflect capital flows rather than underlying trade and competitiveness conditions. Therefore, any depreciation in the exchange rate tends to increase inflation both directly and indirectly and tends to push up long term interest rates, and often short term interest rates as well, as local and foreign savers demand increased compensation for the eroding capital value of investment.

That brings us to the critical issue of whether a fall in the nominal exchange rate can actually help our exporters and import-competing industries in the longer term. The value of a depreciation is soon eroded if inflation continues to run ahead of our major trading partners because this undermines our competitiveness. I have just outlined the reasons why a nominal depreciation creates a number of pressures to build inflation into the system. Two of the world's most successful export countries in the past few decades have been Japan and West Germany-indeed, they are not only successful export countries but they are probably the two most successful countries in the world in terms of growth and lifting the living standards of their people. The currencies of each of these nations have been steadily appreciating over time.

There has been various economic modelling done by various institutions in recent times-and, indeed, over a lengthy period-to look at the question of the gains or otherwise from continued easing of monetary policy. A very interesting article in today's Australian comments on some recent economic model simulations by the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA). That IPA modelling showed that there would be little to gain and something to lose from continued easing of monetary policy. Any cuts in interest rates would be unlikely to be sustained, according to the outcome of the study, and there would be no improvement in unemployment or growth. The only lasting impact of looser monetary policy would be to lift the inflation rate significantly above its current trajectory.

The IPA simulations did show, however, that long term gains could be delivered with a tighter fiscal policy. With a substantial tightening of fiscal policy there would be beneficial effects on the current account deficit and a sustained fall in interest rates and the exchange rate. This is what makes these Appropriation Bills so irresponsible. The inadequacy of the Budget in effectively restraining outlays means that the Opposition's continued call for a rebalancing of policy appears not possible with this Government. It is impossible to deliver sustained falls in interest rates unless looser monetary policy is backed up by tighter wages and fiscal policies.

The failings of this Budget were also evident in a number of issues that were raised by me and by many other members in the Senate Estimates committees. In the area of the Department of Finance, major bungling was revealed over the sale of assets which are supposed to contribute up to $1 billion to the Government coffers this year. The sale of the Moomba to Sydney gas pipeline has run into trouble, involving Supreme Court action, possible breach of business contracts, and a repeat tender process after changing the rules of the game midstream. I would also refer to the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation sale which saw journalists being raided. I must say that the obstructionist line at Estimates hearings from asset sales task force members was a matter of concern to the Senate. We will be returning to that in the committee stage.

We saw evidence of abuse of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. We discovered delays in the payments made from the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office. We found continued tensions between the Government and the Australian Audit Office over its role and resourcing. In the Treasury evidence to an Estimates committee we saw massive stonewalling on the question of the Treasury involvement and the knowledge of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of developments in the Pyramid collapse in Victoria. Then there was the question of the sale of the State Bank of Victoria to the Commonwealth Bank and the role that the Treasurer played in that. The Treasury, remarkably, is still sticking to its Budget forecasts even though both the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the Treasurer have admitted in recent days that two of the central parameters, namely inflation and unemployment, are understated. The possible compensation for oil companies after the Treasurer's inappropriate interference in the setting of oil prices was also a matter for considerable debate in Estimates committees, and it is a matter that I hope the Senate will pursue in consideration of these Bills in Committee of the Whole.

Finally, and most importantly, in mentioning matters relevant to the Senate Estimates procedures, I foreshadow that, when Appropriation Bill (No. 1) is being considered in the Committee of the Whole, the coalition will be moving the following request for amendment:

That the House of Representatives be requested to amend the Bill by reducing the vote for the Department of Administrative Services by $1,028,596 because of the decision to write off as irrecoverable money unlawfully paid out as postage entitlement for certain members of the Parliament.

In the last couple of minutes available to me, let me go back to the overall thrust of the Budget. I have outlined the problems that the coalition sees with the Budget. I now want to outline briefly the alternative strategy that we would adopt in government to start tackling the problems which have beset Australia very importantly as a result of the actions of this Government. There are several major areas of difference between the two parties and never has the electorate had a clearer choice than now exists between the two major parties in the Federal Parliament. First of all, on expenditure we are committed to a much greater degree of restraint than has occurred under Labor. SPEECH.PARA: Today I wish to look at several areas concerning individuals and groups of individuals that are affected by the Budget, governments and the community. Mainly those are rural people, and people who are mobile. I include Australian Defence Force (ADF) families. There is a lot to commend in the initiatives that have been taken recently by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), with the support of the States, on new federalism. I will continue to support those actions fully and will bring to the attention of both the Prime Minister and the State Premiers instances and areas that they need to look at.

Although a lot has been done through the new federalism discussions, let me highlight some of the problems facing mobile families in terms of education. It is only in the last two years that education has moved forward and we have recognised that we are Australia and not six States and two Territories. People do move between the six States and the two Territories. They do not require visas or passports to do so. However, with the education system that exists between the six States and the two Territories sometimes they would have greater ease of movement if they were moving overseas.

We do not yet have a common starting age for people commencing formal education. We have managed to overcome the problem, but on previous occasions it has meant that children commencing formal education at the beginning of the year in one State may not have been able to continue their schooling if, for instance, their family moved to another State in the May school holidays. For example, a family may have moved from Victoria to Queensland for employment reasons but, because the starting age in Queensland was different, that family's children were not able to continue their schooling. The States have been amenable and very cooperative in overcoming that problem.

There was also a problem with handwriting in that States would not accept another State's handwriting style. For the life of me I cannot understand why, in this single country called Australia, one handwriting style is not the sensible way to go. However, the States have now agreed to accept the different handwriting styles within the country. That is a very good move forward on the part of the States and I thank them for it.

There is a need for some portability of subjects because what might be called economics in one State may not be at all like the economics taught in another State. There may be problems with teaching languages. If the family of a child being taught Italian in a school transfers that child may find that at the new school he cannot continue his option of Italian but has to learn Indonesian, Japanese, German or perhaps French. That discriminates against the child. Usually languages are taught at the senior level, so that person who is preparing himself for future education and employment is being discriminated against, causing him problems when he tries to get a decent high school certificate score or tertiary entrance score, depending on which State it is. In addition, conditions of entry into high school are not the same throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you promoting a unitary system?

—I am promoting some portability so that students can move between States in Australia without harming their education to a great degree. I recognise that moving around Australia has some positive benefits, but we have to be very conscious of the problems that that can cause. A lot has been done by the States and the Commonwealth Government to overcome these problems. I call upon them to continue that work and to move towards overcoming the problems even further.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Education Council has a working party on the problems of mobility. In 1987, 70,000 students moved interstate. I am not talking about a small or insignificant number. I was told by a senior person within a State education department that it was only about 3 per cent and, therefore, it did not warrant any special programs or any special assistance. However, the bright children within the school system make up about one to 2 per cent of the school population and they do have special programs. I think that that dispels the dismissal by that particular educationalist on that subject.

The working party looked at the introduction of a number of things. One that strikes me as very worth while is a student information portfolio. It is a booklet that outlines for parents-there is also one for schools and teachers-the types of material that students should take with them when moving schools so that the teachers at the incoming school will have a very clear understanding of the level of attainment they have reached, the type of subject, and what was being taught. This is very important. The Australian Defence Force initiated a lot of this work to improve and overcome these problems. To the people I had the opportunity of working with last year I say: congratulations on your hard work and the benefit that has come.

Another area that has caused problems for people who move is professional qualifications and registrations. Until now there has not been portability or transferability. Registration is required within each State for each profession. A number of professions do not require registration within all the States, so a person who is moving around has to know which States require registration and which States do not. Some States maintain that their course is the best and, therefore, nobody else comes up to it and only they will recognise their trained people. That is also a problem. I understand from media reports that some of these problems have been overcome in the federalism talks that took place this week. I commend the States and the Prime Minister for that. I will keep watching that matter with a great deal of interest.

To highlight some of the problems, let me talk about Broken Hill. Broken Hill is a city in New South Wales with a population of 25,000 to 35,000. It is close to the South Australian border. It takes five hours to drive from Broken Hill to Adelaide in South Australia and three or four hours to drive down to Mildura in Victoria. It is about a seven- or eight-hour drive to Dubbo, the nearest major centre in New South Wales, and a nine-, 10- or maybe a 12-hour drive through to Orange. To Sydney it is a day and a bit. The people in Broken Hill naturally relate either to Victoria or South Australia for many of their things.

These problems were highlighted to me by a group in Broken Hill called MEDSAC. They highlighted the problems they were having getting medical people to come to their community. If they wanted a specialist to come from South Australia, I am advised that that person requires registration in South Australia and New South Wales. If they wanted someone to come from Mildura, he required registration in Mildura. This highlights the problems that the psychiatrically ill face with that particular State border. If someone is psychiatrically ill in Broken Hill, Tibooburra or somewhere such as that and requires a schedule 2, that is covered by State law. As I understand it, that requires a doctor who is registered in New South Wales to fill out the necessary documentation. He is then transported to the nearest psychiatric institution, which in New South Wales happens to be Bloomfield, Orange. That can be a nine- to 10-hour journey. The patient may require restraint or may refuse to take fluids during that trip and the people of Bloomfield end up in the middle of summer with someone who is not only psychiatrically ill, but also physically ill. That is a problem that I will keep bringing to people's attention until we overcome these problems. I am prepared to recognise that people are keen on States rights. I am also prepared to say that we do have to overcome a number of the problems that are thrown up by these barriers.

I take this opportunity to say thank you to defence families. The members of the Australian Defence Force fulfil many roles. They fulfil the defence role. Last year in New South Wales they also went out fighting bushfires for us at very short notice. Last year they went out and repaired a bridge that a bulldozer on the back of a low-loader had knocked down. After the fires had been put out, they then went to help the communities that had problems with floods. Some of them must have spent several weeks, and maybe months, working in particular areas. They were given short notice and have been separated from their families.

The communities have sent their thanks to members of the ADF, who have done their job above and beyond the call of duty, as they always do. We also need to say thanks to the families, because they are the ones who are left to support the children; and the partners are alone on many occasions when their spouses go off to deal with these disasters and emergencies. Our thanks must go out to them. On behalf of honourable senators in the chamber, I thank them for the support they give to their Defence Force spouses. Not all Defence Force spouses are female. A number of women within the Defence Force are married and have spouses who are not members of the Defence Force. To them all, I send a big thank you.

One of the initiatives of the Labor Government has been to introduce FIND; that is, family information network for defence. That was introduced in March 1989. Some people were sceptical about this. This is a 008 number, which enables defence people and their families to ring up and seek information on policy matters. Since its inception 18 months ago, it has received in excess of 9,000 calls, which works out at 500 calls a month, which is well over 100 calls a week. That indicates to me that it has been fulfilling its aim of being a source of information and improving communications for families.

One topic that has been very popular for people to ring about is housing. In the last couple of years many improvements have been made in defence housing. Certainly it is not all fixed or finished and there is a lot of work to do, but the Defence Housing Authority has come up with some very good initiatives, housing proposals and plans. It is doing simple things that have not been done before in some areas and, for some time now, has provided security doors and fly screens for houses. When we bear in mind that a number of the defence houses and establishments are in very hot, dry and remote areas, this is most welcome. It has also improved the procedures for the repairs.

I would like to refer again to health. This is an area which I have a great deal of concern about and which, because of my nursing background, I will continue to watch and work very closely with. I have visited these rural areas and I know the problems that these rural communities are having in attracting doctors to practise there. I do not have all the answers and perhaps I will have to have a talk with Senator Peter Baume, particularly after he has moved to his new capacity as a professor, to see what we can do to encourage medical practitioners to do some country work. It has been put to me by some doctors that perhaps their training is lacking. They train in the cities, do most of their practical work in teaching hospitals and get a very good understanding of the drug regime that is needed for cardiac and renal transplants and the high-powered technology stuff, but they do not feel confident in the knowledge they have gained about the more simple, generalist areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our new Associate Professor of General Practice did nine years practice in Bourke.

—I am delighted. Those are the sorts of moves that we have to encourage. We are also setting up a rural and remote health unit. I note that some of the States are doing the same thing. So this problem is being recognised. We must continue to work on it. I thank Senator Peter Baume for that piece of information. It heartens me greatly. There is someone, going into the practice of teaching, who has the practical experience as well as the theory. This will be very good.

SPEECH.PARA: There are problems in getting locum relief. I have mentioned the training. But there is difficulty in attracting not only doctors to rural areas but also the full range of health professions. It is important that we do not just say, `We can't get doctors to go to country areas'. There are also shortages of nurses. There are certainly gross shortages of occupational therapists, speech therapists and physio- therapists, just to name three other paramedical professionals. We will have to continue to address these problems. Maybe we will have to address them with the professional bodies themselves. I know that the College of Nursing takes postgraduate and post-basic training courses to the rural areas. They do not necessarily go to the remote areas, but I know that the New South Wales college takes out a number of its courses to places such as Tamworth and Dubbo. I think on occasions it has been out to Broken Hill too. This is beneficial to those of us who have practised and worked in those areas because we do not have to travel down to the big city. That is important. It is not that we do not like the big city; it is just that it is much easier for us to move around within the country areas.

I would like to move on to areas specifically related to country people. In this year's Budget there was an allocation of $900,000 over the next two years to expand Countrylink. Many honourable senators may not know what the Countrylink program is. It is a very important source of communication and information to country people on what the Federal Government has available to them. The telephone number is 008 026 222. It is toll free. This service has an annual usage of about 20,000 calls. That indicates that it is a needed service. It is able to provide people with information on the services available and refer people to the appropriate areas.

This Government has increased the usage of 008 numbers within many of the Commonwealth departments. This is only to be lauded and applauded. This service is of great benefit to those people who have high enough telephone bills without the prospect of having any greater burden placed on them when trying to contact government departments. When people ring government departments they often get a response telling them which department it is and asking them to hold the line. The callers can quite literally hear the cents ticking over. The availability of 008 numbers stops this from happening.

Countrylink also has shopfront displays, community information stands which it takes around to shows in small country centres, a database and the Rural Book. The Rural Book has to be one of the Commonwealth's most popular publications. I am currently sweating on the latest edition coming out. It provides in hard copy lists and phone numbers of Commonwealth departments and services. It has been most beneficial to country people.

Also in the Budget we saw the announcement of an allocation of $128.3m to the Weather Bureau. Of that, $2.6m will be devoted to aspects of upgrading severe weather and flood warning services. When I first saw this and thought it was very important, everybody asked why. They failed to recognise that, west of the mountains, half of New South Wales has this year been just about under water. We are looking to help those people on the upper reaches of the Lachlan and Macquarie rivers to receive earlier flood warnings with the installation of various equipment.

The Bureau of Meteorology has two types of equipment for collecting the data, one of which is a telephone telemeter. This is a gauge to record rainfall and rises in river levels. It simply involves the Bureau ringing an automatic gauge to collect the data on the telephone. In the old days, a person had to measure these things manually. In areas where there are sudden rises in rivers and streams-sudden floods and gushes-the people who have to go out and physically collect the data are put at some risk. This gives an added element of safety. The telemeters can be so placed that people's lives will not be endangered and they can perhaps even give quicker and more accurate information.

There is also the radio telemeter. This gauge performs the same function, but every time there is any rainfall or the river rises one centimetre this information can be sent to a local point. The gauge itself is primed to ring in to, say, the local town clerk's office, as this may be the centre for the State emergency services and this type of organisation if there is a lot of rain. These local points will receive recordings, information and alarms when there is a certain increase in the rain level and river height.

These facilities are very beneficial. For instance, in the floods of April, May, June, July and August, in Wellington three rivers rose together. It was known that there would be a big flood but there were difficulties in getting the precise details of how big that flood would be.

I was delighted to see in the Budget that the Government is moving to introduce some of these systems. Most of them are more applicable to the coastal rivers because they rise much more quickly. Of course, they abate more speedily as well. They would not be needed in places such as Bourke or Brewarrina because it is often known several months in advance when the flood is coming. As a result of the floods earlier this year, communities on the downstream end of the Lachlan River and the Darling River will be flooded at Christmas time. It is a very strange country, but the flood warnings will help those of us who live closer to the mountain ranges.

Also on health, I am pleased to note that the Government is making a contribution to the secretariat of Farmsafe. This organisation has been set up in conjunction with WorkSafe as well as in conjunction with the Rural Training Council of Australia, the National Farmers Federation, the Rural Development Centre at the University of New England and the Moree Hospital Agricultural Health Unit to look at ways to reduce farm accidents. Farming is a very dangerous occupation. After mining-coal mining in particular-farming is the most dangerous occupation. Farmsafe is setting up small organisations right across the country and it is having a very beneficial effect. It is raising the level of awareness and knowledge of the danger within country communities and is to be applauded.

I say in conclusion that this is a very good Government. It has introduced a number of initiatives to help and to look after people. There have been a number of attacks on the Budget by the Opposition but we have not seen any clear-cut alternatives. We do not need comments about greater restraint; we need to have outlined very carefully how these initiatives will hurt the individual. It is fine to talk about economic modelling situations, but these economic modelling situations have to be reduced to just what the implications are for the individual. When those opposite talk about greater fiscal restraint, just where do they intend it to take place? In pensions? In defence? In Farmsafe? In Countrylink? I pose those questions to the Opposition. I will be interested to hear of any alternatives that those opposite may wish to put up, but I am sure that they cannot do better.

Those people who agree with that approach or who say that it should have gone further actually become partners to the proposition that we should deliver personal income tax cuts and at the same time pay for some of them by making life harder. How are we going to make life harder? It was announced in the Budget that effect would be given in this Appropriation Bills package and in associated Bills to a number of measures to withdraw some benefits from battlers-for example, the ending of the first home owners grant, which was useful to battlers of a young age, and the announcement by the Government that it would make more demands on the elderly. Witness the new rules with which elderly people will have to comply in relation to the deemed interest on their cash deposits. That is a part of this Budget package which will make life harder for the eld- erly. Witness the new pensioner payments for pharmaceuticals. Whether one takes mark 1, mark 2, mark 3 or mark whatever is finally decided on, it will mean that elderly people will be paying more for their pharmaceuticals and that is in direct repudiation of a specific election promise.

It is a Budget that will make life harder by tightening access to income support for the ill and unemployed, and requiring more form filling and more documentation; a Budget which will make life harder by reducing payments for the younger unemployed-all so that Senator Bolkus and I can have cuts in our personal income tax. This is absolutely immoral. If that is the level of government thinking, from whatever side of parliament, it is quite immoral. This is a Budget which reduces government expenditure on certain program components of the campaign against drug abuse, even while the problems continue to increase. It is a government whose Budget program, as announced, withdraws half a million dollars from the previously agreed upon funding for the better health program-so that we can get our income tax cuts. It cuts $140,000 from Commonwealth funding of methadone maintenance programs while the number of people needing those programs continues to increase. It is a program which cuts by up to $3 previously agreed to rates of funding for AIDS even while the number of people suffering from HIV infection continues to increase markedly. All of this hardship is so that we taxpayers can have cuts in our personal income tax delivered to us.
As the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said in his Budget Speech, included in the Commonwealth spending policies are:
. . . the personal tax cuts announced during the election to be paid from January 1 next year costing the Budget $1 1/4 billion,

I propose that if $1 1/4 billion is to be spent-that is $1,250m to be spent-it could be better spent on the poorer and needier members of society. There is absolutely no morality in delivering to Ministers of State, on salary packages of $122,000, or to senators and members on salary packages of $80,000-and we are among the body of taxpayers-cuts in our personal income tax. That is not where the priority should be. The priority should be with those who are needy and poor. Yet, as I have said, they are bearing the brunt of much of what is going on in this Budget and in the associated Bills. It is immoral. There is no justification for that kind of priority. Whether it comes from a laissez-faire government of one persuasion or whether it is included in the programs of an alternative laissez-faire government, it is still unacceptable. Our priorities should be first to the poor and needy and if there is money to be saved it is to those people to whom the resources should be applied first and it is the taxpayers like us-like you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and like everyone else in this chamber-who should be prepared to stand back and forgo tax cuts if it means that some people in real need might benefit. The proposal to give personal income tax cuts and to put into effect the kinds of Budget cuts I have mentioned is, in fact, a quite regressive proposal. It is a transfer of income from the poorer to the wealthier and I am ashamed, at this stage of my career in this Parliament, that it is a Labor government that has introduced a Budget like that. But enough of that.

Let me turn to my views on policies in the social welfare area. The rhetoric which we hear from Senator Richardson is the correct rhetoric. It is the rhetoric which says, `Let us respond first to need. Let's agree that the first thing we have to do is try to identify need, try to measure need in society and try to identify unmet need wherever we can, recognising that that is a value determined matter'. I might think that a certain matter is of high need and you, Madam Acting Deputy President, might think it is of higher or lesser need, but that does not matter. Once we identify need and unmet need, let us respond first to those matters in the welfare area. I suggest to the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, that tax cuts for him and me do not qualify as highest need, and that the delivery of those personal income tax cuts, in light of the kind of rhetoric which Senator Richardson has put forward in this place, is unsupport- able.

Our welfare programs should respond to that need and to unmet need and they should do it adequately. I am proud to be a philosophical Liberal. I am proud to be from the Liberal tradition. It is communal obligation and action to give effect to communal obligation which have characterised many of the most glorious achievements of Liberal democrats in the last 150 years. The introduction of the age pension has meant that many senior Australians-many Australians over the age of 60 or 65 years-can now enjoy their retirement with some dignity and security. Perhaps those people who are concerned to see cuts delivered in personal income tax would like to do away with the age pension. After all, in one step they could release $8,000m. The zealots seeking smaller government might tell us that the payment of the pension is expensive anyhow and, if they are looking to redistribute income to themselves, that is perhaps one way to do it.

SPEECH.PARA: Liberals are proud as well of some of the other programs to help the needy with which we have been associated over a century-programs of sickness benefit, unemployment benefit, the invalid pension, the sole parent benefit, disability allowances and widows' pensions. We are proud of the roles which philosophical liberals have played in the introduction or enhancement of each of those programs. Each of them seeks to respond to some area of deprivation and need, and yet each of them, over recent years, has been subject to erosion or attack, or attempts to remove the legitimacy of the payment, mostly by those who support a philosophy of minimalist government, those who do not feel or display overt sympathy and those who seek to redirect the resources so freed to the non-needy majority, including themselves. I find it disgusting and this Budget seems to be doing the same kind of thing. We seem to be taking from the needy to give more to ourselves.

What I would do first and differently in welfare policy is concentrate on the assessment and measurement of need and then respond to need first and to the better off only later, if at all. There is plenty of need and there is plenty of unmet need. Professor Bettina Cass undertook a needs assessment exercise for the present Government. We could determine to act on more of her recommendations or, if we do not like them, we could set out to do another assessment of need.

There is plenty of need around. Consider sole parents for one moment. They have been the subject of enormous vilification and abuse-I have to say that too often this has happened at meetings of my own political party. More lies have been told about sole parents and more punitive measures have been proposed than for almost any other benefit. What judgmental, punitive people seem to forget so conveniently is that only 4 per cent of sole parent beneficiaries are teenagers. They seem to forget that less than 20 per cent of the beneficiaries have never been in a marriage or a marriage-like relationship. They seem to forget that most of the beneficiaries are women. They seem to forget that almost half the beneficiaries live below the poverty line or some decent living level.

What the sole parent benefit responds to is desperate financial need due, in most instances, to the breakdown of a marriage or a marriage-like relationship in which a woman-it is almost always a woman-is left with no money and with dependent children. The support of those mothers and children is within our capacity and if it is within our capacity it is our duty and privilege to be able to respond. That is the point. It is not something we do as charity; it is part of our communal obligation as citizens.

Certainly I support the enforcement of rules associated with the benefit. I support the active search for non-supporting or non-custodial parents to make sure that they contribute towards the support of their children. I support efforts like that which has been made by Senator Durack to have the parents of children contribute financially to their upbringing. But saving money is not of itself-and never has been-a sufficient or justifiable social goal.

It is a judgment upon a society that would make the saving of money the social goal which is being pursued. It is not an adequate social goal. A social goal has to be what one gets by way of outcomes. It is certainly not an admirable social goal if one of the consequences is a tougher life, more misery and more difficulties in responding to significant need.

I would target my welfare policies to those in need. We can argue about how we define it, but I would extend programs first to those areas of unmet need. I support any government, including this Government, to the extent that it will do that. It follows that I would withdraw the benefits by one mechanism or another from those not in need, as I defined it. The only caveat I offer, and I do commend it to the Government, is that if one decides to withdraw benefits, spare the aged aged-those who are very elderly. They cope very badly with changed conditions. If they are receiving benefits on an understanding, do not change the rules half way as was done with some of the pension rules in the last year. It causes a great misery for the older aged Australians. The changes, if we want to make them, should apply to younger Australians and to new entrants to any benefit or welfare scheme.

I have one other comment to make on welfare. I would direct my benefits by way of welfare payments; I would not direct them by way of the tax system. I do not approve of welfare being made available through the tax system. Senator McMullan is nodding. Welfare paid via the tax mechanism is regressive; it often does not target those for whom it is intended; it is not a good way to direct benefit to those for whom the benefit is intended. The other thing I would do is work towards direct provision.

Let me talk now about health policy. Such a notion is really quaint in Australia because we do not have a health policy. I do not think we have ever had a health policy in Australia. What we discuss in this country is some financing policy. That may be valid. We spend a lot of time arguing about who pays what by way of which levy. That is merely a taxing measure. I want to say something about health policy. Let us suggest something quite outrageous: we might need to have health goals for a health policy; we might actually have to have some goals which relate to the health of society; we might actually want to have a health policy which has as its program goals the achievement of certain better health outcomes.

In that kind of system, health insurance is a means and not an end in itself. Getting the health insurance arrangements right does not give one a policy. It is a sideshow. At the end of the day it may be important how things are financed but it does not guarantee the delivery of any useful health outcomes at all except one, perhaps, and that is that the promise of the right to access to medical services might be important. This is-and I say this with some diffidence in the presence of a learned surgeon-assuming that the provision of health services has any significant effect on health outcomes. We can argue that at some other time.

A concentration on health insurance is disastrous when it is joined with an absolutely mindless desire to save money as the primary purpose of the entire policy approach of a party. If someone says, `We don't care what you do, just save $600m out of the health portfolio', that cannot be done without cost, and the cost might be a cost that is borne in terms of the health of the nation.

Let me say a little about health insurance. I will not say much because as a member of a Senate select committee which is studying this matter I do not wish to breach privilege. But I can say a little; that is simply that I am not impressed by the acceptance by all major political parties of community rating, as it is understood, as the basis for health insurance. It simply does not make sense. It would make sense if it were concerned with some insurance scheme to which all members of society contributed, but private health insurance at the moment involves only about half the Australian population. The older funds involve particularly those Australians with the worst health experience in terms of usage of services. Community rating is merely a means of taxing the well to pay the insurance costs of the less well. Whatever we do in this country, if we are to get health insurance right-we will just take a look at that for a moment-we will have to fix up the great fallacy of community rating because it does not work. I will not say anything more about health insurance. The Senate Committee will say something about it in due course, and I will be a part of that report.

If health policy starts with health goals, what kind of health goals do we want? Australia traditionally has not had health goals; we do now have some health goals. This change came about in 1984 with the report of the Health Targets and Implementation (Health for All) Committee, and some health targets have now been accepted and adopted by some Ministers around Australia. For the first time we have some goals in health. I have not heard those goals referred to much in debate in this chamber. If we want a health policy, why not direct it towards the achievement of these goals?

I will read some of the goals out to see whether honourable senators think they are worth trying to achieve. They have nothing to do with money. They include: reducing significantly the gap in the health and well-being of Australian women; improving the overall health and well-being of Australian women; reducing the prevalence of smokers from 33.5 per cent in 1983 to 28 per cent or less by the year 1990 and to 15 per cent or less by the year 2000; reducing the proportion of adults who persistently have a diastolic blood pressure of greater than 90 millimetres of mercury to 5 per cent or less by the year 2000; increasing participation in breast cancer screening to 70 per cent or more of eligible women by the year 1995; and increasing triennial participation in pap smear screening to 50 per cent or more of women aged 20-69 years by the year 1990, to 75 per cent or more by the year 1995 and to all but a negligible number by the year 2000.

Further goals include: ensuring that evidence of a completed immunisation schedule is used as a condition of primary school enrolment, with exemptions being granted for defined medical, personal or religious reasons by the year 1992; eradicating indigenous measles by the year 1991-I might add here that any medical person whose child gets measles ought to be ashamed of himself because it can be prevented by immunisation; ensuring the use of combined measles/mumps/rubella vaccine in all immunisation programs for children by the year 1990; ensuring that hepatitis B immunoglobulin and a complete course of vaccination is given to all newborn infants of women identified as carriers by the year 1992; establishing a national database to record the incidence of diabetes and its complications by the year 1990; and increasing participation in sufficient activity to achieve and maintain physical fitness and health to 40 per cent or more of adults by the year 1990 and to 60 per cent or more by the year 2000.

Those goals may not be accepted by everyone, but they were presented to the health Ministers of this country and as far as I know they were generally supported by all Australian Ministers for health. I certainly support them. They are goals with which I hope the Liberal Party would have no difficulty agreeing. They do not say a thing about money; they are actually about the health of people and the health of communities. They will actually provide a better basis for a health policy than much of what has gone before. Of course what flows from that is that our policies would then be directed towards saying how we would give effect to achieving those goals by the dates and in the outcome figures which are provided. The question then ceases to be one of funding and becomes one actually of trying to achieve health for Australia. I see very little in this Budget and very little in the activity around this country being dir- ected towards goals such as the ones to which I have referred. That is what is so disappointing.

For this Government does not speak for them any longer. This Government has forgotten them. That is what the Budget Papers tell us and what the Appropriation Bills drive home. There may not be many old style Deakinite Liberals or Menzian welfare stat- ists-call us what you will-left in Parliament in this clinical and uncaring time, but those of us who are here will be heard while we remain and we will speak for standards of fairness and obligation, for compassion and sharing that underpin the introduction of much of the best welfare legislation during my lifetime. We will do so because that is right and we will do so because it is necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to follow Senator Peter Baume in this debate and to pick up the theme he developed. In addressing myself to the goals which I believe this country should pursue, but woefully I feel is not, I very much regret that in the not too distant future we will not have Senator Baume in our midst. I think it will be a great loss to the Senate when that day occurs. The goals I want to talk about are somewhat different.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me begin by saying that I believe this Government is attempting to build an economy, to change Australian society and to embark upon a number of projects without-and here I reflect the general theme of Senator Baume's remarks-clearly identifying the social and environmental imperatives which must guide our approach to the future. The facile and uncritical acceptance that economies must continue to grow and that environmental considerations must be made to conform with economic runs rather than the other way around and the contention that that is both desirable and inevitable so that we in the rest of the industrial world must become more competitive-these are the issues that I want to address.

It is into this deregulated free market economy that this Government seems to believe it can throw some high technology and that then Australia will once again become the lotus land-the lucky country, as it was described in the 1960s and 1970s. The social and economic models of this Government and its models of the future are remarkably similar to the models of those years of the 1960s and 1970s: the future will be like the past but only more so; where it will differ will be in the application of so-called high technology. It is a mechanical and a deterministic view of the future which this Government seems to see lying before all Australians.

I want to speak this evening about an alternative view which I find exciting and creative and which will be satisfying to all Australians, both now and in the future. It is one which will include both some high technology and some low technology, but it is one in which all the technology will be selected because it is appropriate to a happy society in balance with the ability of the Australian environment to sustain it indefinitely into the future; a society which will lead the world towards sustainability; and a world sustainable both socially and environmentally. This is the vision that I have for our future and this is the great destiny that I would have this country fulfil.

There are those who would frustrate this sustainable future led by an enlightened Australia concerned above all with the protection of life on this mere speck of rock in the universe-the only speck of rock in our corner of the universe that we believe is able to support life. These selfish vandals-and they are all around us-would sell us short with the sci-fi mirage view of the future, with multifunction polises, with very fast trains, with spaceports and, above all, with greed-led cargo cultism of foreign investment and endless consumerism.

We are the inheritors of the plans and aspirations of yesterday. The plans that we make today shall be the inheritance of our children and of our descendants. It is certainly not putting it too strongly to say that in practically every aspect of social and national life we are not coping very well; nor are we addressing satisfactorily or comprehensively the many very pressing problems which beset us. It should be plain to all, other than the wilfully blind, that our approach to the future must then be very different from the way our forebears planned for us.

Rapid technological change throughout most of the years of this century, together with the adherence to an economic model predicated on growth, on competition and on exploitation of the natural world, has produced a society in which the worship of and submission to technological change have become the religion and purpose of society. Technological innovation is now acting as the principal agent of profound social and environmental change. Technological change is no longer serving human needs determined by an open democratic process informed by an understanding of human and environmental needs.

The proposed multifunction polis (MFP) is but one example of this phenomenon. The multifunction polis much beloved by Senator Button, should it be built, will be the most expensive-and this is where I link back to the Appropriation Bills-and the most disastrous development ever undertaken in this country. The multifunction polis is based on this now outdated and inappropriate utopian vision of technology drawn from science fiction imagery. Honourable senators will remember the term `post-industrial age' used in the late 1960s. The vision then was of a future served by robots in the workplace, in transport, and in the home; videophones; three-dimensional television; information retrieval at the touch of a wristwatch computer, et cetera. This sci-fi view of the world was once thought to be a sufficient description of the future. Environment and human or social factors were never considered to impose pre-conditions; nor were human and environmental factors conceived as the end to which technology should be directed.

The MFP and the other proposed developments I have mentioned are the playgrounds of those who have not grown up. It is a Disneyland of gee whiz gadgetry. I would remind the Senate that the Japanese Ministry of International Trade and Industry in 1987, in its basic MFP concept document, included a proposal to build a mountain 2.1 kilometres high with a runway to launch linear rocket vehicles into orbit. This proposal was withdrawn from the English language translation.

Moreover, the planning of these projects has always been from the top down, and it remains from the top down. It has certainly not been democratic. From 1987 to the present, the project has been promoted through high level think-tanks comprising the top people in Government and the industry sector, and this remains true today. I would remind the Senate of the Sydney conference which was held on Monday and Tuesday last week, addressed by Senator Button and Premier Bannon and attended by the well-heeled and the wealthy and by business and government leaders. It cost $995 for the two days. Even now, while this period of public consultation over the MFP is in progress in South Australia, the Bannon Government has retained a public relations firm, at a cost of $150,000, to convince the public that the MFP is good for it.

This approach to our future really does not even fulfil the immediate and most obvious needs. A number of proposals for the MFP were evaluated by consultants McKinsey and Co. Ten of these were reduced to a short list of three which the consultants thought were commercially viable. These were: `Hollywood of the South Pacific'; `Home Betting'; and `Home Shopping for SE Asians'. Of these, Ken Davidson, the economics writer of the Age, perceptively asked:

Why would the Hong Kong Government allow its TAB business to be leached away by the MFP? The Japanese are the world's most sophisticated consumers who demand personal service. Why would they buy superseded goods from a TV presenter from Australia?

Moreover, the Bureau of Industry Economics' study of the economic viability of the MFP found that on the most optimistic assumptions-and that needs to be stressed-the project would yield a trade deficit of $800m for each of the first 13 years. Infrastructure alone is expected to cost taxpayers some $2.6 billion at a time when Government seems unable or unwilling to find the money for essential infrastructure elsewhere.

Indeed, there is a great irony in the call for corporations to invest in a world university in the MFP in the same year that an independent study finds that Adelaide University is both overcrowded and run down with a shortage of funds to maintain its present facilities. The plight of the University of Adelaide is no different from that of universities elsewhere, or indeed from Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) divisions around Australia. Nor does the MFP proposal meet the perceived longer term objectives and needs of Australia.

A huge blind spot in the MFP vision is the failure to recognise environmental and resource constraints except in so far as they give rise to market opportunities-for example, in waste management. The emphasis again is on profit maximisation, which underlies one think-tank's promotion of nuclear power as the preferred solution to the problem of global warming. One must ask rhetorically: why opt for solar power and energy efficiency when the fuel cannot be sold and the need for waste disposal technology is reduced?

Last week in Geneva scientists from around the world met to discuss solutions to the quickening problem of global warming. They have already identified that the world must cut its emissions of greenhouse gases by 60 to 80 per cent as rapidly as possible just to stabilise the rapidly increasing levels of these gases in the global atmosphere. I stress that that is not to return the levels to their pre-industrial level. For instance, with respect to carbon dioxide, where the pre-industrial level was 270 parts per million, the expected levelling, even with the most stringent restrictions imposed as rapidly as possible, would occur at some 400 parts per million. Without doubt, this is the most serious environmental problem humankind has ever faced. It is global. Its solution will require unprecedented leadership and cooperation and will impact on the basis upon which hitherto we have built our industrial growth oriented civilisation.

The Hawke Government has paid lip service to the seriousness of greenhouse and has issued a discussion paper on ecologically sustainable development. While it has done that, the actions of the Hawke and Bannon governments belie their words. In today's Australian Financial Review Dr Maurice la Riviere, a professor of environmental biology and the head of the International Council of Scientific Unions, is reported as saying:
We are at an interesting edge between science and policy now.
We hope governments and policymakers will understand what scientists mean.
Where we go from here is up to them but given what we know, there is absolutely no excuse for governments not to save on energy.
Harmuth Grassl, a German professor of meteorology, is reported as saying at the same conference:
Change on Earth is now so fast there is no analogy during the last 10,000 years.

While the submission on the multifunction polis in Adelaide gives greater weight to environmental management industries than previous MFP studies, it neither attempts to design its proposals or the project as a whole in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable developments nor even outlines what those principles might be. This is simply a symptom of the way in which this Government and State governments around Australia are and have been behaving. Instead, it is based on an outdated economic model aimed at indefinite growth in gross domestic product.

Honourable senators will recall that I have asked Senator Button a long series of questions in recent weeks about the importance the Government places on greenhouse and how the MFP and its other high-tech developments are to mesh with an attack on this problem. The questions, without exception, have been dealt with with derision by Senator Button and, I am disappointed to have to say, most of the Labor and coalition senators present.

The Federal Government has set a heavily qualified target of a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emission by 2005. The International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has found that CO2 emissions will have to fall from the present global average of 1.45 tonnes per person to 0.35 tonnes, a drop of 76 per cent, in order simply to stabilise-and I stress that word-atmospheric concentrations.

The situation for Australia is indeed much more precarious than that. Australian emissions amount to approximately 4.5 tonnes per person. Thus, we would have to reduce our emissions to less than 8 per cent of current levels to meet the IPCC global average. Anything less than that drastic reduction of 92 per cent in greenhouse gas emissions implies an indefinite continuation of the existing global inequity in access to energy.

Against that sort of reduction, let us consider what has been happening during the term of this Government. A recent report found that Federal Government funding for renewable energy resources has fallen 88 per cent in real terms since 1978. In December 1987, in response to Democrat pressure, the Government undertook to spend $5m over five years through a renewable energy research trust account. That was to be funded out of oil tax revenues. That commitment has been broken in this Budget.

One eminent solar energy researcher has told me that he could get funding for only 30 per cent of his applications and that lack of funds had caused a real drop in development work in his area. Another leading researcher of world class has obtained funding from the United States Department of Energy yet has not obtained funding for projects from the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council. We adopted a report from that organisation this afternoon.

Another world class researcher in this very city, Professor Stephen Kaneff of the Australian National University, has developed an advanced solar collector but has had to use money left over from other grants to carry on that development work. Research on the hydrogen or gas-fuelled zirconia fuel cell which was being carried out in the CSIRO Division of Materials Science and Technology in Melbourne has had to be suspended because that development could not be made to yield immediate economic returns.

In this country we have world leaders in the very technologies which specifically attack the problem of greenhouse gas emissions and which provide useable energy in non-polluting ways, yet this Government is withdrawing funds from these researchers and these developments and alternatively is pinning our future to the importation of outdated technologies which are part of the problem but not part of the solution.

Professor Martin Green's work is outstanding. He is working at the University of New South Wales. He has produced the most efficient photovoltaic cells in the world and has built the facilities to produce these in commercial quantities. While detractors point to the per watt cost of these cells and compare them unfavourably with coal fired electricity, the comparison takes no account of the cost of greenhouse damage resulting from coal burning or of the very large reductions in energy use which could be achieved through efficiency improvements now attainable with existing technology and which would reduce the per unit costs of end services.

The solar thermal technology of Dr David Mills, who works at the University of Sydney, which has already been sold to India for solar cooking and is used by one hospital in New South Wales for its sterile and hot water supply, is another technology which would allow very large and economic reductions in CO2 emitting fossil fuel use. Yet his work has essentially been on hold for the past 10 years through lack of government support.

On Wednesday last I travelled to the New South Wales Parliament House from North Sydney in an electric car-the townobile, manufactured in Sydney by an engineer, Mr Roy Leembruggen. He is an internationally respected authority on transport engineering. If we take that technology together with the research into more efficient control on motor technology progressing at Sydney University, we could have a total solar transport driven system in this country. But Australian governments have ignored Mr Leembruggen's work. Unless the Government rapidly changes its approach to this area of research and development and its belief in Australia's scientific inferiority, we shall be importing similar technology from other countries in the years to come. I draw the Senate's attention to considerable work which is now going on in other countries on electric vehicles.

The Australian Democrats suggest that in this country we have the talent and, moreover, a better sense of direction amongst some of our scientists, conservation groups and within the Australian Democrats than is found expressing itself in the official policies of most other countries. So we do not need to become a clever country; we need to become a wise country with wiser leadership in Canberra.

In relation to the appropriations, it is very appropriate to ask where the money for alternative energy research and development comes from. We would argue strongly that the money is already here but is being misspent. Indeed, Senator Button has identified one:
. . . fundamental element of policy environment conducive to the development of a robust . . . manufacturing sector.

That is to ensure that the maximum benefits are obtained from the Government's considerable purchasing power. He instanced the development and building of frigates in Australia, the submarines and the partnerships for development program. For example, the $4.6 billion submarine contract and the $4 billion frigate program are just part of military equipment programs and, of those amounts, $3.5 billion will be spent in 1990-91. As a result of this spending by government, shipbuilding has been revived and a large military electronics industry has sprung up based very substantially in South Australia where some 25 per cent of companies at Technology Park are involved in military electronics technology.

Paul Dibb, amongst others who wrote the report on Australia's defence needs several years ago, has identified Australia as one of the most secure countries on earth. Moreover, the low level attacks which we may suffer are not to be countered by the possession of submarines; they are part of a global, predominantly United States based, defence strategy.

Compared with the vague and unlikely threat of military invasion, the threat of global warming and the urgent need to address it are serious, massive and immediate. We urge the Government to use the same strategy of government-led purchases to stimulate the development of the alternative, but nascent, energy efficient and renewable energy technologies now languishing for want of research and development funds. We urge the Government to look to spending some $500m a year in this area through directed government purchasing. This would make us, we believe, once again the lucky country but, just as importantly, a wise country and one that could then help lead other countries down the road to their own pattern of sustainability. In that way, we would suggest, we will become a world leader-not a leader in the role of competitive economic exploiter, but rather a leader in the role of cooperative guide to survival.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1991 and related Bills. Together these Bills, which are being debated jointly, constitute the Government's Budget for the 1990-91 financial year. As a member of the Government I support this legislation and the broad thrust of the Government's Budget. It is the eighth Budget we have brought down since we gained the Treasury benches. This one continues the focus on restructuring the economy and making the Australian industrial structure more competitive internationally.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget, which is basically the centrepiece of the Government's fiscal policy, is working with incomes policy and monetary policy through interest rates to synchronise total levels of spending in the community with total levels of production. That has been the biggest problem facing Australia in the last couple of years. That is, spending and aggregate demand, in the jargon of the economists, have far outstripped total productive capacity in Australia. As a result, there has been an enormous spill over to imported products. The aim of policy has been to synchronise those levels of spending and levels of production.

The Budget, on my analysis, is a very tight one. Fiscal policy, as exercised by this instrument, is extremely tight. One of the objectives is to help relax monetary policy-broadly speaking, the use of interest rates to regulate spending on assets in the community. I am pleased to note that since the Budget was brought down some two months ago there has already been one major reduction in interest rates. So part of the objective of the tight fiscal policy being exercised through the Budget has been to already reduce interest rates as part of another round of reductions. That brings in the calendar year 1990 the total number of reductions in interest rates to five. For example, official cash rates have now come down 5 percentage points during 1990. There is a long way to go yet, but certainly the trend of interest is down.

Under this Government there has been a shift from Budget deficits. We had many decades of Budget deficits, that is, government spending far outstripping revenue collections. Under the Hawke Labor Government we have moved from Budget deficits to Budget surpluses. Last financial year the surplus was $8,000m. If we could add to the surplus within the Australian community the deficit in government spending overseas, where we spent more than we raised, the actual domestic surplus would be far in excess of the $8 billion; it would be $10.9 billion or, roughly speaking, about 3 per cent of Australia's gross domestic product. That is a very large proportion indeed for the outcome of one particular Budget and confirms how tight fiscal policy has been in recent years.

A number of key policy decisions were made by the Government before the Budget was brought down. For example, through the instrument of incomes policy, better known as the accord with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), there was an agreement before the Budget that there would be a tax and wage trade off package for employees. Part of that package is to provide for personal income tax reductions from 1 January. Of course that is less than two months from now. So in some eight weeks time Australian employees will be getting substantial personal income tax reductions as part of policy decisions made this year.

The thrust of the Government's policy in the incomes policy area is to boost the disposable income of Australian workers-the take home pay, if you like-by focusing on reductions in income tax rather than have employees demanding higher wage and salary increases in the economy.
