In the final event it is the employers who have to pay those high wage and salary increases. We take the view that it is better, in terms of helping Australia's international competitiveness, to focus on the bottom line-the take home pay or the personal disposal income-by providing personal income tax reductions. They will be coming into effect on 1 January.

Another part of the Government's income policy is for controlled money wage rises. For example, the agreement with the ACTU is to maintain the real incomes of workers in the September quarter-that is in the months July, August and September this year-by providing for an indexation of wages, I would imagine, probably within the next few weeks following the release of the consumer price index for the September quarter which is due to be published tomorrow. So we will have our first reversion to wage indexation in Australia for some four and a quarter years. The last time wages and salaries were adjusted for inflation was in July 1986, so we will have a wage indexation rise based on the consumer price index when it is published, which I believe will be tomorrow. For example, most of the estimates appear to be that the consumer price index will rise by between 1.5 and 2 percentage points for the September quarter. Whatever the figure is, that will be the amount of the wage rise paid to Australian wage and salary earners.

In addition to that percentage increase-we all know that percentage increases reward those on very high salaries more than those on lower salaries and wages; High Court judges receive much more from a 1.5 per cent wage rise than does the average worker-and to compensate partly for that effect, we shall be providing for a flat $12 a week wage rise early in the new year, probably around March or April. That sum of $12 will go to all wage and salary earners across the board. Those two measures-the indexation wage rise and the flat wage rise-are designed, through the incomes policy, to help family living standards. The Government is very well aware that family budgets have been constrained and confined in recent times. These measures are designed to take the pressure off family budgets.

When the Budget was being formulated, the economy was showing some slowing. It had been growing at an annual rate of about 6 per cent; it had been cut back to a 3 per cent growth rate. That, of course, was a deliberate result of government policy. We have not taken the decision lightly to slow down economic growth. In fact, the measure was designed to slow down the spillover, the excess demand, into imported products. As a result, growth had slowed from 6 per cent to 3 per cent up to June on an annual basis.

At the time the Budget was brought down there was still significant growth in the jobs markets. The number of people in jobs compared with the same time last year had grown by 2 per cent-quite a respectable figure. There had been some rise in unemployment with a 6.9 per cent unemployment rate recorded for June this year. At the same time that those things were happening in the labour market, there had been a trend down in the monetary variables. I have mentioned the reductions in interest rates. Prices had been trending down; the consumer price index in the 12 months to June had risen by 7.5 per cent. That was still far too high but it was a refreshing reduction from the levels of earlier years. Certainly it was nowhere near the double digit levels of inflation that were recorded under the Liberal Government earlier in the 1980s.

If the consumer price index that will be published tomorrow is less than 2.3 percentage points, we shall see a reduction in the annual rate of inflation in Australia from the figure of 7.5 per cent up to June. If the consumer price index is below 2.3 per cent, that will mean that the annual rate of inflation and of price rises will decline below the 7.5 per cent figure.

At the time the Budget was brought down we continued to have a significant deficit on the current account element of the Budget. There had been that very large deficit but there were some signs of improvement-with imports, for example, falling by 8 per cent in the period to June this year. That was certainly a very welcome reduction, partly reflecting the slowdown in economic growth in the Australian economy. Also at the time of the Budget we saw a trend downwards in fixed business investment. But despite all the doom and gloom about investment, that decline was from an extraordinarily high base. The share of business fixed investment in Australia's gross domestic product had been very high before it started to decline.

I turn to the broad outline of this year's Budget. We are certainly anticipating that total government spending in the Budget will be growing faster than it did last year. We are anticipating that spending in real terms ahead of price rises will grow by 0.6 per cent. Last year there was not spending growth of a positive nature; there were in fact real spending cuts.

One of the features of this Budget is the analysis which relates total government spending to the size of Australia's gross domestic product. We estimate that in this financial year that ratio will fall to 23.5 per cent. So, in total terms government spending will be less than a quarter of our gross domestic product. That is part of a continuing downward trend-a trend which has been evident under the administration of the Hawke Government. It compares very well with the figure in the 1982-83 financial year when government spending constituted 28.9 per cent of gross domestic product. Comparing the figure of 23.5 per cent-a reduction of over five percentage points-in a share of gross domestic product accounted for by government spending, we can clearly see that the Hawke Labor Government is not a high spending government. Despite all the rhetoric from some sections of the community about government spending, the record is very clear. Under this administration the share of government spending in gross domestic product has shown a very steady and substantial decline.

I now turn to the revenue side of the Budget. We anticipate somewhat slower growth in revenue collections this year than in the last financial year. We estimate that we will get growth of about 6.5 per cent in revenue this year compared with almost 8 per cent in the last financial year. The reason for that is very obvious. I have already pointed out that the Government has had a deliberate policy of slowing down the total demand in the economy, slowing down the level of activity in Australia. As that happens, so do revenue collections decline, as revenue is based substantially on income flows in the Australian community, whether they be of a personal or company nature. Last year there was real growth in government revenues-that is, revenues outstripped inflationary figures. This year there is hardly any real revenue growth.

It is very illuminating and instructive to look at the ratio of tax to gross domestic product. I looked at the other side of the ledger a moment ago-the ratio of government spending to gross domestic product. In regard to tax, the ratio will be of the order of 24.3 per cent this year-a figure which is very close to the figures obtained in the early 1980s. It is certainly not a figure that gives any support to the argument in some quarters that this is a high taxing administration. When it can be seen that tax revenue as a percentage of gross domestic product is of the order of 24.3 per cent, it is very hard to sustain the argument that Labor is a high-tax party.

The net result of the activity on the spending and the revenue side of the Budget is that there will be a surplus this year of $8.1 billion, which is a substantial sum. It is only the fourth Budget surplus at Commonwealth level in 40 years. It is the fourth surplus in a row. In that period of 40 years there were many years of conservative administration in Canberra and in none of the years of the previous Liberal administration was a Budget surplus recorded.

That surplus has been put to very good use. Specifically it is being used to help to pay off government debt. That provides ongoing benefits which do not relate just to this financial year but to future financial years. We estimate that there will be a saving of the order of $3,000m in interest payments annually simply because debt has been paid off over the last three financial years, and more will be paid off in the current financial year. In fact, in the three years before this year the Commonwealth paid off $18,000m in total in domestic and overseas public debt. The estimate for this financial year is that it will pay off another $7,000m. They are substantial amounts of money. Cumulatively over four financial years $25,000m in debt is being paid off.

I am pleased to say that within that total we have already paid off $4,000m of overseas debt. When we hear all the hype and hysteria about Australia's overseas debt, it is very important to remember that the Commonwealth Government alone has already paid off $4,000m of debt in recent times. It is very instructive to note that the Commonwealth Government is now a net creditor overseas; it is not a debtor. The Commonwealth Government has more in overseas deposits, overseas bank accounts and overseas reserves than it owes overseas. Therefore, it is a net lender overseas; it is not a net borrower as some sections of the electorate believe. This year the Budget is very contractionary and puts in place a tight fiscal policy, and that is partly reflected by the big domestic surplus. The Budget is probably taking 3 per cent or more from the economy in the current financial year.

Turning to the specifics, on the spending side of the Budget it is useful to look at some of the major spending areas to try to gauge where the Government's priorities are in reality. In money terms, total Government outlays are up 6.9 per cent. It is very interesting to note that in the science and research area that figure of 6.9 per cent is far exceeded. The total allocations for science and research in this Budget are to grow by 19 per cent. So 2 1/2 times the average growth in total outlays will be the rate of growth in outlays in the science and research area. In Question Time today a question was asked about the status of the cooperative research centres program which the Government is operating. Part of the funding for that will of course be within that 19 per cent growth for science and research.

Education outlays are up 14 per cent. A significant part of that is to focus on the need to restructure Australia's economy, to make it more competitive, to make Australia the clever country, to upgrade our work skills and to retrain our people. Within that allocation, for example, there is a 25 per cent increase in outlays-a massive increase in spending; equivalent to over $200m-to improve training and opportunities for disadvantaged job seekers in the Australian labour market.

One of the outlays that reflects levels of activity in Government policy is funding for unemployment benefit. Certainly there will be forecasts of an increase because we are slowing down the economy as a deliberate policy to reduce imports. We estimate that while on average 385,000 people received unemployment benefit last financial year, this year the average monthly figure will be 475,000. So there will be an increase there. Unfortunately, that is a direct result of having to slow down the economy to stop the level of imports being sustained as it has been.

However, on the other side of the ledger there will be substantial increases in family payments. The family allowance, which goes to most Australian mothers, and the family allowance supplement, which is focused on low income working families whose head is in the work force, will see their payments increased in line with the cost of living from January next. It has taken the Hawke Government to be the first government in Australia to index family payments in order to protect purchasing power, to protect those payments against price rises. In January next there will be a further increase in both the family allowance and the family allowance supplement.

As I have pointed out, taxation cuts come into effect on 1 January. Only two months from now there will be substantial personal income tax reductions. These will be given effect to by both changes in income tax rates and an increase in the amount of tax exempt income. The tax threshold will be increased from the present level of $5,100 to $5,400-a significant rise in the amount of tax exempt income. But over and above that the individual tax bracket rates will be reduced. For example, the present 29c in the dollar tax rate will go down to 21c in the dollar.

In addition, I am pleased to say that early in the new year there will be adjustment of the various tax rebates for cost of living rises. For example, the dependent spouse rebate and other rebates will be increased by 8 per cent in line with inflationary trends. Where there are dependent children, the dependent spouse rebate at the moment is $1,200. In the new year that will be increased by 8 per cent to $1,296. I know, from talking to people in my State, that that will be of significant benefit to single income families in the Australian community.

If the Hawke Government's performance is summed up in one particular area, one highlight has to be its record in extending superannuation through the Australian work force. Ten years ago only very privileged people, usually those in white collar jobs and usually male, had access to superannuation. When we came to power in 1983 the estimate is that only 44 per cent of Australian employees had some form of superannuation cover, some form of cover for their retirement when they ceased working. The figure now is not 44 per cent, 55 per cent or 66 per cent; it is 77 per cent. Seventy-seven per cent of Australian employees now have some sort of superannuation cover, some protection against costs in their retirement, a guaranteed income stream for their retirement years.

One of the aspects of this Budget which will stimulate superannuation contributions more is the fact that we are restoring tax deductions for many workers. This year, for low paid employees whose employers' contributions to superannuation are relatively small, below the equivalent of 4 per cent of wages and salaries, we are going to provide full personal income tax deductions for superannuation contributions made by those employees, the workers themselves. Those first $3,000 of contributions will be fully deductable against personal income tax.

A large number of retired members of the community are single pensioners. This Budget relaxes the taxation treatment of single pensioners by allowing them to have $40 a week over and above the basic pension before they are liable for income tax. That standardises the tax treatment of all pensioners with the income tests of the Department of Social Security for pensioners and it is a long overdue move. It is high time that both the taxation system and the social security system worked together and had consistent thresholds and income tests. This will finally apply in the current financial year.

On 1 January we begin the brave new world of the so-called gold tax. It is not really a gold tax. In fact, it puts the goldmining industry on the same footing as every other industry in Australia. One of the biggest rorts that ever existed in this country started in the 1930s when the goldmining industry was given privileged status. No company tax was levied on the goldmining industry. Perhaps it received investment it should not have received because of that tax distortion. From 1 January the goldmining industry will pay company tax on the same basis as income producing industries in the rest of the economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —There won't be many left. They have all been graded out.
— I am sure that Senator Parer would not want industries to be kept in operation by tax subsidies.
—They pay some tax anyhow.

—I know that Senator Panizza has a special interest in the subject. In the present day and age we cannot sustain an argument that industry should be propped up by tax subsidies. This move has not been brought in overnight. It was flagged and foreshadowed years ago that it would come in on 1 January next.
—That was a very stupid thing to do.

—No, it is a very sensible policy. We have to make sure that industries are taxed on the same basis. This particular measure removes one of the distortions in the tax system as it affected the goldmining industry.

SPEECH.PARA: With those few remarks, I would like to turn very briefly to the impact of the Budget on my State of South Australia. I am pleased to note that $4m has been allocated in the Budget for feasibility studies for the multifunction polis site in the Gillman area in the Port Adelaide district. Those studies are very important and will help us look at the site in some detail for the multifunction polis to be built eventually in South Australia.

The Budget allocates some $529m this financial year for the Collins-class submarine project to replace Australia's Oberon submarines. My estimate is that, of that $529m spent nationally, possibly over $200m will be spent in South Australia. That certainly will be an important boost to the local economy and will also help smooth out the business cycle as it operates in South Australia. In these trendy times of privatisation and deregulation it is important to have significant public projects with ongoing work because they can stabilise local economies as the income stream from those projects goes out into the community.

I have outlined a number of items in the Budget, I have focused on the broad outlines, and I have looked at some of the expenditure detail in the Budget. I think that overall this Budget shifts the Australian economy in the correct direction, continuing our process of economic restructuring and reform. It certainly slows growth. That was an unfortunate event that had to occur. It is due entirely to the fact that Australians were spending too much on imported products. We had to slow growth in demand for products produced overseas.

The Budget continues on the path of getting the economic fundamentals right in Australia. However, it is tempered, very importantly, with a strong dose of social justice through the indexation of family payments; through the adjustment for inflation of the various tax rebates; through personal income tax reductions which begin on 1 January next; and through wage rises, through the accord with the Australian trade union movement, which the community can afford. Despite the difficult economic times, I am sure that all those measures in this Budget will help take pressure off family budgets.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening the Senate is debating the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91 and related Bills. In speaking to these Bills, I would say that Australians today should be questioning how much longer they are prepared to live with a Federal government that is increasingly putting Australia deeper into debt. We have just listened to Senator Maguire trying to justify some of the actions of the present Government and not doing very well.

SPEECH.PARA: The policies of this Government are putting Australia deeper and deeper into debt, something which affects every man, woman and child in the country. Since this Government was elected in 1983 there has been a dramatic change in Australia's fortunes-not that it was not coming; it is just that many commentators Australia-wide failed to note what the average Australian could have told them, namely, that it is getting increasingly harder out there in middle Australia to make ends meet. And unfortunately there is no let up in sight.

This Government has deserted middle Australia. It has deserted the men and women it relies on to produce the goods, to buy the goods and to keep on paying the taxes so that this Government can continue its high-spending policies. Millions of average Australians have known for the last three or four years that this Government has been a failure as an economic manager of this country. When is this Government going to say that we have to make some policy changes and that we would like the cooperation of the Australian nation to bring those policy changes about?

I will tell honourable senators this evening that millions of Australian families know more about the reality of economic life in Australia than do members of the Government and the Government's advisers. They have living proof of it. They know about this Government's housing policies-policies this Government so loves that the Australian dream of home ownership has been put beyond the reach of ordinary Australians. Home ownership is now getting steadily beyond the reach of all but the relatively affluent people who are entering the home market for the first time. That fact is not only an economic disgrace; it is a social and family disgrace.

Just two years ago the Treasurer (Mr Keating) promised a Budget to bring home the bacon. Today there is not a housewife in Australia who could not put the Treasurer out of a job and budget better. Today the bacon he has brought home is reflected in crippling high interest rates, a crisis in the rural sector-the likes of which cannot be recalled for many years-declining living standards, increasing unemployment, higher inflation, higher foreign debt and a business sector under considerable pressure. We are much closer to that banana republic which Mr Keating warned us we were heading towards a number of years ago.

The Budget brought down by the Treasurer showed just how out of touch the Hawke-Keating Government has become. It clearly has no idea of the extent of the recession in the private sector in Australia, nor of the hardship being experienced by the great bulk of Australians. The hardship is felt by some of the thousands of people who have lost their jobs even in the last year or the thousands more who are about to lose them- regrettably, I must say; by the record number of small business people who have gone broke as a result of high interest rates, people whose life savings have been lost and who will take years to repay their debts; by those who are struggling to buy a home with a 16 per cent mortgage interest rate, or those who are forced to sell their house in a falling market; by spouses who have been forced to go to work just to pay the mortgage and supermarket bills; by the workers who had thought that a Labor government would look after their interests, only to find their wages squeezed and more than clawed back by higher inflation, interest rates and the Treasurer's bracket creep-a famous phrase that former Senator John Stone always used to talk about; and, finally, by a particular section of the Australian community which is bearing an undue amount of that hardship, that is, our great and previously profitable rural sector.

The headlines say it all. Senator Panizza will be interested in this: `$1.80 will buy one beer-or 18 sheep'. That is a figure that the headlines tell us about. Perhaps honourable senators prefer this headline: `A pair of Reeboks costs as much as 36 bags of wheat'. That is a very sad state of affairs for rural Australia as far as I am concerned. In simple terms, this means that the heartland of Australia is being devastated by high costs, inflation and general taxes. Small rural businesses and farming families in many cases can no longer keep up with the imposts of bureaucracy and big business.

An estimated 30,000 farmers are suffering a cost-price squeeze which will force many from the industry in the 1990s, to join the 30,000 who have left in the past 30 years, ironically when, for all its shortcomings, agriculture will earn a near record $15.5 billion in export income in 1990-91.

Country businesses are also in rapid decline. The Australian Small Business Association estimates that 15,000 businesses closed last financial year. The flow-on effect means that towns are dying. Communities with populations of fewer than 2,000 people are likely to lose schools, hospitals, police stations, post offices and banks in the next decade. Good houses lie vacant.

The extent of the rural crisis is shown by the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics, which estimates that the real net value of farm production will fall 51 per cent in 1990-91 to $1.6 billion. There is no doubt about it: the expenses incurred by the farmers are having a devastating effect. According to the June issue of the Bureau's quarterly, farm production will be only 29 per cent of the level in 1980, down from $4 billion in 1988-89.

Rural Australia's agony is all too evident. Witness the need to shoot millions of aged sheep and the state of the wool market. One farmer in Queensland got in touch with the St Vincent de Paul Society. He suggested that something be done about the fact that he had to shoot many of his sheep. One of the Catholic hierarchy got in touch with various people. Instead of the sheep being shot, destroyed and buried by the farmer, people cooperated to have them collected, killed and cut up. I believe that even Woolworths Ltd got into the act. The sheep were then delivered to people in very poor circumstances who were able to enjoy the mutton.

I congratulate the farmer who had that idea in the first place, the priest who organised it and all the people who cooperated with the transport, the killing and the cutting up of the sheep. Many people in Queensland would be very pleased indeed with the farmer who had the bright idea. It is a very sad state of affairs when these farmers have to shoot these sheep. It certainly does not help their income.

We then have the state of the wool market, the falling beef and wheat prices, the floods that occurred in Western Queensland and New South Wales earlier in the year and the plight of the farmers in the navy bean, pig meat, peanut, sugar, pineapple, canned fruits and dried vines industries. Booms and busts have been the nature of primary production for the past 202 years, but even after a good run agriculture has become less viable for a large number of farmers. Various forecasters see their ranks diminishing further from 175,000 to 100,000 in the next decade.

The Australian Bureau of Statistics says that Australia has 130,000 primary producers who grow more than $20,000 worth of commodities a year and 45,000 who produce between $5,000 and $20,000 worth. Despite our rich natural resources, we spend more than $7 billion a year on importing food, beverages, tobacco, wood and paper products and textiles. While this is a relatively minor component of the current account problem, the sheer value and volume point to structural problems in the economy. The situation is particularly worrying in the citrus, dairy, pork, dried fruit and oilseed industries.

Australia has a golden opportunity to become the world's greatest agricultural exporter with its pollution-free food. Indeed, we are on the doorstep of rapidly emerging Asian markets, the demand from which is expected to lift commodity prices in real terms for the first time this century. Yet, because vital industries are not being nurtured and preserved, the nation stands in grave danger of failing a rich and proud rural heritage. The nation should be concentrating on primary production because a 100 per cent increase in income from a manufacturing industry will be minor compared with any increase in the much larger rural industry. We need to put the financial incentives there to encourage people to produce more so that we will eventually claw our way out of the current economic mess.

The severe financial crunch the industry is facing is illustrated by the interest component of farm costs, rising from 9 per cent in 1985 to 13 per cent this year. That is an increase of 50 per cent in five years. Rick Farley of the National Farmers Federation suggests that Australia is neglecting agriculture to the nation's cost, partly because too few people understand the industry. This is caused by our being one of the most urbanised countries in the world and by the Great Dividing Range. These barriers are the reason why 12 million of 17 million people live in the largest 14 cities.

Mr Farley says that the most serious dilemma is the cost-price squeeze, in which farmers have to take world prices for their goods but are saddled with domestic costs that are not exposed to world forces. He sites government monetary policy as the second reason for falling farm returns. High interest rates are no solution to the current account deficit. The exchange rate is of tremendous consequence to us. Every move upwards of one cent costs the rural sector $150m.

There is no doubt at all that rural producers are indeed suffering. They are hit by fuel pricing policies which might make a great deal of sense in bureaucratic-compact Canberra but which add intolerably to the cost of living in remote parts of the country. These fuel pricing policies mean that the Federal Government Treasury coffers and the exchequers of States which impose fuel taxes are garnering rich profits from the crisis in the global oil market.

Today farmers are also being made to face financial risks associated with fluctuating commodity prices. The farm is failing in Australia because as a nation we have ignored our greatest resource, yet it offers solutions to our economic problems. We cannot afford simply to sit back and wait for the farm sector to be virtually depopulated. It is in everyone's interest to control the process, to ameliorate its worst effects and to approach the whole issue with a balance of sympathy and energy. South Australian farmer John Ayliffe recently told the Bulletin magazine:

When you buy a property, you make allowance for floods, droughts and bushfires but no-one can allow for the level of financial stupidity that has gone on in Australia. If we hadn't been hit by this monetary policy, we would probably have been paying tax at a higher rate now and employing one or two people. You know, we could live a lot more comfortably by selling the farm, investing the money and retiring.
I have said that at our home on quite a number of occasions. But it is not the nature of man to be a quitter. Another farmer from Victoria said:

Farming has a bright future because it is one of the few things Australia is good at. All we need is for the Government to change its interest rate structure which is carrying the can for mismanagement by State and Federal governments.

Wherever one goes in Australia the message is the same. My home district of Kingaroy and the Burnett is no exception. The south Burnett region in which I live normally produces 90 per cent of Australia's navy beans and it also produces 70 per cent of Australia's peanuts. Crops are down to 25 per cent of normal levels this year owing to either drought or wet harvests. It is very difficult to realise that in a short space of time there can be a change from everything being very dry and the farmers wondering whether they will get a crop because of drought to there being so much rain when the poor farmers are in the middle of harvesting their peanut or navy bean crops that they cannot get them in. The run of bad seasons has sapped farmers' confidence in what was regarded as one of the nation's safest climatic regions. What was among the most expensive farming country in the State in 1982 at $2,640 per hectare is now valued at $1,350 per hectare.

The equity crunch is expected to drive at least 200 of the region's 1,000 peanut and navy bean farmers out of business this year, according to the Queensland Industry Development Corporation. The slow reduction in peanut and navy bean crops has also turned the nation away from being an exporter of these commodities, thus adding to trade deficit problems. This situation has been compounded by growers in developing countries exporting to Australia at rock bottom prices because of preferential tariff treatment for the Third World. A farmer from the area, Ian MacFarlane, told the Bulletin:

It's a common comment up here that people could have handled bad seasons, low prices or high interest rates but to get them all at once is too much. It is devastating to see the erosion of farmers' financial positions.
Mr MacFarlane continued:

The problem we are facing is that the costs of growing these crops have quadrupled since 1983 while the price received hasn't altered. Combine that with high interest rates and the high value of the Australian dollar and it is a serious situation . . . The same applies to the wheat industry. A number of farmers around the Millmerran area have said to me that this will be their last year unless they get a good crop.

Urban Australians-the great majority of this country's people-have very little grasp of the realities of making a living in the bush. To them, the country is a place to drive through on the way to a holiday. Where it has not already fallen prey to agribusiness, the farm sector is a family affair. Yet such farms rarely make enough profit to pay each productive family member a living wage. I speak from experience when I say this. To that extent, farms are small businesses and should be seen as such by the tax man and the bureaucracy.

They are given that recognition in Japan-a country so often held up by this Government as one which we should try to emulate. In Japan the Government recognises the need to maintain its rural sector and, as such, 72 per cent of a farmer's income is provided by the Japanese Government. Goodness me, if our farmers could get 72 per cent in that way to help them along they would be in clover instead of my telling this sad and sorry story here this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had better move to Japan.

—I do not know whether there would be quite enough room for Senator Boswell and Senator Panizza. But I am certainly not suggesting that we want as much assistance as that in Australia because we are the most efficient farmers in the world.
—What we want is a level playing field.

—That is right. But I certainly suggest that a little recognition and help would relieve the high burdens farming families and communities are now carrying. It is small wonder that in these circumstances farmers are getting restive. This Government and many of its members representing rural areas in my State of Queensland have not even recognised that there is a crisis in rural Australia. Indeed, only a few weeks ago the Chairman of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Caucus primary industries committee, the honourable member for Hinkler, Mr Brian Courtice, told the Australian Rural Times:

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly do not believe or agree rural Australia is in crisis or about to collapse, but there is no doubt wool and wheat have difficulties to overcome.

Mr Rob Hulls, the honourable member for Kennedy and a man who should know better than most ALP members about the plight of those in rural Australia as his electorate covers most of north-west Queensland, rejected suggestions that rural Australia was at crisis point. Instead he maintained that present economic policies were working. Goodness gracious me; he is very much out of touch. Only last Friday I heard him on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio once again denying that a crisis existed in the bush. Mr Lavarch, the honourable member for Fisher-our next door neighbour, federally speaking, as his electorate is near the south Burnett-said the suggestion that the rural economy was going to collapse as a result of high interest rates was `an over-simplification'.

Beyond doubt, the farm sector must live with the strictures that apply to all components of Australian society. However, we must recognise the need to regulate the effects of fast moving change on sectors of the economy which impinge most heavily on individual lives. There is not much point in producing something if it cannot be sold profitably. I am sure that any industry would feel exactly that way. So it is not much use rationalising our rural sector if we eventually see the demise of the family farmer-the person who spends unrecognised hours and effort producing that end product. This Government has often made much of the fact that its major endeavours were to encourage the growth of an adaptable and efficient primary industries and energy sector. It is often when assessing the rural industries that we talk only in terms of how much they have contributed to Australia's growth and not the effort made to achieve those exports. It is here that I would like to point out that in striving to achieve the goal of low cost, internationally competitive industries, the Government has to be aware that it could be killing the goose that lays the golden egg. If in the process of achieving cost efficient industries we push the small family farm off the land, in the long run we are serving no really good purpose for Australia.

Only recently we have started to see the tragic nature of this crisis. Although suicides and mass family murders are the extreme end of the spectrum they do illustrate the utter hopelessness felt by many in the country. But there has also been an increase in the need for more emotional counselling, increased reliance on anti-depressant drugs, increased illness as a result of higher stress and increased family breakdowns. There are many rural women who will wake up tomorrow to face such crises once again. They are the women who spend many hours of loneliness and are required to do back-breaking work; the women who have stood side by side with their husbands clearing the land, tending the animals, fighting the elements and then returning to their homes to make them a nurturing hearth for their families.

They and their families are being penalised today. They are suffering because governments fail to recognise the contribution given to society by those in the outback. They should not be penalised by what is sometimes called the tyranny of distance. I want, once again, to ask this Government to reconsider the position of rural Australia. These people do not have the opportunity to send their children to conveniently located neighbourhood schools, to enjoy good roads and to have access to modern conveniences that are not provided to isolated families.

When will this Government recognise that by the very nature of farming, liquidity is a major problem and that many farmers do not have the means to afford the cost of schooling? They have been given no help and, regrettably, no hope. The Government has failed to recognise when it asset tests the family farm that capital invested in farming earns a very low return. Discrimination now exists for the geographically isolated. We should be ever vigilant that we do not allow ideology on economic issues and crass politics to displace the needs of people. This is what is happening in many industries today and it is at the expense of one of the most important sections of our community-the economic survival of the small family farmer.

Finally, I would like to read from a letter written recently to the Courier-Mail in Brisbane. It contains the comments of an ordinary Australian fed up with what is happening to his country and a plea to the Government to finally recognise the mess we are in. It reads:
I have had enough of watching the Australian Treasurer Paul Keating telling us his economic policies are working.
We have:
Record current account deficits.
The highest continuous interest rates historically, which are doing irreparable damage not only to small business, but to grazing and farming industries as well as the nation.
The greatest number of small business collapses in our history outside the great depression.
An Australian dollar so high it has priced the export industries off world markets and dramatically reduced our opportunities to trade.
A national debt which has, in only a few years, escalated out of all proportion to $140 billion.
The nation's greatest single export earner-the wool industry-with it confidence shattered . . .
A wheat industry about to receive the lowest first payment for many years.
A beef industry struggling for survival, for although it has been receiving high prices (which are now falling fairly dramatically), it is being smothered by escalating costs and government charges.
A desperate sell-off of the Commonwealth Bank to prop up the incompetent financial performance of the Victorian Labor Government.
If this rot doesn't stop, the nation will never recover.
We will have lost the lucky country.
I agree with every word in this Queensland paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow a speaker like Senator Bjelke-Petersen-a genuine country woman speaking for genuine country areas, who always gives of her best at all times in this place even though she may be under pressure in other quarters.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 and other allied complementary monetary Bills. I will briefly address the problems that I perceive in the changes to Austudy, as it pertains to remote and rural areas, and to the aerodrome local ownership plan (ALOP). Also I will give a brief resume of how the Budget has treated primary industries.

One could probably say that this is the non-Budget of all the Budgets that have been brought down by this Government. It is probably the biggest non-Budget brought down by any government in our time. In this 1990-91 Budget the Government has discriminated against rural families and their student children-more so against student children than families. This is happening at a time when rural families are facing a very difficult time, not necessarily of their own making.

I will let the Government off to some extent at this stage because I do not think it fully realised when it framed the Budget some time before August what the position was going to be by the end of this fiscal year. Not only have the Government's monetary policies made it difficult for business people and farmers and their families in rural areas but also the Government has struck another blow which has put the boot into the same families.

The particular decision is the change in the asset test used for assessing eligibility for Austudy allowances. The Government has decided to reduce the asset level from about $320,000 to $200,000. This is a severe reduction. Then, of course, there is an allowance of 50 per cent when it comes to rural holdings. So we are looking at a case where the asset test on rural properties cuts in at $400,000. Where assets, whether business or farm, are used to generate income, 50 per cent, as I have already said, is taken into consideration. For people outside of rural areas we have virtually cut the asset test basis from about $750,000 to $400,000.

Let me say at this stage that I support the asset test. I do not believe in subsidising people who have assets. But in certain cases, in certain regions and in certain industries at certain times it is not possible to stay with that idea all the time. Student children from rural areas are now excluded from any Austudy and family allowance if their families have assets over a certain figure.
An article in the Australian on 22 August 1990 states:
The Government has decided to boost schools funding and expand the higher education system mainly at the expense of student assistance.
The same article quotes Mr Dawkins as saying:
The better targeting of student assistance under Austudy would save $23.4 million in 1990/91. The differences, effective from January 1 next year, include changes to the parental assets tests.

I do not decry Mr Dawkins's effort to improve the education system. I totally agree with it and I will applaud him if he eventually carries this out. But the problem is that in this case the Government is, or seems to be, improving the education system at the expense of some rural based children. As I have said already, asset testing of rural people in times of downturn can severely affect their children's education.

Is the Government suggesting that rural families take up the Senator Walsh option? We have heard Senator Walsh say many times in this place that if one is not producing income from assets one should sell them. One could probably say that that would be a fair enough assumption in normal times. But when there is a general downturn in agriculture all over Australia, it is very hard to accept his idea. Furthermore, if someone wants to sell those assets at this stage of the game, who is going to buy them?

Taking the $400,000 that the Government has now set, in these times I do not know what sort of figure the Government deems those assets should produce. However, if one takes the average return from rural investments at between 5 per cent and 6 per cent over the normal run in reasonable times, $400,000 worth of assets should produce between $20,000 and $25,000, or something like that. That is far less than the figure above which a wage earner is eliminated from getting Austudy or the family allowance for his children. On that basis alone I believe this system is unfair.

Of course one might ask why 1991 was picked as the year in which these measures would be brought into action. Mr Dawkins's statement about better targeting students to boost funding for schools and expand the higher education system certainly has a hollow ring. But once again I will give Mr Dawkins the benefit of the doubt. When he drew up this part of the education budget, he may not have known the extent to which this crisis was going to develop but, knowing the state of the economy, as it was in July 1990 I think he must have had a fair idea. I know he probably could not have forecast the real decline in wheat and wool but he should have been able to forecast the big rise in unemployment.

The Government is meeting its basic commitment to expand student numbers in both secondary and tertiary sectors at the expense, at least in part, of those Australian families who in the past were eligible for, and able to depend on, Austudy to help meet the cost of placing their children in hostels, boarding schools or tertiary colleges. The ability to depend on such an allowance is even more critical with the rural downturn I have been talking about.

What is more, from what I have been told very little information has gone out to schools to date. I suppose one could quite justifiably argue that there is a good while to go until the next school year, but nonetheless, along with the other problems I have dealt with, schools, parents and students themselves are asking questions and are becoming very worried. Of course, there is evidence-and I know the Government's claims and its figures-that more children are staying at school than when this Government came to office, but I suggest that a lot of that has come about because of the evolution of this country. Countries should improve their educational systems and a lot of other things, and by natural uprise this should be occurring in Australia. However, to give credit to the Government, it has done something towards increasing the retention rate in schools, although I think there could be a turnaround. When parents learn about the changes to the assets test, I expect that downward pressures on children remaining at school will be greater.

I also know that some hostels for students in country areas in Western Australia are under threat of closure for existing financial reasons of their own. These are deficit funded hostels in the government system. My guess is that there are at least five such hostels around Western Australia. Prior to the threat to cut out Austudy as well as other threats, the State Government was under pressure to keep a couple of them going. The staff at the Merredin hostel, for example, volunteered to work for a week without pay pending finance coming through. That finance should have come through much more quickly from the State Government; fortunately, as a result of pressure from around the area it came through and they were able to keep the hostel going. Parents had already been put on notice that they might have to find alternative accommodation for their children. These children came from areas upwards of 150 kilometres from Merredin.

Mr Deputy President, you were in Merredin on another inquiry last year so you know of the remoteness of that town. Parents were told they probably would have to look for alternative accommodation for their children. That was back in August. The Government was then able to come forward with enough money to keep the hostel going but it took it out of the maintenance and repair fund for the school. The school buildings themselves have nothing to do with the hostel. By this means, however, the hostel was able to keep going.

Bearing in mind the monetary problems of Western Australia, one must realise that other State governments will be under similar pressures. Even more pressure will be placed on some country hostels and I think a few of them will collapse. Of course, more pressure will then be put on boarding positions, probably in private schools in the city. It will also place more pressure on some parents to remove their children from school altogether. Of course, everyone knows what happens when a child misses out on going to school. In respect of university students who take a year off, the wastage rate is around 80 per cent; they never go back again. For high school students the figure is probably near 100 per cent, unless the children pick it up through adult education.

Those are some of the fears I have about cutting out Austudy for a lot of people. I have contacted some boarding schools in Perth, not the big private schools but the schools at the lower end of the scale, that is, the lower end of the church boarding schools. I have been advised that for a boarding school to remain viable, it needs roughly 100 boarders. A number of years ago I was on the board of a girls' boarding school in Perth. During the year this school decided to close its boarding facilities. Pressure from parents meant that the school board was able to keep the school going by looking for overseas students. The pressure will be on these places even more if they start losing more students. Hopefully one day-and not in the too distant future-the economy will turn around. That would be best for all sides of politics. But if boarding schools or hostels are closed down, it will be hard to get them going again.

Of course the Western Australian Government is also implementing a rationalisation of schools, not only country schools but also city schools. In that case children will have to travel further where they can travel, but many of them will have to look for boarding facilities. The Government, having decided to coincide its harder assets test with the measures I have already discussed, has certainly been a drag on the education system. As I said, the Government may not have known at the time what was going to happen, but the problem is here now and it must be addressed.

We have gone some three or four months down the track from the Budget. We know what the problem is out there and it is not too late for the Government to do something about it. I will just give the Senate a few more figures on Austudy for 16- and 17-year-olds, which, as I understand it, is not subject to the means test. The Government in this Budget has increased the allowance on Austudy for 16- and 17-year-olds from $900 to about $1,300 per annum, and this is not means tested.

At the lower end of the boarding school system it costs $5,300 a year for the boarding fee and in the deficit funded country hostels the cost is $4,800. So for people who are struggling to make ends meet and for rural producers who are not going to make any profit whatsoever in the next 12 months, finding the $3,300 in between is going to be very difficult, especially if they have two or three children in the education system. I have already said that those children from those remote areas must board away. It is not a question of sending them to a snobby private school; they must board to have an education.

Let us compare the city and the country asset testing now. Everyone has a limited asset testing of $400,000. This still discriminates against the rural areas, because in the rural areas it is the producing assets that are taken into consideration-whether one makes a profit or not. But in the city one can have $2m worth of assets and still qualify for Austudy. Before the Minister has a heart attack, I will tell the Senate why. The Minister obviously knows himself.

Let us take the case of a family in the city living within walking distance of a school or a university. Anyone in this place with children will know that it is much cheaper and easier to maintain them in a home than at a distance. Someone could be living in a house worth $1m and within walking distance of a school and if his income is below that threshold then he still qualifies for Austudy. What I am calling on the Government at this stage to do is to look at some suspension of the assets test in the crisis areas of our remote and pastoral areas. I might just quickly mention that even a member of the Government in the other House, Mr O'Neil, took up that very point in his speech to the House of Representatives on 12 September 1990, in which he said:

After many years of working to assist average families to obtain the best future for their children, my personal opinion is that the away rate Austudy allowance does not adequately cover the basic needs of the student.
Then he went on to mention a bit more:
One of the decisions handed down in the August Budget that I believe will put unnecessary strain on rural families is the assets test placed on family allowance payments.
He went on to mention Austudy as well. Obviously, there is someone in the Government with much the same ideas who can see what the problem is.

I would just like to briefly mention a couple of other items in the Budget. The first is the ALOP-the aerodrome local ownership plan-which is being phased out. This was a measure that was well hidden away in the Budget. I certainly did not find it for quite a while and I found it only when the Airport Owners Association rang me. The plan was formed quite a number of years ago to enable local governments to share in their airports and maintain them on a fifty-fifty basis with the Federal Government. About 270 local governments around Australia took up the offer on this fifty-fifty basis. There was no consultation whatsoever between local governments and the Government, to my knowledge, about the fact that this was going to be eliminated. The arrangements are mostly under contract, although there are some word of mouth arrangements that have been going for quite a time. But the Government has still decided, even with the written contracts, to phase them out.

None of the contracts seem to me to be the same, judging from what the local governments I spoke to have said. I was involved with my local government at the time when we took over our airport. Some of the contracts are very loose and one can drive a bus between the conditions. The Government can get out of them very easily. I questioned the Minister concerned, Senator Collins, during the Estimates committee hearings, and he said that he would deal with each local government on a one to one basis, depending on how they stood. I urged all the local governments in Western Australia that may have had airports under this scheme to contact the Minister. I do not mind admitting, and he obviously knows, that no-one seems to have got a very satisfactory answer. They have got answers but they are not satisfactory to the local governments that want to know whether they are going to keep their airports.

I understand that there will be three categories of assistance: 25 per cent, 50 per cent and 100 per cent-I hope I am not wrong with these figures-all depending on the needs of the community. No-one really understands how the criteria work and how a local government is eligible on a social need basis. One of the conditions to qualify is that the airport must be over 100 kilometres by sealed road from a major town. But then there is the case of Mullewa in Western Australia, which lies about 100 kilometres east of Geraldton on a sealed road. That town is on the system but is not going to qualify. What is forgotten is that, going in an easterly direction from Geraldton, the next major set of hospitals is probably in Alice Springs.

If patients were taken to somewhere near the State borders or to a point from where they could be taken to Kalgoorlie, there are another 300 or 400 kilometres in which vehicles may come in or light aircraft may land to take them to the small hospital or to transfer them to another airplane. I cannot see that that is a very good way to go about it. There are other airports that may be able to be closed or phased out, but those strategic ones in those outer rim areas have got to be looked at.

The Government says that there are some viable airports around and, of course, there will be. Probably Perth will always remain viable, as will Karratha and Port Hedland. But there are no others in Western Australia that can remain viable, except maybe Kalgoorlie and Geraldton, but I doubt it. I believe this is something that the Government has to look at again-especially where there are contracts.

I would just like to speak briefly on rural marketing matters. I see that inspection fees have been raised from 60 per cent to 100 per cent. Our side of politics believes that the inspection charges at fifty-fifty was a good way to go because the rural producer certainly had an interest on inspection to make sure that the best produce left Australia and that we would not have a pesticide in beef fiasco or a kangaroo meat scandal again. We believe that rural production benefits not only rural producers and that the other half should be picked up by the rest of Australia because of the export income we earn.

If we take the Budget at face value, spending on primary industries has increased, but that comes mostly from the increased wool tax, which goes into a revolving fund of money taken from farmers and used as a back-up when wool does not reach the reserve price. I could speak for another half an hour on the rural industry but my time is drawing to an end. I would like to put on the record-if Senator Bjelke-Petersen has not already done so-the position in the bush concerning wheat and wool. We will have much more debate concerning wool before this session is over.

As all honourable senators know, the wheat industry is experiencing a great downturn. I believe that the Government should be doing more than it is, by talking to the United States Government and to the European Community in the hope that they will bring sense into their export enhancement programs, by which they are subsidising their export sales by up to $A70 a tonne. The Government could also do much more to hold down the price of fuel, not by pegging the price of oil but by passing back a certain amount of the windfall gains it is making as a result of the Gulf crisis.

In conclusion, I can tell the Senate that the country is hurting. Having attended four rural crisis meetings, I can tell honourable senators that our concern is with the way in which small businesses are hurting. Rural producers probably have another three or four months before they really hurt. There is the genuine complaint that the banks are not passing on the total interest rates cuts. Finally, the biggest concern amongst the women and children relates to higher education and the cut-off point for eligibility for Austudy, with which they badly need help. We will talk more about these issues when the crisis hits the rural sector, probably in March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1990-91, the Appropriation Bill ( No. 1) 1990-91 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1990-91, I wish to pursue a matter that I have been pursuing for about two years in this place through Estimates committees and the Appropriation debates. I refer to our presence in Antarctica and what I see as some of the inadequacies that have been experienced over the past couple of years. While some people see this as a criticism of the Director and senior members of the staff of the Antarctic Division, that is not the case. The pressures that have been placed upon them by the former Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories and senior bureaucrats in Canberra have made their position quite untenable.

SPEECH.PARA: I first became interested in this matter during the construction of the Aurora Australis. On many occasions I raised the problems that I saw with the construction of that ship. I asked questions about the costings but the then Minister and the departmental officers consistently declined to provide an answer concerning the extent of the Commonwealth's financial liability for Aurora Australis immediately prior to the signing of the charter contract. When the contract was signed in October 1988, the ship had already been under construction for 10 months and it was launched only 11 months later. This happened because the then Minister, in his exuberance to promote what he thought was a re-election of the Labor Government in New South Wales, put out press releases and instructed a letter of intent to be signed. In the end, there was no choice for the Commonwealth but to sign whatever contract the tenderers, P and O, wanted.

The contract that was entered into was certainly not weighted in favour of the Australian Government. Let me list some of the concerns that I had at the time and still have. The accepted bid was $10.1m for the first season, or $124m at present value for 10 seasons. After the tenders were let, the Commonwealth entered into a contract with P and O to pay the company $12m for the first full season and more than $150m for 10 seasons.

I am very concerned about the requirements that were necessary for the safety of the crew as well as their experience level. In fact, this is my major concern about the Antarctic Division and the way in which it is going. In the contract that was signed, for the first time ever the Commonwealth agreed to meet all non-Antarctic season lay-ups, which amounted to $0.5m per year. The lay-up port was not specified. That meant that P and O could decide to lay the ship up in any port without regard to the extent of costs which the Commonwealth was to bear. The ship was taken on charter at Newcastle, not Hobart, which incurred significant additional cost to the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth paid an additional $460,000 for the provision of scientific equipment by P and O. Crew numbers and pay conditions that were negotiated by P and O with the unions were simply passed on to the Commonwealth. There was no reduction in the charter rate given for extended besetment in ice during the Antarctic season, which was a standard condition in previous contracts.

If an ice pilot was needed to meet the requirements of the Antarctic experience for this particular vessel, the Commonwealth paid for the pilot. That was the first time that had been included in a contract. The list goes on and on. The Commonwealth credited the owner with one full day's charter, more than $50,000 per Antarctic season, which had not happened before.

During the construction of the ship no proper monitoring by technically qualified people was carried out on behalf of the Commonwealth. In the finish, not only was P and O unable to deliver the ship in October 1989 for the start of the 1989-90 season but the ship was unable to be delivered until 15 February 1990.

I have also raised matters of concern about the operation in the Antarctic. There was a large leakage of 90,000 litres of oil at Casey. On 27 June I called for an independent inquiry into this incident but that did not happen. Antarctic officials claimed that 50,000 to 55,000 litres of fuel had been recovered, but I noticed in the Adelaide Advertiser that the Station Leader, Joan Russell, stated that 32,000 litres were recovered. This still leaves unaccounted for, debatably anyway, 58,000 litres, 290 drums or 58 tonnes-whichever measure one wants to use. This oil is possibly under the winter snow. The expeditions at Casey did a marvellous job in trying to clean up the mess, but the environment there is of concern to me and I do not believe that we were given the answers we should have been.

Another concern I had about safety related to the ice runway. Were Senator Richardson here tonight he would probably remember the number of questions I asked him about this project. Unfortunately, this has been somewhat of a fiasco. Over 15 years the Antarctic Division has spent millions of dollars on air transport studies for an experimental airstrip at Casey. No doubt, were it feasible, acceptable and possible, it would be something that everybody would welcome.

However, in 1985, the then director of the Antarctic Division, Mr Bleasel, was concerned by the apparent waste, so he commissioned a review into the air transport options. That review concluded that Casey was not operationally feasible and he cancelled the project. However, just this year we have seen the present director, immediately on taking over the job, reopening the whole project. So far the failed efforts to try to establish a runway there have cost this Commonwealth Government another $1.1m. By the way, they did not even carry out an environmental impact study for that airstrip.

As I mentioned earlier, the question of the ice pilot was raised by my colleague Senator Archer during Estimates. I was not present. In previous questions that I had asked during Estimates I was told that there were no problems with--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were you?

—I was with the senator's colleague, Duncan Kerr, in the Soviet Union. I will get around to that later. I was led to believe that there were no problems with the qualifications of the crew members. It was set down in the charter contract that the experienced captain of the Aurora Australis would be four years in Antarctica in a vessel the size of the Aurora Australis or any others.

SPEECH.PARA: We find now that in the original contract the ice captain had to satisfy four years Antarctic ice strategy experience and also that the first officer and two deck officers had to comply with similar experiences. We find out in answers to questions given in Estimates this year, and I have to read my notes, that the director said:
My view is that he has the equivalent with the training program he did in the north of three.

The upshot of it is that in the first year we have to employ an ice pilot, which will cost the Commonwealth Government another $28,000. I have raised the question before about this problem. I was told that everything was okay and that the experienced crew and captains were no problems. These were promised when the charter was filled, but now we find that it is all starting to fall apart again.

As I said earlier to Senator Tate across the chamber, I have been recently on part of a parliamentary delegation to the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, Mongolia and Japan. Whilst I was in the Soviet Union I took the opportunity to discuss with our Russian counterparts Australia's possible use of an Antarctic vessel for our own purposes in the sub-continent. I pursued this matter on previous occasions. Most recently, my colleagues Senator Archer and Senator Baume also mentioned this matter during Estimates. The reason I bring this forward at this stage is that the Antarctic Division is currently considering arrangements which will set in place the chartering of a vessel for the next three Antarctic seasons. It is my belief that perhaps not sufficient consideration is being given to the use of a Russian vessel. I would therefore like to relay some of my concerns and also some of the details of my discussions.

By way of background, Anderson Hughes, who is the current chartering contractor for the Antarctic Division, arranged for the charter of the Icebird for the 1991 season. That is a back-up to the Aurora Australis, the second ship, the Aurora Australis already being in Antarctica and having one or two problems. This decision was made by a selection committee made up of Anderson Hughes, the Antarctic Division and the Department of Administrative Services with the Department of Transport and Communications acting as a technical adviser.

The final choice of a vessel was narrowed down to the Icebird and an offer by the Soviet Arctic and Antarctic Research Institute which was for the vessel Akademik Federov. Indeed, the offer by the Russians was prompted by encouragement from the Australian Government during a visit to the Soviet Union by Senator Richardson and Mr Blunn from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. It also should be pointed out that the Akademik Federov is a state of the art research ice breaker and, as such, the use of the Akademik Federov would have provided our own scientists with a unique opportunity to work with the Russians. I might add that that vessel was only built in 1987. It is my understanding that the price of the Akademik Federov, which included bunker fuel, helicopter and crew overtime, was $2.9m whilst the Icebird's price is estimated to have been around $3.6m including bunkers and overtime. It is easy to see from the comparison that the difference between the Akademik Federov and the Icebird was somewhere around $0.8m and $1.1m.

Apart from the obvious financial advantages the Akademik Federov offered a number of other features which should have made it attractive. The fuel tanks are inside a double skin hull, a similar design future to that of the Aurora Australis. This provides much greater protection for the Antarctic environment from oil spills should the vessel ever become involved in an accident. The Antarctic Division's strategic transport plan makes reference to possible problems with the Icebird by stating:
The potential exists for environmental problems as fuel is carried in tanks again its outer hull.

The Akademik Federov also has on board long range, heavy lift helicopters which would have enabled access to the stations earlier in the season and, therefore, an opportunity has been lost for Australia to trial larger ship based helicopters at no cost. This is very puzzling, particularly when the Antarctic Division had previously wished to try larger helicopters in the 1989-90 season, but they proved too expensive to charter for such a short time. It is easy to consider the value of such helicopters because the Aurora Australis has already been fitted at considerable expense with a special hangar and helideck to cater for such large helicopters, at the recommendation of the Antarctic Science Advisory Committee.

I have already mentioned the benefits which would have flowed from our scientists working with the Russians in the spirit of the Antarctic treaty. I know from my personal experience that there is a ready willingness by the Russians to become involved in assisting Australia's Antarctic efforts. When the Russian Premier, Mr Ryzhkov, visited our country recently there was a joint announcement with Mr Hawke of a special series of stamps to depict Australian-Soviet cooperation in Antarctic marine research. The Russians must certainly be questioning how serious to that commitment are our intentions in light of some previous decisions.

Naturally, as a representative of Tasmania, like my colleagues Senator Tate and Mr Duncan Kerr, who accompanied me on this trip I had discussions with representatives of Russian fishing fleets in Vladivostok and Nakhodka. We spoke with many of the Russian politicians in the Soviet far east. I do not know about Mr Kerr, but I am concerned because the chartering of the Akademik Federov would have provided Hobart with an ideal opportunity to demonstrate its willingness and capacity to service Soviet Antarctic and southern ocean ships. There is no doubt that this would have provided a considerable financial boost for local businesses and could have served as an important preliminary to the use by the Russians of the port of Hobart for their fishing fleet.

We should also remember that this will be the first season in which the Aurora Australis with its relatively new crew will be working in the Antarctic and that the Akademik Federov would have provided valuable icebreaker back-up for our own vessel. When these and other issues were raised by me on previous occasions, the Antarctic Division has responded that the Akademik Federov was far too large to enter Mawson Harbour. However, I believe that the Russians were prepared to offer the Division every assurance that the Akademik Federov was quite capable of entering Mawson Harbour, and even if conditions prevented entry, cargo could easily be transferred by the large helicopters from outside the harbour.

There were also concerns raised regarding the possible logistics in a voyage charter. However, I believe that these should be weighed against, firstly, the financial advantages, and, secondly, the willingness of the Russians to amend their own plans to suit our needs.

It is true that the decision which was made to charter the Icebird over the Akademik Federov for the 1990-91 season cannot be changed regardless of the circumstances. However, there have been more developments in relation to further chartering requirements and I believe it is imperative that the Antarctic Division and those responsible for decision making should be prepared to give much more detailed consideration to the use of a Russian vessel. On 14 August 1990 Anderson Hughes invited expressions of interest in and firm proposals for providing a ship to the Antarctic Division for three seasons from 1991 to 1992.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The weekend before last I was present in Pittsworth in south-east Queensland to attend a rural crisis meeting which was called jointly by the Millmerran Shire Council and the Pittsworth Shire Council. Before speaking further on this matter, I seek leave to table the following documents: a meeting format sheet; a copy of resolutions tabled at the meeting; and a press release that was issued by the Millmerran Shire Council following the rural crisis rally.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —A quick perusal of the documents I have tabled shows that there was a great deal of concern in Pittsworth that day. The press release issued after the meeting suggests that some 2,000 people were in attendance at the meeting. While it was difficult to estimate the number of people actually present from the speaking position because they extended on one side way beyond my field of vision, I would point out that the organisers of the rural crisis meeting had at the meeting attendance registers, and I can only assume that the figure of 2,000 people is roughly correct.

SPEECH.PARA: Given that the population of Pittsworth and Millmerran Shires is not substantially large, a turnout of 2,000 people is quite remarkable. I believe that it shows the depth of the rural crisis that is being experienced all across Queensland as it is being experienced in other areas of Australia. The people who were there were not hotheads or rednecks-or whatever phrase some people like to apply to them. They were fairly conservative, quiet people from provincial Queensland. They were people who would not even dream of having a protest rally, let alone saying some of the things that were said. There was justifiable anger at the Federal Government's inaction and at what they considered to be a neglect by the Federal Government of their particular plight.

A perusal of the resolutions that were carried is very interesting. Although we had what some people may consider to be, shall we say, more inflammatory resolutions-I am not particularly in favour of one resolution which recommends a blockading of food to Canberra as it would not be survival of the fittest but survival of the fattest, and I fear that I may be one of the first to go-I believe that the resolutions show the depth of feeling. A lot of other resolutions were passed-ones that we would all consider much more reasonable and ones that I would hope the Government would be willing to take on board. In particular, there was grave concern over the imposition of assets tests and the reduced values of assets tests for such things as family allowance, family allowance supplement and Austudy.

There was also concern about the quarantine standards that are currently being imposed by the Federal Government on agricultural produce imported from overseas. There was a concern in these areas-and areas that are not particularly threatened-that if we impose very lax quarantine standards we run a very grave risk of losing the natural protections that we enjoy as an island. Certainly the people of Pittsworth and Millmerran have an interest in intensive production of pork and, therefore, are concerned about the importation of Canadian pork. But they are also concerned about issues that do not touch their area. I refer, for example, to the potential importation of bananas from Ecuador with the diseases of black sigatoka and moko.

The people at this meeting were not thinking just of themselves. They were also thinking of people throughout provincial Queensland, as indeed they were thinking of people throughout provincial Australia. One of the things that I found personally disturbing was that at the end of the meeting the people who were assembled there produced effigies of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating). Those effigies were strung up on a pole and roasted on a bonfire.

Senator Sherry might find this amusing, although I caution him that if he wishes to make it to the front bench he should not laugh at such matters. Although some people may find these matters amusing, I think the meeting showed that there are people throughout provincial Australia who are suffering very greatly from this Government's policy. There are people who are at their wit's end. The message is very clear that this country cannot afford to lose further farmers from the land.

Suggestions that all we have to do is to improve farm efficiency are way off the mark. This underlines the fact that if we continue to neglect our agricultural sector, any hope of improvement in agricultural efficiency is absolutely ridiculous. It is not the bad farmers that we are losing at the moment but the good farmers. We are losing people who may have been on the land for 20 or 30 years. If we lose those farmers, we lose the very core of our agricultural efficiency. We lose what drives our rural economy.

It was interesting to look at the figures that were produced by various speakers at the meeting. It was suggested that up to $16m or $17m of agricultural income alone may be lost from the Pittsworth and Millmerran Shires during this financial year-$16m to $17m of agricultural earnings.
