When one applies the multiplier effect, the actual loss of earnings, the loss of product in those two shires in southeast Queensland alone, is frightening. That shows the truth of the fact that we desperately need a drop in interest rates to return income to the agricultural sector, not just in Queensland but throughout Australia.

It is an oft-touted figure and a figure that I believe is correct that for every 1c drop in the Australian dollar we will give to our agricultural sector earnings in excess of $150m during the course of the next year. In Queensland alone a 1c drop in the dollar will add another $18m to the cattle industry-and $40m to the cattle industry across Australia. We must start to recognise that the pain that currently exists in rural Australia cannot go on indefinitely. One cannot keep starving the body, otherwise the patient will die.

I believe that we face a very real crisis. Although members on the Government benches might not believe that there is a crisis or might not wish to talk about it, ostensibly because they are afraid that they will talk down the rural economy, the very clear fact is that a crisis is upon us now. The time has come for government to implement action which will save some of those thousands of people who turned out in Pittsworth. It is time that the Government took the opportunity to take a bold step to ensure that we do not lose more farmers from the land, not just in Queensland but in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia.

The sorts of things that this Government must consider as a matter of urgency are a reduction in fuel taxes and substantial reductions in interest rates to bring the dollar below 70c. It must consider-and I hope that the Senate will accept this during its deliberations tomorrow-the very real need to examine our policy with respect to dumping and countervailing. I believe that we should consider the possibility of introducing as a matter of urgency penalty rates of duty on subsidised goods from overseas. We cannot continue to allow our farm sector to die, to allow it to be strangled and suffocated by cheap imports that flood in from overseas, bringing with them, as they do, the very real risk of disease which could destroy our home-grown agricultural industry.

We cannot allow those cheap, subsidised groups to be brought in from countries such as the United States of America, China, Ecuador or from wherever, and destroy the livelihoods of Australian farm families. There is a very real crisis-a crisis which will continue while the people of provincial Australia lack any confidence in the Government that is supposed to look after them and represent them.

There is another rural crisis meeting taking place this Saturday in Emerald, a meeting that I believe is particularly significant. I shall be there. I hope that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), or at least one of his representatives, will be willing to turn up, talk to the people, listen to their problems and explain the Government's strategy, because quite frankly it is just insufficient and wholly inaccurate for the Government to continue to ignore the very legitimate concerns of these fine Australians who are struggling to make ends meet.

I conclude with a plea to the Minister and to those on the Government benches to pay heed to what the people of provincial Australia are saying and hopefully to take on board some of their suggestions and take some real steps to restore some sort of productivity and opportunity once more to provincial Australia because it is an area that is suffering dreadfully at the moment and an area whose suffering will continue whilst the Government continues its inaction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Labor Party (ALP) has its centenary celebrations next year and there will be many events to mark this occasion. However, another centenary which I believe is worth noting and one intimately linked with the formation of the Labor Party has passed this week. The date 5 November 1890 marked the end of the great maritime strike. This strike ended with the total defeat of the striking workers, but this very defeat became the catalyst for the formation of the greatest political party Australia has known-the Australian Labor Party; a party with a history and a background which make the others seem ephemeral and insignificant. The ALP is the oldest democratic socialist party in the English speaking world and its formation provided a model and an impetus for the establishment of democratic socialist parties in other countries which were emerging from colonial rule. I know that even some who sit on the Opposition benches acknowledge the great and seminal role of the Australian Labor Party both inside and outside Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now 150 years since trade unions began in one form or another in Australia. The trade union movement in Australia was not an imported one. It grew in response to the way the Australian colonies grew. It was probably the gold rushes of the 1850s which created a working class for the first time and these workers soon began to form trade unions to defend their political and economic rights. However, it was really the 1880s before there began to be any real coordination of trade union activities. The first intercolonial trade union congress was held in Sydney in 1879 and this began a network that brought the various trade unions throughout the different colonies into closer connection. During the 1880s Australia saw a huge period of growth, and such periods have traditionally seen a growth in industrial activity and gains in workers' pay and conditions. This was certainly the case during that decade.

The 1880s bore an uncanny resemblance to the 1980s in that it was a period of unbridled capitalist greed: a boom based on an illusion-the same illusion that we became very familiar with in the 1980s. Huge amounts of foreign capital poured into Australia and land prices soared. Some individuals became enormously rich but little of lasting benefit remained when the bubble burst at the end of 1880s. The bursting of the bubble saw widespread poverty and hardship and the rapid erosion of the rights so recently gained by workers. In fact new, harsh industrial laws against striking, picketing and even the publication of material were enacted-particularly in New South Wales and Queensland-which made the conditions of workers worse than ever. Up to this time, members of the colonial legislatures had not been paid, so it is obvious that they would have come almost entirely from the wealthy and landed classes and would represent the interests of their kind.

The general attitude of these ruling class legislators was one of total belief in the workings of the capitalist economy and a belief that these workings should on no account be impeded. In addition to this, most of them believed that the poor had only themselves to blame for their situation. There was very little by way of a social welfare safety net. This had not mattered quite so much during the boom years of the 1880s, but the economic disaster of the 1890s fully exposed the sink or swim nature of Australian society. As far as the rights and conditions of workers were concerned, the parliamentary representatives of the time had no doubt on which side they stood. They believed that the workers would have been happy under the benevolent guidance of their employers if they had not been stirred up by a few agitators. Apparently many of these men believed that these agitators even caused the depression of the 1890s by scaring off foreign investors.

The great maritime strike of 1890 was, as I said earlier, squashed within a few months and the workers were totally defeated. Nevertheless, it has established an important place in Australian history alongside the shearers strike of 1891. In fact, the two strikes were very much linked. The maritime strike began in Melbourne, with a dispute between shipowners and ships officers over the right of the officers to an industrial organisation linked with the Trades Hall Council. The shipowners were horrified by this. They regarded the officers as class traitors for their failure to identify with their employers. For a long time officers' pay and conditions had stagnated, or even gone backwards, whilst those of the ordinary seamen had improved, even to the extent in some cases that they received more money at the end of a voyage than did the officers. The supposed sweetener for the officers was that they had a higher status-they were gentlemen-whereas the sailors were workers. Eventually the officers realised that the right to feelings of superiority did not put dinner on the table and they began to take industrial action.

Even though the industrial problems in the maritime industry began in this way, the focus soon moved to New South Wales. The strike became a contest between capital and labour in its purist form. Many of the people who had come to Australia, be they bosses or workers, were adventurous and free spirited-the qualities required to move to a new and largely unknown country on the other side of the world. With the hardships endured in the establishment of the colonies, and the arrival of many people for the gold rush, an uneasy equilibrium had been maintained in colonial life. The rampant capitalism of the 1880s followed by the depression of the 1890s destroyed that equilibrium. The trade unions realised that the time had come to try to ameliorate the worst aspects of the society and to press the claims of those who had no access to other vehicles for doing so.

The employers for their part were equally busy. The pastoralists were fighting a battle to have their wool shorn by non-union labour in order that they could avoid improvements in pay and conditions for workers in one of the hardest jobs in the colonies. Their battle included collaboration and joint planning with the shipowners to ensure that their wool reached its markets unimpeded. The shearers, in their turn, appealed to the maritime workers not to handle or ship non-union shorn wool and the maritime workers responded. The strike started in New South Wales on 16 August 1890, involving 10 unions. At its peak, when the shearers came out also from 24 September to 2 October, it involved some 15,000 workers-by far the largest industrial action ever seen in the colonies.

The strike was finally called off on 5 November. The pastoralists, fired by this victory, launched the famous confrontation with the shearers in 1891 in which they won another crushing victory. In this climate the capitalist classes had the unions at their mercy, or thought they did. The unions had been beaten and humiliated in a series of disputes. High unemployment meant that they had little bargaining power on behalf of their members.

However, in many ways these so-called victories prepared the way for a huge reordering of Australian society which was to the ultimate benefit of the workers. For one thing, the maritime strike revealed that, although the workers were defeated, the labour movement was well regarded in the general community. This attitude was to be the most important in subsequent events. Secondly, these industrial defeats caused trade union leaders to look, for the first time, to the political sphere to achieve their goals. They made the decision that trade union endorsed candidates should contest the 1891 New South Wales election. And so, out of apparent defeat, grew a new party and a more mature and diverse political climate in Australian politics.

Once the Trades and Labour Council had made the decision to contest the 1891 election, matters got under way with amazing speed. The timing of the election gave it only three months to organise, so it straightaway called on unions to form Labor Electoral Leagues. The actual beginning of our Party was marked by the formation of the first Labor Electoral League at Balmain on 4 April 1891. This was quickly followed by many more in the suburbs, and country branches were established in provincial centres and mining towns.

Even 100 years ago the Labor Party showed the superior organising skills that still benefit our Party today. Even though the new Party contested the election with less than three months to organise and with very little money left after the recent industrial disputation, it contested all 42 seats in the metropolitan area of Sydney, of which it won 15. In the country areas another 20 were elected under the Labor Party banner, as well as several independents who were sympathetic to Labor's cause.

All this was achieved against a background of doomsaying from the establishment. Its leaders thundered in parliament, in churches and in the press that the new Party would bring into parliament people who were not suitable to be there-and, of course, that meant workers. It is certainly true that the new Party brought into parliament people who would have had no hope of getting there through the existing parties. But although the catalyst for the formation of our Party was the union movement and the recent industrial confrontation, even 100 years ago the Labor Party represented so much more than this.

Earlier I used the phrase `democratic socialist' to describe the Labor Party. But even within the Party, and certainly outside it, there are those who find this term anathema. They prefer the description `social democratic', which is apparently a less threatening term. Even historians argue about whether the Labor Party was established with socialist ideals or whether it was formed to represent a different set of petit bourgeois interests and, indeed, that even the workers it represented did not have a real class consciousness because of the nature of Australian society. To my mind that is really a non-argument. Then, as now, the Labor Party represented a broad range of people with different political beliefs and objectives-all those whose interests and aspirations had not been represented by the existing conservative parties. To some of its supporters it was a `socialist' party; to others it was not.

Those who flocked to it included social reformers and radicals, many from the union movement and from the middle class; many intellectuals; and a good number of rural workers, small farmers and small businessmen. This wide range was reflected in the newly elected members of parliament. It was reported at the time that the new members included several miners, three or four printers, a boilermaker, three sailors, a plasterer, a journalist, a draper, a suburban mayor, two engineers, a carrier, a few shearers, a tailor, a mine owner, a squatter and an MD-truly the party of the people in the widest sense. Mr Deputy President, I am sure that you approve of the latter. I believe that, on the whole, the disparate elements represented by the Labor Party created, and continue to create, within the Party a dynamic tension which is creative and beneficial. Problems are caused not by this conflict but when one tendency obtains a stranglehold within the Party and genuine debate is stultified.

It is my belief that it is a very productive exercise for the Labor Party to continue to reflect on its roots and to remember whom and what it was created to represent and to continue to represent; to accommodate both the battlers and the idealists of our society; and to continue to represent a genuine intellectual and ideological tradition. This is the strength of the Australian Labor Party and it is our unique place within Australian society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.56 p.m.
